From jeme at brelin.net  Sat May  1 06:26:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

Subject: [PLUG] SCO Clarification

 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0404301509440.5686@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405010608030.2192@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Fri, 30 Apr 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
> On Fri, 30 Apr 2004, Robert Kopp wrote:
> > "The world, especially here in America, is shifting to one that is an
> > information society," McBride said. "In the future, is that $229 billion
> > in software still going to be there? Or in the case of the Free Software
> > Foundation's goal, is proprietary software going to go away?"

McBride seems to be stating simply the goal of the Free Software
Foundation and it's a fairly accurate depiction of one of that
organization's goals.  I fully support that goal, by the way.

>   The answer is a resounding "no" regardless of whether the software is
> proprietary or sold under the GPL.

Huh?!?  To which question is your resounding "no" the answer?

"Is that $229 billion in software still going to be there?"
"no"

Logically, this would have to be what you meant, but then you go on to
write about software profiteers as though they are the future rather than
relics of the past that will eventually fade away.  So it's totally
contradictory.

"Is proprietary software going to go away?"
"no"

This can't be what you mean because you write "whether the software is
proprietary or sold under the GPL".  Software distributed under the GPL
(by trade or share) is in no way proprietary.

> There are numerous solid, value-filled applications for linux that are
> proprietary and cost money; e.g., VMware.

UML seems to have filled that niche pretty nicely, I'd say.  Other systems
will surely be developing compatible user mode equivalencies and VMware
will go out of business.  Hope you don't depend on the software for
anything critical else you might get stuck with a piece of software that
is unmaintained and unmaintainable.

> Also, there's nothing in the GPL that prevents an application being sold
> (e.g., Red Hat's distribution, Slackware's distribution, SuSE's
> distribution) with source and the GPL.

Well, no, but how many copies are you going to sell when the folks who buy
it can and will simply put it on their website/DAV/P2P system and share it
freely?

There is no value in information already recorded.  The value is in
recording new information.  (I use this loosely to also encompass the
re-ordering of existing information in non-trivial ways.)  Once it is
recorded, it can be shared freely and all can benefit from it.  People
will be paid for producing new work (mostly via modifications of existing
work, of course) and providing services rather than simply redistributing
bits.  We've got a nice bit distribution system and it doesn't need to be
artificially restricted to promote an archaic business model.

J.

From john at meissen.org  Sat May  1 11:13:02 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Sat May  1 11:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SCO Clarification
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Sat, 01 May 2004 06:26:01 PDT.)
             <20040501132601.27872.837.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20040501181231.D349773A09@john.meissen.org>

Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> said:
> UML seems to have filled that niche pretty nicely, I'd say.  Other
> systems will surely be developing compatible user mode equivalencies
> and VMware will go out of business.  Hope you don't depend on the
> software for anything critical else you might get stuck with a piece
> of software that is unmaintained and unmaintainable. 

It's a nice fantasy, but not particularly realistic.

While it may or may not apply specifically to VMware, as long as software
is patentable there will be proprietary software for which there will
not be a quality OSS alternative. And before you go quoting jpeg vs png
and ogg vorbis vs mpeg, note that I did not say ALL patented software.

And even when there aren't patent issues Open Source Software has to
compete on quality, where it often fails. OSS development only works
if there are interested developers. A lot of OSS projects reach a
stage of minimal functionality and then development stops, mostly
because the few developers involved lost interest or don't have the
time to make the project a priority. Unless there's a business model
based on the application there's no guarantee of any support or specific
development plans. If I were a business that depended on the continued
development and support of a specific project I don't know that I'd want 
to bet my future on that development model. When an OSS application
becomes unmaintained it's true that it's still maintainable since the
source is available. But the cost of paying for even one developer to do 
that is significantly more than the cost of the license I'd have to pay 
for a commercial/proprietary product.

And finally, there's marketing. I learned a long time ago that a bad
product with good marketing will be more successful than a good product
with bad marketing, even when that good product is close to free.

So yes, there will always be proprietary software.
> Rich Shepard wrote:
> > Also, there's nothing in the GPL that prevents an application being sold
> > (e.g., Red Hat's distribution, Slackware's distribution, SuSE's
> > distribution) with source and the GPL.

> Well, no, but how many copies are you going to sell when the folks who buy
> it can and will simply put it on their website/DAV/P2P system and share it
> freely?

So you're saying there's really no point in any of these distributions
existing? Interesting, since without them Linux wouldn't be enjoying 
it's current increase in popularity.

john-

From jeme at brelin.net  Sun May  2 00:09:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Sun May  2 00:09:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SCO Clarification
In-Reply-To: <20040501181231.D349773A09@john.meissen.org>
References: <20040501181231.D349773A09@john.meissen.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405011338160.2192@shaft.bitmine.net>

[I started writing this message this morning and got pulled away from the
computer until just now... I'm going to finish it and send it before
reading the rest of the list.  Enjoy.]

On Sat, 1 May 2004, John Meissen wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> said:
> > UML seems to have filled that niche pretty nicely, I'd say.  Other
> > systems will surely be developing compatible user mode equivalencies
> > and VMware will go out of business.  Hope you don't depend on the
> > software for anything critical else you might get stuck with a piece
> > of software that is unmaintained and unmaintainable.
>
> It's a nice fantasy, but not particularly realistic.

If by "realistic" you mean "the way things are today", you're right... but
that's a very narrow view.

There is an old guard standing watch over the systems of the past that
have led to the creation and maintenance of the "powers that be".  Some
are direct benefactors and wielders of that power and others are merely
"conservative" and don't know how to look to something better.  Through
methodic subversion and the occassional outright rebellion, we can push
those powers aside and develop new systems that are as nice as our
fantasies.

> While it may or may not apply specifically to VMware, as long as
> software is patentable there will be proprietary software for which
> there will not be a quality OSS alternative. And before you go quoting
> jpeg vs png and ogg vorbis vs mpeg, note that I did not say ALL patented
> software.

There are surely problems with patent law!  However, when administered at
all (actual review of patent applications for non-obviousness and prior
art), it's difficult to see how a patent would cover code that couldn't be
simulated without violating the patent.

Your examples are quite fine.  It's an interesting tactic to give the
counter-argument and then dismiss it out of hand.  Is that something like
a pre-emptive strike?

> And even when there aren't patent issues Open Source Software has to
> compete on quality, where it often fails.

There are some applications for which there is no clear Free equivalent,
sure, but there are capabilities in Free Software that are just not part
of the design considerations in the proprietary software world.

While one could say that, say, sodipodi doesn't do half of what
Illustrator does, you could also argue that Illustrator isn't nearly as
scriptable nor are its data files nearly as configurable or flexible in
their interface with other programs.

The GNU project got the ball rolling with writing Free replacement
software for existing proprietary applications and utilities.  Free
Software has progressed to include more than just duplicating the
proprietary software functionality, but evolving new kinds of applications
and systems that do things "the unix way".

So there are certain applications that can be compared
feature-for-feature, but so long as you use the proprietary work as the
standard, the Free Software will fall short.  A comparison in the other
direction will have the opposite result.  They are different beasts.

> OSS development only works if there are interested developers. A lot of
> OSS projects reach a stage of minimal functionality and then development
> stops, mostly because the few developers involved lost interest or don't
> have the time to make the project a priority.

This is true of all kinds of human endeavor... not just "OSS projects".

> Unless there's a business model based on the application there's no
> guarantee of any support or specific development plans.

Just because there's a business model based on the application doesn't
mean there's a guarantee of any support or specific development plans.

> If I were a business that depended on the continued development and
> support of a specific project I don't know that I'd want to bet my
> future on that development model.

The smart money, of course, doesn't bet the future on a business that
depends on the continued development and support of a specific project.
Flexibility is key.

Don't look for the solution that depends on the piece of software that is
most likely to be around in ten years.  Look for the solution that doesn't
depend on any particular piece of software and allows for drop-in
replacements or easy re-engineering.

> When an OSS application becomes unmaintained it's true that it's still
> maintainable since the source is available. But the cost of paying for
> even one developer to do that is significantly more than the cost of the
> license I'd have to pay for a commercial/proprietary product.

Well, this would be true if you had to pay developers for every single
software product you run, but that's just not the case.  For most
computer-dependent mid-to-large-sized businesses, the cost of software
licensing and support is more than the cost of a developer or two.

When I worked at ELI, members of my team were specifically told to spend
time enhancing a few of the key Free Software and merely open source tools
that we used and contribute back to the community.  Other tools, we used
in their mainstream development branches and didn't modify at all.  The
network of companies hiring developers to enhance different products made
for a large group of programmers working on the complete set of tools for
less money than licensing a proprietary replacement set for each company.

> And finally, there's marketing. I learned a long time ago that a bad
> product with good marketing will be more successful than a good product
> with bad marketing, even when that good product is close to free.

Yeah, what we call "marketting" today is what Adam Smith called a "market
flaw" in 1790.  There are lots of ways to make it difficult for people to
make informed decisions.  So long as there is power to be gained from
exploiting other people, a few will continue to attempt exploitation.
That's just one more damned good reason to get rid of the exploitation and
the power by eliminating proprietary software once and for all time.

> So yes, there will always be proprietary software.

You're coming from a sharply narrowed viewpoint, I think.

> > Rich Shepard wrote:
> > > Also, there's nothing in the GPL that prevents an application being
> > > sold (e.g., Red Hat's distribution, Slackware's distribution, SuSE's
> > > distribution) with source and the GPL.
>
> > Well, no, but how many copies are you going to sell when the folks who
> > buy it can and will simply put it on their website/DAV/P2P system and
> > share it freely?
>
> So you're saying there's really no point in any of these distributions
> existing?

I have no idea how you read that into what I wrote.  I just wrote that, as
the pipes get bigger and the connectivity gets wider, there will be less
and less interest in plopping down cash for mere distribution of
information.  The vendors MUST include some added value that is
demonstrably worth the price alone.  Hence, the software that they produce
will merely be a tool for ensnaring more customers to the services that
have real value.  In other words, they won't be selling software anymore.

> Interesting, since without them Linux wouldn't be enjoying it's current
> increase in popularity.

Again with the narrow view.  This is a transitional phase and it is surely
going to give rise to transitional (hybrid) organizations.  But we are
already seeing the distribution business disintegrate and the services
business come to the fore in these organizations.  RHI's recent change in
development and distribution model is a good example of the transition in
action (though it's pretty clearly a dead-end model that is only
attracting some of the former Red Hat and rpm-based distribution customers
looking to keep up to date and nobody else -- Gentoo and Debian have the
fastest growing share and I don't think it's coincidence that they are not
associated with proprietary development and for-trade distribution).

J.

    jeme at brelin.net

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun May  2 13:13:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun May  2 13:13:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Parental management of teenage boys on Internet
Message-ID: <20040502201153.GA27675@gate.kl-ic.com>

This is a question for you Linux Parents out there, and for you young
guys who can remember what it was like to get on the Internet at 14.

I just set up a 14yo godson with a dialin to my computer.  He is on a
Xandros/Debian box, and the dialin is behind my firewall;  I am not too
worried about him inadvertently unleashing a virus or breaking security.
He is probably not going to be a True Hacker (but he already has 
figured out how to pull screen backgrounds off windoze games disks,
not bad for 2 weeks on Linux).

My main concern is that I have given him a capability and a
responsibility that his single mother will have to manage.  They have
a single telephone line.  I instructed him in how to use modem access
responsibly, and he is a well-behaved and thoughtful young fellow.
However, he did just get the keys to the candy store and he could
fall into bad habits, or long phone usage could create a source of
friction with his mom (who is kind but not computer savvy, and
certainly can't afford $650/yr for cable modem). 

So, parents, what works for you?  Recent ex-teens, what worked for
you?  What can I tell him and his mom that will help them work through
this potential source of friction and make it positive?  Am I fretting
too much?

Keith

solution.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sun May  2 14:39:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Sun May  2 14:39:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Parental management of teenage boys on Internet
In-Reply-To: <1083530321.18977.117.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0405021321350.8374-100000@uplinknetworks.dyndns.org> <1083530321.18977.117.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

>

>catch-a-call.  At least that way, calls will get through.  The other way
>is to get the phone company to answer your messages.

On dial-up, I know there are some services that provide
values based access.  PAX comes to mind.  The scariest
thought about a single mother putting a 14 year old on the
net is how much affect some of the predatory stuff one
runs into will have on a teen.  I guess my advice would
 be caution if the mother is not aware of what the net is
these days and perhaps some faith based advice for both
of them.  There are problems with sheltering anyone,
but a teenager is especially vulnerable to the net's darker
corners.  The best defense I guess is to teach proactively
and filter while including the teen and mother in that
somehow.

At 14, I wonder if this person is mature enough to be
capable of making the right decisions when
 confronted with a darker corner of the net?  Will the
mother be allowing net use when she isn't able to
monitor it?  The other problem with teenagers is that
they think they're adults, but even in your twenties
sometimes you're still stupid.  

I think most people with DSL or Cable have as their
primary complaint that the net delivers arousal
and gratifcation well, but falls far short in most cases
 of giving what it is really desired, wanted, or even
needed.  It's annoying that the net is such a lawless
and filthy frontier in so mnay parts.  If he has email
access through you, I recommend filtering it so that
he doesn't see Cialis, etc., ads.  You're providing the
connection, don't be afraid to do so in a way that fits
with your values.  I guess the only advice is to make
the teenager part of your values based decisions
because a teen, while he/she won't say it, wants to
learn about adulthood from a trusted source.  Most
teens want protection still as they're just starting to
learn what it means to be an adult and  beginning
to assume more responsibility for themselves,
but they want to feel independent too.  It's a hard
time.

I'm surprised DSL is so expensive, in many places
now you can get it for just $20 a month.  That might
be misleading though if you have to get a static ip,
etc.

     --   Michael C. Robinson

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon May  3 08:54:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon May  3 08:54:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Who repairs monitors around town?
In-Reply-To: <20040503134210.14166.97673.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040503134210.14166.97673.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040503155302.GA2728@gate.kl-ic.com>

Wally Wharton wrote:
> I have a 17" flat screen CRT monitor, barely a year old, that has lost
> its vertical control.  I've sent it back to the manufacturer to be
> repaired once, but two months after the repair, the vertical is shot
> again.  

While it may indeed be the monitor, you should also try replacing the
video cable and VGA board that drives the monitor.  You would get the
same effect (no vertical synchronization, slowly rolling video) if either
of those were intermittent, or the connectors were making bad contact,
so that pin 14 (vertical sync) was not always connected.  

The most likely thing that would fail in the monitor yielding this
symptom is the HD-15 connector, or the circuit board trace connecting
it to the video sync chip, or the video sync chip in the monitor.  I
would guess bad strain relief on the monitor's connector - the cable
puts a lot of leverage on the connector, and the flexing and pressure
probably breaks connections on the circuit board.  This may be a usage
issue rather than a monitor replacement issue.  Make sure there is no
undue pressure on the monitor connector, or the system will break again.

If cable swapping and video board swapping doesn't fix the problem,
it might be an idea to send one or both along with the monitor next
time you send it in for repair, to quell a "somebody else's problem"
attitude on the part of the repair technician.

It sucks that with all the zillions of transistors that go into a
video board and monitor these days, they cannot put in a few thousand
extra to verify the integrity of the video path.  Sadly though, in a
few years we will likely get that "integrity check" in the form of
some "Digital Rights Management" Linux lockout on the video path.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon May  3 09:40:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon May  3 09:40:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Large Data Back-Ups to CD-R(W)
Message-ID: <20040503163829.GA3077@gate.kl-ic.com>

Robert McIntosh writes:

> I'm working with a large volume of data that's closing in on 20 GB that
> I'd like to back-up bi-annually to multiple CD-R(W)s.  I'm familiar with
> Hugo Rabson's powerful Mondo Rescue (http://www.microwerks.net/~hugo/)
> but in my particular environment (FreeBSD) it seems to be a real push to
> configure the prerequisite packages into FreeBSD.

<soapbox=1>

At the risk of missing an important reason to use CD-R disks, may I 
suggest you look at  http://www.keithl.com/linuxbackup.html ?  The
disk-to-disk RSYNC backup techniques are fully portable to BSD and
other forms of Unix. 

Bi-annual backups are risky - chances are, when the source disk fails,
you will have an average of 3 months of data entry lost.  Scary.

More importantly, writable CDs fail frequently and are expensive; I
see about 5% failure-to-verify on the "good" brands of media (I like
Fuji and Memorex), and 10-15% on "bad" brands (Imation, Dysan, Verbatim,
TDK, store-brand-du-jour).  So 20GB -> 30 media, thus you can expect to
see about 2 fails per backup pass (and your back software had better
handle this gracefully).  Given that CD-R media can also fail on the
shelf (it is not an archival process)  you will need to make at least
two interchangeable sets of disks if you want some chance of ever
reading back those data sets at a later time.   At 5 minutes per disk,
including verify and labelling and replacement of fails, that sounds
like a whole day of work.

I could ramble on - but I strongly suggest you do disk-to-disk backup
instead, and pick a scheme (my webpage mentions many) that matches
your data set.  Redundant backup of 20GB can be done on two 80GB
backup disks, with very little per-backup work once the system is
set up.  The biggest source of backup/restore failure is the failure
to do the backup;  a day per backup onto CDs sounds like a highly
put-off-able task.

<soapbox=0>

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Mon May  3 13:36:02 2004
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Mon May  3 13:36:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Large Data Back-Ups to CD-R(W)
In-Reply-To: <408F0E6C.8080906@comcast.net>
References: <408F0E6C.8080906@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <29484-64472@sneakemail.com>

On Tue, 27 Apr 2004, Robert McIntosh mcintoshrt-at-comcast.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> I'm working with a large volume of data that's closing in on 20 GB that
> I'd like to back-up bi-annually to multiple CD-R(W)s.  I'm familiar with
> Hugo Rabson's powerful Mondo Rescue (http://www.microwerks.net/~hugo/)
> but in my particular environment (FreeBSD) it seems to be a real push to
> configure the prerequisite packages into FreeBSD.

Backing up that amount of data onto such small media will be a headache.
Some of the issues:
  + media swapping
  + media errors during backup
  + media errors after backup
  + loss/damage to one portion of the backup
  + partial restore
  + frequency of backups
  + verify backup

Media swapping
--------------

It may not seem like a big deal, but it is very tedious to swap, label,
and store huge numbers of disks for one backup.  Ask anyone who survived
50-floppy backups in the Bad Old Days.  ;-)

Media errors during backup
--------------------------

Does your backup method allow you to retry a particular segment of the
backup in the event of write errors, or must you start all over from the
beginning?  Murphy's Law would have the backup fail partway through the
last disk and make you start over again.  :-(

Media errors after backup
-------------------------

What happens if disk 12 of 40 is bad?  Can this error be ignored?  Will
the rest of the backup be restore-able or does the software choke on the
whole thing?

Loss/damage to one portion of the backup
----------------------------------------

Similar to the above, but what if the whole disk is missing?

Partial restore
---------------

If you only need one file, must you read the whole set of disks to restore
it?  (tar is notorious for this.)

Frequency of backups
--------------------

Twice a year?  Would you even WANT to restore data that old?  I can see
only doing a full backup this often, but what about much smaller
incremental backups?

Verify backup
-------------

Ideally you'd be able to read the entire backup and compare each file with
the one on the current filesystem to make sure the disks were written
correctly and can still be read.

Before embarking on this, you should borrow a copy of the O'Reilly UNIX
Backup and Recovery book: http://safari.oreilly.com/1565926420.  The
chapter "Freely Available Filesystem Backup & Recovery Utilities" was very
helpful for me.

When I had to do something similar to you (not as bad, only 6 GB of data)
I settled on using "dump" since it filled the disks, allowed for easy
single-file recoveries, has a nice built-in method for continuing the
backups as incrementals, and didn't require me to read the whole damn
thing when restoring.

The main drawbacks were lack of portability (ext2 only), and the confusing
syntax of dump.

Make 2 copies and stuff one in a safe deposit somewhere.  You'll be glad
you did when the backing peels off the cheap CD-Rs on your first copy.
;-)

  -- Steve

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon May  3 21:18:02 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Mon May  3 21:18:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Large Data Back-Ups to CD-R(W)
In-Reply-To: <20040503163829.GA3077@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040503163829.GA3077@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <1083644227.8339.7.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Mon, 2004-05-03 at 09:38, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> Robert McIntosh writes:
> 
> > I'm working with a large volume of data that's closing in on 20 GB that
> > I'd like to back-up bi-annually to multiple CD-R(W)s.  I'm familiar with
> > Hugo Rabson's powerful Mondo Rescue (http://www.microwerks.net/~hugo/)
> > but in my particular environment (FreeBSD) it seems to be a real push to
> > configure the prerequisite packages into FreeBSD.
> 
> <soapbox=1>
> 
> At the risk of missing an important reason to use CD-R disks, may I 
> suggest you look at  http://www.keithl.com/linuxbackup.html ?  The
> disk-to-disk RSYNC backup techniques are fully portable to BSD and
> other forms of Unix. 
> 
> Bi-annual backups are risky - chances are, when the source disk fails,
> you will have an average of 3 months of data entry lost.  Scary.
> 
> More importantly, writable CDs fail frequently and are expensive; I
> see about 5% failure-to-verify on the "good" brands of media (I like
> Fuji and Memorex), and 10-15% on "bad" brands (Imation, Dysan, Verbatim,
> TDK, store-brand-du-jour).  So 20GB -> 30 media, thus you can expect to
> see about 2 fails per backup pass (and your back software had better
> handle this gracefully).  Given that CD-R media can also fail on the
> shelf (it is not an archival process)  you will need to make at least
> two interchangeable sets of disks if you want some chance of ever
> reading back those data sets at a later time.   At 5 minutes per disk,
> including verify and labelling and replacement of fails, that sounds
> like a whole day of work.

The other big issue in doing backups to cd-r are the problems of
preserving filenames and permissions.

If you have filenames that are longer than about 131 characters, they
will get truncated.  

If you have filenames that contain non-english character sets that have
not been translated to utf-8, they will not always go on the disc.

If you have file attributes beyond the basic permissions, then they will
probably forgotten.  (Such as extended attributes or posix security
permissions like what SELinux uses.)

I am not certain how much of the above gets preserved by tar or cpio. 
(Especially extended permission bits and odd acls.)

I once thought dvd backups were all I needed.  Now I have my doubts.

-- 
We are living in the "interesting times" the fortune cookies warned us
about.




From alan at clueserver.org  Mon May  3 21:53:01 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Mon May  3 21:53:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Parental management of teenage boys on Internet
In-Reply-To: <20040502201153.GA27675@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040502201153.GA27675@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <1083646337.8339.24.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Sun, 2004-05-02 at 13:11, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> This is a question for you Linux Parents out there, and for you young
> guys who can remember what it was like to get on the Internet at 14.

When I was 14, there was not much of an Internet to be on.

> I just set up a 14yo godson with a dialin to my computer.  He is on a
> Xandros/Debian box, and the dialin is behind my firewall;  I am not too
> worried about him inadvertently unleashing a virus or breaking security.
> He is probably not going to be a True Hacker (but he already has 
> figured out how to pull screen backgrounds off windoze games disks,
> not bad for 2 weeks on Linux).
> 
> My main concern is that I have given him a capability and a
> responsibility that his single mother will have to manage.  They have
> a single telephone line.  I instructed him in how to use modem access
> responsibly, and he is a well-behaved and thoughtful young fellow.
> However, he did just get the keys to the candy store and he could
> fall into bad habits, or long phone usage could create a source of
> friction with his mom (who is kind but not computer savvy, and
> certainly can't afford $650/yr for cable modem). 

If he has local access to the net, there is no reason for him to rack up
long distance.  The porn dialer trojans need Windows to operate.

> So, parents, what works for you?  Recent ex-teens, what worked for
> you?  What can I tell him and his mom that will help them work through
> this potential source of friction and make it positive?  Am I fretting
> too much?

If you are worried about him getting to porn, there is *nothing* you can
do.

Period.

Wanting to learn about sex is a part of growing up.  (No matter what the
"moralists" will say.)  Seeing sexual images is not harmful to kids that
age, unless they have been previously traumatized by their parents.

What you need to worry about is what friends they make on the net.  He
needs to know that not everyone on the net is what they claim.

Every 14 year old girl on the net is actually a 40 year old cop looking
for a promotion.

There are some pretty desperate and whacked people on the net. 
(Especially in chat rooms and IRC.)  He needs to know this.  He also
needs to know that there are some people who get off by pushing other
people's buttons.

Teach him how to not feed the trolls.

The censorbot software actually makes people comfortable in cases where
they should not.  It blocks things that are relatively harmless (Usually
sex, but also other things that make so-called adults uncomfortable) and
does not block the real threat -- people who want to use you, abuse you,
imprison and/or kill you.  There is no real way to block those out. 
(Even if you cut off all the .gov and .mil addresses.) 

Teaching him what the real threats are will go much farther than putting
in a porn blocker.

I don't have any censor programs on my home network.  My daughter has
full access to the net.  

Net censorship is just another way to say "I don't trust you".

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Mon May  3 22:05:03 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Mon May  3 22:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Untarring files with '..' in them
Message-ID: <1083647100.6304.5.camel@timmy>

This is not a cry for help, but a solution to a problem.

Earlier today, I tarred up some files, foolishly putting a '..' in front
of every filename. When I tried to untar them, it complained with this
message:

Member name contains `..'

The files were not extracted. 

After some drudging through the manpage, I discovered the solution:

       -P, --absolute-paths
              don't strip leading `/'s from file names

When I tacked this on to my command line, the files were extracted to
the parent directory. 

I'm posting this here because I was unable to find this anywhere else
and thought I might save someone else the grief.

Evan

Ouch.  The original spec for HTTP only used something like 256 
characters for a URL.  There are limits to what browsers and servers 
support.  It is usually much higher than 256 characters, but you're 
into the 1k range.

> I assume this is some Windoze worm out there, assuming I am running
> M$ IS and trying to buffer-overflow its way in.  The IP dotquad
> these requests are allegedly coming from doesn't respond to ping,

> concerned about?  Is there anyone I should be informing?

I think Alan might be right.  It could be a misconfigured spider or 
something.  Do all the hits tend to come from one or a small cluster 
of IPs?  Do they seem to be methodically going through your directory 
tree?  The redirection to Comcast might be confusing it, maybe???

Then again, maybe there is another vulnerability in IIS having to do 
with long URLs and you're just the current target of some script 
kiddy.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue May  4 12:13:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue May  4 12:13:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] exim4 as ssl/tls client
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0405041157460.16903@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

At some point in the (hopefully) near future, I'll be moving my main
mail server out of my house to co-lo facility. I want all my home
machines to relay mail through that box, and I want those connections
verified via SSL-certificate checking.

So I built my own little certificate authority and generated
certs for each host on my network.

I'm pretty familiar with sendmail's m4 configuration process, so
telling local hosts running sendmail how to offer up a client
certificate was pretty easy: just add confCLIENT_CERT and
confCLIENT_KEY definitions and rebuild sendmail.cf.

Harder -- well, more obscure -- was getting exim4 to offer up a client
cert. The exim4 config file has settings for tls_certificate and
tls_privatekey, but they're only good when exim is acting as a server;
they don't apply to exim as a client.

The answer wasn't documented at all in the comments in the exim4
config stuff, nor was it in the README.TLS file. Instead, buried in
the FAQ on www.exim.org is this little gem:

  A1705:  This means that the clients have not sent certificates when
  asked by the server to do so. If the clients are running Exim, check
  that tls_certificate is correctly set in their smtp transports. Note
  that this value is not automatically inherited from the global
  tls_certificate option.

What that means in practice is that your remote_smtp transport
definition needs a bit of tweaking, e.g.,

remote_smtp:
  debug_print = "T: remote_smtp for $local_part@$domain"
  driver = smtp
  tls_certificate = CONFDIR/exim.crt

Voila!

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue May  4 13:39:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue May  4 13:39:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Two Noobie questions
In-Reply-To: <4097FEE5.7090102@comcast.net>
References: <4097FEE5.7090102@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0405041333210.16903@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Tue, 4 May 2004, Mike Layne wrote:

> 1. My Fedora Core 1 install was working just fine on my IBM T21
>    until this morning when it hung while trying to load the pcmcia
>    module.  Question:  What do I do to get back to functionaL?

Do you mean that it hung during the boot process?

> 2. Where do I go to either assign an IP address or find out what IP
>    address the machine is using?

/sbin/ifconfig will list all interfaces currently configured.

Look at /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-* for the interface
configuration files. If you don't want to edit text files, the
more-or-less official configuration utility is
/usr/bin/redhat-config-network.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Tue May  4 13:51:01 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Tue May  4 13:51:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Two Noobie questions
In-Reply-To: <4097FEE5.7090102@comcast.net>
References: <4097FEE5.7090102@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405041347210.10729@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Tue, 4 May 2004, Mike Layne wrote:

> 1.  My Fedora Core 1 install was working just fine on my IBM T21 until
> this morning when it hung while trying to load the pcmcia module.
> Question:  What do I do to get back to functionaL?

  Drop it?

  Try booting into single-user mode (linux single at the boot prompt). Then
read dmesg to see what went on when it hung up.

> 2.  Where do I  go to either assign an IP address or find out what IP
> address the machine is using?

  /etc/hosts. The format is IP address <space> fully-qualified-host-name
<space> alias; e.g.,

127.0.0.1       localhost.localdomain   localhost
192.168.55.1    salmo.appl-ecosys.com   salmo mail
192.168.55.2    caddis.appl-ecosys.com  caddis

HTH,

Rich

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Mike> what IP address the machine is using?

Rich>   /etc/hosts. The format is IP address <space>
Rich> fully-qualified-host-name <space> alias; e.g.,

Bzzt.  /etc/hosts is just a mapping of ip number to hostname.  That is
not where you go to assign an IP address to an interface, which is
what I gather Mike was looking for.  Nor does /etc/hosts get filled in
magically.  Essentially, it is a place to manually place mappings.

From jason at vancleve.com  Tue May  4 22:38:02 2004
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Tue May  4 22:38:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] iptables On Default Installs?
Message-ID: <20040504223820.2d9cf929.jason@vancleve.com>

I was pondering "sasser" just now, briefly, as I emailed my old man,
telling him 'Doze users running ZoneAlarm shouldn't be affected; though
I'm not absolutely certain that's true.

Anyway, assuming this sort of attack is blocked by a good firewall (yes,
and not running unneeded services, etcetera), I'm wondering if distros
like Fedora and Mandrake are installing with a default iptables
configuration of any kind.  (For, if I say Linux users are better off
for security, it isn't because their ports are nicely sealed; to the
contrary, it can be argued they are better off only because they are not
running the poopular OS.)  If I recommend the Linux on the desktop for
this reason, people might expect it to solve the firewall problem, but
does it?

It could be a simple matter of adding a startup script or something,
which is still better than installing ZoneAlarm on Winders.  But with
Gentoo I had to write my own iptables script, which is not an end user
type thing.

--Jason V. C.

--
I'd give my right arm to be ambidextrous!



From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue May  4 22:44:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)

Subject: [PLUG] iptables On Default Installs?
In-Reply-To: <20040504223820.2d9cf929.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20040504223820.2d9cf929.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1083736135.11170.375.camel@localhost>

On Tue, 2004-05-04 at 22:38, Jason Van Cleve wrote:

> Anyway, assuming this sort of attack is blocked by a good firewall (yes,
> and not running unneeded services, etcetera), I'm wondering if distros
> like Fedora and Mandrake are installing with a default iptables
> configuration of any kind.  (For, if I say Linux users are better off
> for security, it isn't because their ports are nicely sealed; to the
> contrary, it can be argued they are better off only because they are not
> running the poopular OS.)  If I recommend the Linux on the desktop for
> this reason, people might expect it to solve the firewall problem, but
> does it?

No, many (most?) distributions leave it up to the end user to configure
a firewall if they want one.

More than once I've been burned by RH's default firewall closing
everything off on somebody else's box.  It bugs me.  :-)

Slackware doesn't ship with a firewall, Gentoo doesn't ship with a
firewall.  There are a plethora of preconfigured firewall scripts out
there, though, if you want 'em.  Heck, I even hacked on one a friend
wrote to make it my own.  I almost rewrote it in c++ as a learning
exercise but decided that was a bit too insane - even for me.

Rob

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed May  5 12:46:02 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Wed May  5 12:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] iptables On Default Installs?
In-Reply-To: <20040504223820.2d9cf929.jason@vancleve.com>
References: <20040504223820.2d9cf929.jason@vancleve.com>
Message-ID: <1083786298.15470.57.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Tue, 2004-05-04 at 22:38, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> I was pondering "sasser" just now, briefly, as I emailed my old man,
> telling him 'Doze users running ZoneAlarm shouldn't be affected; though
> I'm not absolutely certain that's true.
> 
> Anyway, assuming this sort of attack is blocked by a good firewall (yes,
> and not running unneeded services, etcetera), I'm wondering if distros
> like Fedora and Mandrake are installing with a default iptables
> configuration of any kind.  (For, if I say Linux users are better off
> for security, it isn't because their ports are nicely sealed; to the
> contrary, it can be argued they are better off only because they are not
> running the poopular OS.)  If I recommend the Linux on the desktop for
> this reason, people might expect it to solve the firewall problem, but
> does it?

Redhat and Mandrake both ship with a firewall.  What gets blocked
depends on what security level you set the machine at and what services
you tell it to open up.  They tend to be better in the most recent
versions.  Most of the configuration utilities give you a list of
"standard" services and allow you to check them.  If you need something
non-standard (like nfs) you have to look up the port numbers and enter
them. (Usually in the form of port:type.  Example 443:tcp)

The hard part with Mandrake (and sometimes Redhat) is figuring out where
they put the iptables data if you need to modify it by hand.  

> It could be a simple matter of adding a startup script or something,
> which is still better than installing ZoneAlarm on Winders.  But with
> Gentoo I had to write my own iptables script, which is not an end user
> type thing.

Yeah.  Not fun having done it too many times.  There are a number of
firewall configuration scripts and programs at
http://www.freshmeat.net/.  They are a good start.  Also "Linux
Firewalls 2nd edition" is very useful for good information on writing
rulesets.  Just make sure you get the errata.


-- 
We are living in the "interesting times" the fortune cookies warned us
about.

Mike,

What the others are not saying is that your primary partition / could
not be found by the kernel.  Since it could not find the file system the
kernel paniced.  Paul suggested you do another install.  You might try
booting in rescue mode:  linux rescue.  Check your lilo/grub
configuration for where it should find the root filesystem.

Ken
CAD2CAM.COM

                                 PRESENTATION

                                    VMware

                                      by
                             
                               Brian P. Martin
                         <Brian at MartinConsulting.com>

      VMware is a popular tool for running "virtual" Linux and/or 
      Windows operating systems under a Linux or Windows host

From clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com  Wed May  5 20:53:02 2004
From: clydefrog at adnap.no-ip.com (Evan Heidtmann)
Date: Wed May  5 20:53:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] KDE / XDMCP Question
In-Reply-To: <APEBIDJLFPLCNAAOMMIAGEODFGAA.wamorita@hevanet.com>
References: <APEBIDJLFPLCNAAOMMIAGEODFGAA.wamorita@hevanet.com>
Message-ID: <1083815576.6259.3.camel@timmy>

On Wed, 2004-05-05 at 17:07, wamorita wrote:
> I am trying to get an xserver (X-win32) to connect to a Redhat 9 box.
> In /usr/share/config/kdm/kdmrc I set:
> 	[Xdmcp]
> 	Enable=true
> 
> The xserver is set to query.  I get no login prompt from Linux box.
> What else needs to be set or checked? 
> 

There may be other things, but KDM needs to be running and restarted
after the change to the config file.

You can test locally (removing the possibility of a problem on the
client end) like this:

X :1 -query localhost

If that works and the remote machine doesn't, then maybe KDM is only
listening on 127.0.0.1.

Evan

From aaron at ultravolt.net  Wed May  5 21:44:01 2004

or imap compatible server.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed May  5 22:08:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)

Subject: [PLUG] Webmail server suggestions

> My gf and I just bought our first domain name, and we want to run our own email server.  Hopefully one with a webmail interface.
> 
> can anyone suggest some good programs for me to run?

SMTP:  Postfix
IMAP:  bincimap
WebMail:  SquirrelMail

Then toss SpamAssassin in there for spam filtering.  If you have any
Windows boxes at all that might be reading email from the server or
sending email through the server, I'd highly recommend installing
AMaViSd-new and configuring it to utilize SA and ClamAV.

Rob

References: <AFB0E34FE3EFCF42B5FA5C9C9E908B2212ECEC@MAIL-14PS.atlarge.net>
	<1083820551.6257.10.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <87vfjaj7fl.fsf@ursine.ca>

AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net> writes:
> I'd highly recommend installing
> AMaViSd-new and configuring it to utilize SA and ClamAV.

Your virus checker should *NOT* be advertising itself to the outside
world.  Most, if not all, viruses sent via email today forge the From
header.  Virus companies obviously know this, but don't bother to fix
their software to try to find the correct sender.  Be aware that this
could cause *you* to send free advertising out to unrelated third
parties on behalf of your antivirus vendor.

The best method of handling this is to reject virus infected messages
at STMP time, thus avoiding needlessly bothering anyone.  Nobody wants
your virus vendor's spam, and it only wastes more of your resources to
send it.
http://ursine.ca/article.pl?sid=04/04/11/1127234

-- 
Paul Johnson
<baloo at ursine.ca>
Linux.  You can find a worse OS, but it costs more.

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu May  6 06:17:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu May  6 06:17:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Webmail server suggestions
In-Reply-To: <87vfjaj7fl.fsf@ursine.ca>
References: <AFB0E34FE3EFCF42B5FA5C9C9E908B2212ECEC@MAIL-14PS.atlarge.net>
 <1083820551.6257.10.camel@localhost> <87vfjaj7fl.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405060609240.14998@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 6 May 2004, Paul Johnson wrote:
> AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net> writes:
> > I'd highly recommend installing AMaViSd-new and configuring it to
> > utilize SA and ClamAV.
>
> Your virus checker should *NOT* be advertising itself to the outside
> world.  Most, if not all, viruses sent via email today forge the From
> header.  Virus companies obviously know this, but don't bother to fix
> their software to try to find the correct sender.  Be aware that this
> could cause *you* to send free advertising out to unrelated third
> parties on behalf of your antivirus vendor.
>
> The best method of handling this is to reject virus infected messages
> at STMP time, thus avoiding needlessly bothering anyone.  Nobody wants
> your virus vendor's spam, and it only wastes more of your resources to
> send it.

You don't have to reject at SMTP time in order to silently ignore the
spam.

In one installation, I use the packages AthlonRob suggests along with
postfix to filter spam and virii while sending no messages out about the
spam and accepting no "virus warnings" from outside.

On the subject of the thread, I use the Courier system (IMAP and POP3
components) and SquirrelMail on that same installation for remote mail
services and webmail respectively.  SMTP-Auth is configured to read from
the same database as the Courier authentication.

It's a pretty easy setup and there are numerous good How-Tos.

J.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Thu May  6 07:04:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Thu May  6 07:04:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Webmail server suggestions
In-Reply-To: <1083820551.6257.10.camel@localhost>
References: <AFB0E34FE3EFCF42B5FA5C9C9E908B2212ECEC@MAIL-14PS.atlarge.net>
 <1083820551.6257.10.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0405060652250.26340@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Wed, 5 May 2004, AthlonRob wrote:

> > can anyone suggest some good programs for me to run?
>
> SMTP:  Postfix
> IMAP:  bincimap
> WebMail:  SquirrelMail

Alternatively:

SMTP:    Sendmail     http://www.sendmail.org/
IMAP:    Dovecot      http://dovecot.org/
WebMail: SquirrelMail http://www.squirrelmail.org/

Configure all three to use SSL/TLS for security, and set up
spamassassin via milter-spamc:

  http://www.snert.com/Software/milter-spamc/index.shtml

If you're hosting mailboxes for Windows users and want some anti-virus
scanning, then build ClamAV with milter enabled:

  http://sial.org/howto/clamav/clamav-milter/

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu May  6 12:30:03 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu May  6 12:30:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Webmail server suggestions
In-Reply-To: <87oep1mlmi.fsf@ursine.ca>
References: <AFB0E34FE3EFCF42B5FA5C9C9E908B2212ECEC@MAIL-14PS.atlarge.net>
 <1083820551.6257.10.camel@localhost> <87vfjaj7fl.fsf@ursine.ca>
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405060609240.14998@shaft.bitmine.net> <87oep1mlmi.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405061222590.14998@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Thu, 6 May 2004, Paul Johnson wrote:
> Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:
> > You don't have to reject at SMTP time in order to silently ignore the
> > spam.
>
> Why bother accepting it if everybody using that server is guaranteed to
> not want it?  Seems like it's more practical to just tell your server to
> give spammers the finger and tell them to piss off than accept their
> spew.

You're not giving the spammer the finger.  The spam is probably
originating from a bot on some Windows box somewhere or other automated
script that doesn't care what you have to say about the message.  A bad
SMTP return code doesn't change a thing for the bot.  They're not going to
take the address off the list just because it failed this time around.

So it doesn't matter WHEN you ignore it, so long as it doesn't interfere
with your regular course of business.

In addition to that (or in consequence of it), SMTP has timeouts and
processing each message for content BEFORE you send a return code will
take much longer than just sending an accept for all well-formed messages
to valid addresses and moving on.  If anything causes high load on the
machine, its conceivable that the SMTP will timeout before the content is
examined and you could end up rejecting valid mail (albeit temporarily).

I don't see any advantage to SMTP=time spam filtering.  After SMTP and
before delivery is handy enough.

I currently use the procmail approach but now that all of the users on the
system are using spamassassin, I'll probably go ahead and configure the
milter.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

Either way, you will only get 10mbit without rewiring.

On Wed, 2004-05-05 at 17:07, wamorita wrote:
> I am trying to get an xserver (X-win32) to connect to a Redhat 9 box.
> In /usr/share/config/kdm/kdmrc I set:
> 	[Xdmcp]
> 	Enable=true
> 
> The xserver is set to query.  I get no login prompt from Linux box.
> What else needs to be set or checked? 
> 

There may be other things, but KDM needs to be running and restarted
after the change to the config file.

You can test locally (removing the possibility of a problem on the
client end) like this:

X :1 -query localhost

If that works and the remote machine doesn't, then maybe KDM is only
listening on 127.0.0.1.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu May  6 13:54:01 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Thu May  6 13:54:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Webmail server suggestions
In-Reply-To: <200405060818.18015.linux@chrisroberts.org>
References: <AFB0E34FE3EFCF42B5FA5C9C9E908B2212ECEC@MAIL-14PS.atlarge.net> <200405060818.18015.linux@chrisroberts.org>
Message-ID: <409AA3A3.1080605@robinson-west.com>

chris wrote:

>since it hasn't been mentioned, courier has an all in one package that 
>includes pop3, imap, smtp and a webmail interface.
>
>http://www.courier-mta.org
>
>chris
>
>On Wednesday 05 May 2004 08:40 pm, Geoff Freeman wrote:
>  
>
>>My gf and I just bought our first domain name, and we want to run our own
>>email server.  Hopefully one with a webmail interface.
>>
>>can anyone suggest some good programs for me to run?
>>
>>    
>>
I've tried to do HORDE IMP a couple of times but had major difficulties 
with it.  A number
of people prefer squirrelmail.  My advice is to set up webmail last. 
 You want to do
postfix/qmail, spamassassin, DNS, and possibly mailscanner with ClamAV 
first.  
I've tried qmail, Postfix seems easier, Sendmail is a headache and 
insecure, don't know
about Exim.

Note the only thing I don't like about using dns ignorant under Postfix 
and Mailscanner
is that information about what I get is being sent to some unknown 
outside source.
For virus filtering, going out to an external source and getting fresh 
virus info is a good
idea.  If this happens with the email itself, be aware that someone 
outside your system
is probably getting to read it too.

Probably a good idea to chroot apache and custom compile for webmail so 
if you have trouble,
you don't lose all your work setting up the mail server itself.  

I'm getting ready to start a project that takes a completely different 
approach to spam.  Yes you
can filter it, but if you filter solely, you still get a lot of junk and 
could miss a virus, etc.

     It recognizes a few key ideas:

          1) Spam creates excess heat and ruins hard disks that host 
mail spools.

          2)  The more complex your filtering is, the easer it is to 
filter the wrong
               thing.

          3)  Most people can build a list of who they contact and are 
contacted
                by through an email address, this can be used to reduce the
                namespace that needs to be filtered for some accounts.
           
         4)   Untrusted mail needs to be handled off site or thrown away.

I'm planning on mailservers on my gateways that spool in ram and dump to
Sandisks in emergencies to address issue 1.  These mail servers are going to
be developed to selectively relay to my existing MTA.  

Issue 2 will be eased by allowing email from unknown senders to be held 
until
the source is trusted or a period of 24 hours passes .  I'm thinking, have
a website internally for the intended recipient to indicate that a 
sender is okay,
if they want.  If a person had been asked about a sender and doesn't 
trust that
sender, the message can be simply be sent to a dirty site right away.

Concerning point 3, the advantage of this is that space on the relay 
isn't being
lost to  junk mail intended for a protected account.  This approach is 
really
good if a user knows his/her audience and/or can get people to switch the
email address that they send to. So as long as the sender understands that
they have to use the trusted source address having an adequate procedure
to follow if their email address has to change, this shouldn't be a 
problem.    
  
Point 3 is an idea that I want to implement on an email address by email
address basis.  Not implementing 3 will mean following the policy for
point 2 concerning messages from untrusted sources. Implementing three
without 2 means not using email to get new email sources, but it also
means if you don't accept outside postmaster and admin mail that you don't
need a dirty mail mail site.

If I implement point 4 fully, I probably need two new servers.  One machine
would be a Linux iptables or BSD based machine implementing a one way
door for the smtp and smtps protocols.  The other machine gets to be a 
second
mailsite with locally installed MUAs on it as well,  This "dirty" site 
can't touch
the trusted network.     

I recommend that all postmaster and admin email from outside your network
be routed to a dirty mail mail site.

If the dirty mail site gets infected, something important might get 
lost.  Can
anyone comment on using user mode linux, or any other possible tricks, to
address this issue?

For Point 3 to work, you need a special list for unresolvable trusted 
hosts.  I
also recommend throwing away or sending to a dirty site any forged email
where the source domain is not either on an unresolvable but trusted 
list, or
dns server somewhere.  The best test would be a bounce check.  If you can't
bounce a message, why accept the sender or even place the message on a
dirty site?  I am against smtp authentication, apparently noone needs to 
know
the secret to thwart it since they can just copy the secret and voila, 
they've
gotten around your security filter.  It may be that a secret sent out by 
phone
or other means is the way for a sender to mark their message as being from
them.  Encryption seems to be more useful for protecting against snooping
though than unwanted senders.  Anyone can hack on encrypted email for
as long as they want.  Statistically, someone has to be interested 
considering
the sheer volume of email.  

The biggest problem today is invasion of privacy because spam houses and
spam gangs think noone is in control of threir own email boxes and because
some people answer unsolicited and invasive email.  The big thing is how
you determine accurately that an email came from someone, or something,
that /or whom you want to correspond with.  Accomplish the latter, the
race to filter content on your end will be eased considerably.  The 
other big
thing is to not miss anything that could be a virus or malicious code, I 
guess
this means figuring out if an email is just a plain text message that 
isn't a
program and for convenience sake figuring out which mime messages are
safe too.

I've tried iptables based blocking of ips.  I recommend against this 
becuase
of virtual hosting of multiple sites on the same ip and you probably want
to at least allow dns from anywhere.  Besides, if a friend gets a virus
he/she may get blocked.

You might want to spamassassin on a relay and relay marked mail to a
dirty site.  The only thing is, I don't know how to detect trustworthy html
email and/or email that is anything but clear text.

Email is a service that  you may want to go through your ISP for from the
standpoint that he gets infected and you don't.  Unfortunately, I don't know
if there are any ISP's out there that gurantee you won't get viruses from
them, etc al.  I wonder if anyone can gurantee this?

Hope this helps ;-)

     Michael C. Robinson




From miken at hotsushi.com  Thu May  6 14:10:02 2004
From: miken at hotsushi.com (Mike Neal)
Date: Thu May  6 14:10:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Network security toolkit
Message-ID: <5.1.0.14.0.20040506135620.024bcb30@www.hotsushi.com>

Hi,

If you're interested in security, this is very cool.  These guys built a 
toolkit with most of Fydor's Top 75 Security Tools, a flexible security 
probe and a security administration package that has minimal hardware 
requirements. It's a gzipped iso that lets you burn a Red Hat 9 bootable 
security toolkit.  All the popular stuff, nessus, snort, nmap, ethereal and 
lots more,  designed for operation from the console or headless from a 
serial port or remotely through ssh or https. The project includes 
everything you need to modify the system and build your own iso with 
changes to the kernel, the packages and tools as well as customizing 
various configuration settings.  There is plenty of high quality 
documentation and it's all open source. See:
www.networksecuritytoolkit.org

Cheers,
Mike

> accept their spew.

It's an interesting question. My bias is to reject it outright with an
SMTP 550 error message. That's the most standards-compliant way to do
it, and, if the sender is sending spam by mistake (fat chance, I
know), it lets him know his message didn't get delivered.

On the other hand, spambots armies now have some central coordination.
See, for example, the "Spammer zombie group behaviour" thread on the
mimedefang mailing list:

http://lists.roaringpenguin.com/pipermail/mimedefang/2004-April/022003.html

In short, if you reject a message from one spambot, others will try
to deliver the message again soon thereafter. I can see it happening
in my mail logs at home. It's sick and facinating all at the same
time.

The admin is faced with a tough question: Is it better to do things
the right way and be forced to reject the same spam many times, or to
silently discard it and make the spammer think he was successful in
delivering it, reducing the strain on the mail infrastructure.

It's a no-win choice. I choose to do it the standards-based way, but I
don't have a mail server that's already swamped dealing with thousands
of inbound tcp connections, scanning every message for spam and
viruses.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>



From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu May  6 14:58:02 2004
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)

Subject: [PLUG] RJ45 to Coax adapter? 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 06 May 2004 13:07:33 PDT."
             <000b01c433a5$c5190c30$6401a8c0@LAPTOP> 
Message-ID: <20040506215704.3E4A68EE4@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Sasha Romanosky <sasha_romanosky at yahoo.com> wrote:

> 
> I have recently moved into a new apartment and need to have ethernet run
> to a separate room that shares a wall with the room that has it. 
> 
> The previous tenant drilled a hole and fed a coax cable through the
> wall. If I could find an RJ45-to-Coax (type "F"?) adapter I could just
> use this.
> 
> I could go wireless or drill another hole, but I'd rather not. I checked
> with fry's and found all kinds of adapters and converters but not this.
> Does anyone know if such an adapter exists?
> 

As Alan mentioned, the only feasible way to make use of the coax is to
use it as a 10Base2 segment.  It should be noted that the coax is almost
certainly the wrong impedance.  Cable TV coax is 75 ohms, whereas 10Base2
uses 50 ohm coax.  If the run is short and you use 75 ohm terminators, it
would probably work anyway.  That said, I think you would be much better
off using the coax to pull through a piece of cat5.

galen

I'm confused.  Why, exactly, does it matter if I have an

virus.  I don't see how this 'free advertising' (in the form of that
single little header *I* put in there) has any negative effect on
anybody.

Hell, it's ClamAV, it's free already.  :-)

time, which can drag out the SMTP connection for much longer than is
expected, causing servers to assume your system has died and error with
a 4xx.

Perhaps a two-tiered approach would be ideal.

>Agreed.

>
>I ran a lot of cat 5 wire.  Used up a 1000 feet of it to wire up
>
a total of seven rooms, six plus the server room.  It's best if you run 
multiple
cables together all at once though one of the problems I ran into 
running Cat-5
off a spool is that I would have needed to premeasure and pre cut.

Don't run standard Cat-5 through ducting unless you like hydrochloric 
acid, etc.
Also, it's a good idea to use sheilded cable if you can afford it.  Stay 
away from
transformers and power lines as much as possible.  Beware of inductance 
on coax
lines, consider using toroids if you know enough about them and they're 
needed.
  
I think Ethernet wires run at somewhere close to 300-400 volts, get 
shocked once
and you'll probably never touch a live ethernet wire again.  Stranded 
cable is best,
but not really necessary.  Stranded cable is more break resistant and 
actually has
more conductive surface area than solid core wire.  Good patch cables 
are made
of stranded cable.  Cat 5 has to do with the number of twists per foot. 
 If you
open Cat 5 UTP cable, you'll find that there are four pairs of wires twisted
together, hence the Cat 5.  I relplaced bell wire with Cat-5, the 
telephone people
were impressed because the single quality is better.  UTP stands for 
unshielded
twisted pair.  STP is the shielded variety.  Plenum Cat-5 goes through 
ducts.

UTP cable 1000 ft four pair was around $80, but that was a couple of 
years ago.

     Michael C. Robinson

You're nuts!

Ethernet wires are NOT considered HOT!  They're what you call 'safety
extra-low voltage' circuits.  You will not get a jolt from network
cables!  PLEASE check the Lost & Found for your Clue, you seem to be
missing it.

> Stranded 
> cable is best,
> but not really necessary.  Stranded cable is more break resistant and 
> actually has
> more conductive surface area than solid core wire.

Yeah, stranded is best if you're looking at cable that might be moving,
but if you're running it through a wall it's going to be darned static.

These cables are made out of copper, not aluminum.  Copper conducts
electricity throughout the entire strand.  Aluminum is the one you have
to worry about surface area with.

>   Good patch cables 
> are made
> of stranded cable.  Cat 5 has to do with the number of twists per foot. 
>  If you
> open Cat 5 UTP cable, you'll find that there are four pairs of wires twisted
> together, hence the Cat 5.

The category is determined by the number of twists per foot, *NOT* the
number if pairs of wires involved.  There is such a thing as 50 and
100-pair CAT5 cable out there.  The category has nothing to do with the
number of pairs.

>   I relplaced bell wire with Cat-5, the 
> telephone people
> were impressed because the single quality is better.  UTP stands for 
> unshielded
> twisted pair.  STP is the shielded variety.  Plenum Cat-5 goes through

From galens at seitzassoc.com  Thu May  6 17:13:07 2004
From: galens at seitzassoc.com (Galen Seitz)
Date: Thu May  6 17:13:07 2004
Subject: [PLUG] high level low level interface :) 
In-Reply-To: Your message of "Thu, 06 May 2004 16:10:26 PDT."
             <20040506231025.GA8095@subtend.net> 
Message-ID: <20040507001237.C82898EE4@tinman.seitzassoc.com>

Kris <krisa at subtend.net> wrote:

> I need to do some hardware hacking, but only have people with high-level
> progrmaming skills.
> 
> I have a 20V pulse signal which I want to get into a program.  I'm
> thinking RS232 would be the easiest way to get this signal.  I've
> searched google and came up with one suggestion which is to use the
> DSR as the signal to read for the pulse.  I would need to cut the
> voltage down to 5V to do this.

What is generating the signal?  Do you know the output impedance?
Strictly speaking, an RS232 input should accept voltages from -25V to
+25V.  If you are unsure about the voltage, I would connect the signal
to a separate serial port board.  I definitely wouldn't connect the 
signal to a laptop, for Murphy's sake.  The input impedance of an RS232
input is ~4.7K ohms, so you could connect to the RS232 port through
a 4.7K resistor.  That would cut the input voltage in half, putting
it well within the comfort zone for RS232.  That's assuming the output
impedance of whatever is generating the pulse is low.

Also, you said pulse.  How wide is the pulse?  If it is long (> 100 ms),
you shouldn't have a problem polling DSR.

> 
> If I were to explore this method, how can I read the DSR signal from a
> higher language such as perl/python/java?  Are there serial functions
> in these languages to read DSR?
> 
> Or if anyone else has a better solution.

I would suggest looking at pyserial.  I think it can do what you want.

galen

On Thu, 6 May 2004, AthlonRob AthlonRob-at-axpr.net |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Why would CAT5 sent through ducting cause any HCl to be anywhere,
> exactly?  We're not planning on it catching on fire.  If we were, we'd
> just get Plenum cable, anyway....

Many non-plenum cables use PVC (polyvinylchloride) as their sheathing.  I
doubt anything short of ignition (260C) would generate any appreciable
HCl, and even in those circumstances HCl would be the least of my worries.

Although hydrochloric acid sounds impressive, its effects are very
short-lived and you're going to notice it burning your lungs.  Mild
exposure to HCl causes no long-term problems.  (I.e. if you leave the area
and survive, you're in good shape.  ;-)  Compare this to the insidious
danger posed by colorless, odorless, CO (carbon monoxide).

I'd be more worried about the dioxin and mystery compounds present in the
PVC smoke whose effects are more long-term...

Still, to be properly fire-code-compliant, plenum-rated cable should be
used in ductwork.

http://www.aboutbluevinyl.org/performance.asp
http://www.newton.dep.anl.gov/askasci/chem00/chem00513.htm

  -- Steve

PS: Thanks for correcting the bad information in the other post.  I
probably would have been a bit less... forceful, but to each their own.
;-)

received has) and I filter based on that, I've filtered a lot of the
'wrong thing.'

I think more advanced filtering approaches like SpamAssassin which apply
weights to various traits are an ideal solution.
"


Spamassassin on my system can't detect valid html where I don't know if 
there are any
upgrades to fix that.  I don't use simple filters, though at least you 
tried on this criticism.



"
 3) Most people can build a list of who they contact and are contacted 
by through an
     email address, this can be used to reduce the namespace that needs 
to be filtered
    for some accounts.

   I don't think I know anybody who could come up with a whitelist of every
   email address they communicate with. My 89-year-old grandfather
   couldn't, and he's on AOL's 5-hour-a-month billing plan."
"



I could.  Especially if attempts by people I don't let in are known to 
be my the
header of the message.  If the mesesage is on hold, it can definitely 
get through.  
If I don't want to check what mail isn't being let in, why should I?



"

4)   Untrusted mail needs to be handled off site or thrown away.

Handled off-site?  By whom?  And handled how?  Why not do the filtering
on-site?  It's usually cheaper to run these things locally than to run
them on some different physical location.  That just doesn't make much
sense to me.

"



Off site meaning set up another network locally on seperate machines and 
deal with
it on those.  If you can develop a procedure to inject email that can be 
shown to be
safe and that the intended recipient has demonstrated interest in into 
the production
environment from the dirty environment, than by all means do that.



"
I'm planning on mailservers on my gateways that spool in ram and dump to
Sandisks in emergencies to address issue 1. These mail servers are going to
be developed to selectively relay to my existing MTA.

Hope you don't have any power outages....

"



Not a problem.  I have a UPS and I dump to Sandisk in the event of a power
outage.  Sandisks are nonvolatile solid state memory devices that are low
temperature and low power.  I'm also looking at two relays paired together
and spool mirroring.




"
Issue 2 will be eased by allowing email from unknown senders to be held
until the source is trusted or a period of 24 hours passes . I'm 
thinking, have
a website internally for the intended recipient to indicate that a 
sender is okay,

if they want. If a person had been asked about a sender and doesn't
trust that sender, the message can simply be sent to a dirty site right
away.

A dirty site? lol

That scheme sounds just messed up... if they're going to have to look at
the address anyway (and how many times have you seen two spams from the
same address?) why not just let it through to their inbox?
"



If the user gets tired of accepting new senders, new senders will be 
rerouted to a
dirty mail mail site.  If the sender address are not valid and this can 
be caught at
the smtp stage.  Unless there's an expectation for a specific invalid 
address
why let the message in at all in the first place?  If spammers always 
use different
addresses and always use invalid ones, that should be easy to stop. 
 Valid senders
who won't use the same email address, within reason, are going to be a 
major
communication challenge regardless of the email system chosen.  You
don't have to look at mail on the dirty site if you're not concerned and
administration can be eased by putting a one week timeout on any
message sent there.



"

>>Concerning point 3, the advantage of this is that space on the relay 
>>isn't being
>>lost to  junk mail intended for a protected account.  This approach is 
>>really
>>good if a user knows his/her audience and/or can get people to switch the
>>email address that they send to. So as long as the sender understands that
>>they have to use the trusted source address having an adequate procedure
>>to follow if their email address has to change, this shouldn't be a 
>>problem.    
>>
>>Sounds almost like as much of a PITA for the sender as CR spam systems.
>>
>>Yeah.  Nice.
>>
"



That's why it's optional.  I'm proprosing a way to give local recipients 
the power to
have accounts where senders have to rely on them to be able to get in at 
all.  For
business accounts, this makes a lot of sense.  Unlike common CR systems,
registration messages will NOT be sent out.  This email list is a 
registration
system, you can't sign someone else up for it against their will.  All 
of my
users should have one address where they can find out about potential
new senders, but they shouldn't be forced to choose new mail sources from
those that have been routed to a dirty site.  By dealing with questionable
mail outside of the production environment, risk to the production
environment is controlled.  I envision hosting some accounts that are CR 
like
and some that aren't.



"

>>Point 3 is an idea that I want to implement on an email address by email
>>address basis.  Not implementing 3 will mean following the policy for
>>point 2 concerning messages from untrusted sources. Implementing three
>>without 2 means not using email to get new email sources, but it also
>>means if you don't accept outside postmaster and admin mail that you don't
>>need a dirty mail mail site.
>>
>>A dirty mail mail site?  WTF?  :-)
>>
"



Any filtering scheme of any kind can generate false positives.  Quite
frankly, a second mail site for stuff you don't trust offers a means to
make sure nothing important is missed.  Anybody should be able to
send to the postmaster.  Do you want to filter email from anybody on
a server you're worried about?  Do you want to jam up smtp to do a
virus scan between your smtp server and one you don't control?  One
valid point that Jeme has made is that breaking smtp isn't a good idea.  
With a dirty mail mail site, you don't have to.  If this angers someone
because they are intent of flipping someone off, I suggest that person
seek counseling.



"

>>If I implement point 4 fully, I probably need two new servers.  One machine
>>would be a Linux iptables or BSD based machine implementing a one way
>>door for the smtp and smtps protocols.  The other machine gets to be a 
>>second
>>mailsite with locally installed MUAs on it as well,  This "dirty" site 
>>can't touch
>>the trusted network.     
>>
>>WHY?  Spam coming through a mail server doesn't make the mail server
>>infected with some virus it spreads to every computer it can contact.
>>
>>We're talking about spam here, not smallpox....
>>
"



Most viruses and worms are spam.  If you can mark anything that
could be a virus or trojan, why let it on a server that has clients your 
trying
to protect connected?  If you can't be certain of everything that is 
malware,
all the more reason to deal with the unknown in an appropriate way.



"

>Things coming through a mail server don't infect the system...
>duhhhhh....
>
"



 It helps to use Postfix or Qmail since these are designed to resist 
exploit,
but complacency about crackers is never a wise policy.

Saying that smtp software can't be hacked only encourages someone
out there to do just that.  Discrete Mathematics has a proof that
no simple algorithm can show that any program being tested will not
crash.  I see a simlpe extension of this logic to setting
up mail filtering.
  
It's important that viruses be caught and stopped in transmission, not 
on the
hosts they're trying to get onto.  This tears down anti viral requirements.

If you don't stop garbage at the server, you'll have to check for it on
every machine receiving mail service.  You'll have to upgrade all
over the place.  The person who doesn't go after this before it gets
on a workstation, laptop, or personal computer is nuts!

An smtp agent can be infected.  Sendmail comes to mind.  Buffer
overflow is a common source of exploit.  There have been many
exploits of smtp software.

The advantage of a dirty mail mail site is that you don't run the risk of
breaking things by trying to virus scan at smtp time between yourself
and a site that doesn't understand what you're doing.  If you're willing
to break things, don't use smtp then and have the people you want to
communicate with support whatever other transport protocol you're
interested in.



What is needed is a safe way to look at email that doesn't filter or that a
filter thinks is dangerous, so that an administrator can get just the
information that's needed to know if it's safe or not.

Spam is an annoyance, why not have spamassassin messages go to a
second site as long as the intended recipient is allowed to check there?
Give your users a clean mailbox, really.
