 So what if
mistaking millivolts for volts is funny, I suppose it is kinda funny.

I've gotten a shock before myself, it can really hurt to touch a live 
phone wire when
it goes high.  I don't recommend to anyone that they purposely touch any 
live wires
at any voltage.  Ah the wonders of service disconnects.  They make 
wiring so much
safer, and they're so inexpensive.

It's always a good idea to be careful around electricity.  Yeah you can 
touch an electric
fence and it may be more or less than a phone line, but it's not a good 
idea in general.
Just ask a horse or a cow.  I think they smell something coming off a 
hot wire.  A
smart horse knows when the fence is hot and when it isn't.

I don't think it's the voltage that's the real problem, I think it's the 
current.  The human
body has something similar to electrical wiring involving the brain and 
nervous system
that is suceptible to electrical overload.  There may be little cause 
for concern with 300
millivolt low amperage signal wires, but there's no reason to be 
careless.  Maybe it makes
you feel stupid to get shocked on a low voltage signal wire, but people 
really should from
good habits around electricity.  One good lightning strike and that wire 
could be carrying
far more current than it normally would, perhaps enough to be dangerous.

I've had problems running three servers getting shocked on the cases. 
 Given enough
signal wire, I guess there's a point where the wiring becomes a safety 
issue.  Low quality
switching could be the culprit too, perhaps a good reason to use a 
plastic case KVM
switch instead of the cheaper metal box dumb variants.

Well I'm not an EE, my older brother basically is though.  He deals with 
Industrial three
phase power though he says people really should be careful even around 
phone lines.
Apparently some electricians have no respect for electricity, sadly you 
wonder how long
those people will last.

Not religion, religiosity.  I'm using the term in the generic sense, as
one might describe Emacs zealots as "religious".

In a sense, the term is meant as the opposite of, say, "scientific".
While the scientific method is to observe phenomena and form theories and
derive abstractions from the observations, religious thought requires one
to interpret the phenomena in the context of the abstractions and existing
theories.  One does not take a religious belief, test it, then dismiss it
if the test fails.  The belief is constant while the world shifts instead
of shifting beliefs around more and more understanding of a constant
world.

This has little to do with spirituality.

> Whether or not a person is religious has less than everything to do with
> what they are aware of or accepting of.

I'm not sure how to parse that sentence.

> This is a broad statement that doesn't in my opinion pass the test of
> bigotry.

Nor that one.  If it doesn't pass the test of bigotry, does that mean it
cannot be labelled bigotry (for failing the test)?  Your ambiguity
confounds.

> There are some people who believe that their religious view must be
> foisted on others politically.  I don't.

Uh... wha?  A religious view requires all other understanding to be
interpreted within the context of faith.  I don't give a hang one way or
the other if you or anyone else attempts to foist their religious views on
others.  I trust that the theories of the Enlightenment (including the
scientific method) have nearly become deeply enough ingrained in the
cultural fabric to prevent full-scale Inquisition and the like.  Enough
people are capable of judging for themselves that the irrational can be
allowed to do as they please without fear of infecting the rest of
civilization.

> Radical Muslims do.  That's why we're losing troops in Iraq now.  No
> matter how people feel about Iraq, I hope they see the courage of a lot
> of the troops that are over there.

Wow.  Non-sequitor alert... but anyway, this seems like a fine example of
"foisting views".

But really it's more like someone coming over to your house, busting down
your door, then renting you a door (then tearing out your plumbing and
polluting your well then renting you water service, etc., etc.).

[And if the intent were to create a "liberated" state that respects the
sovereignty of the people of Iraq, it would seem the rebuilding effort
would start with the U.S. Constitution and a Xerox machine... but
apparently that's not the goal. -- No, the goal is clearly to open markets
and create yet another client state with little or no sovereignty.]

> I do care about the problems with email, that's very true.

Perhaps you should spend more time analyzing the system and understanding
its strengths before you start devising work-arounds for its perceived
weaknesses.

I find that your draconian (and often far-fetched and misinformed)
proposals destroy those things that make email a valuable communication
tool in order to avoid a minor annoyance.

From baloo at ursine.ca  Fri May  7 10:57:02 2004
From: baloo at ursine.ca (Paul Johnson)

Subject: [PLUG] RJ45 to Coax adapter?

Michael Robinson <plug_0 at robinson-west.com> writes:

> a total of seven rooms, six plus the server room.  It's best if you
> run multiple cables together all at once though one of the problems
> I ran into running Cat-5 off a spool is that I would have needed to
> premeasure and pre cut.

No, you don't.  I've run cable before, you put your spool box down by
the hole you're running the cable from, and pull it through the walls
to where you're going using fishtape, then once you've secured the end
of the cable, go pull the excess slack out, make your cut, and throw
on the connectors.  It's pretty botch-proof if you know how to use a
crimper and fishtape.

> Don't run standard Cat-5 through ducting unless you like
> hydrochloric acid, etc.  

??

> I think Ethernet wires run at somewhere close to 300-400 volts, get
> shocked once and you'll probably never touch a live ethernet wire
> again.

I've handled live ethernet wire before.  Never shocked.  Only time I
got shocked was when I was running ethernet cable, and some jackass
decided to test out an etherkiller on the opposite end of the line I
was working on.  That hurt like hell.  No equipment was damaged, save
for my hand and temporarily tripping the breaker the outlet was on
that I unwittingly shorted with a crimper.

> Cat 5 has to do with the number of twists per foot.

Not exclusively.  Number of wires also factors in.  Category 3 cable
is 4-strand wire, and commonly uses RJ-11 connectors (aka a phone
cord).  As opposed to Catagory 5's 8-strand cord, commonly used with
RJ-45 connectors (aka an Ethernet cable)

-- 
Paul Johnson
<baloo at ursine.ca>

Not only that, but breaks SMTP.  Just try mailing someone something
mission-critical then go on vacation for two weeks to someone with CR
(something I did in 2001, except I didn't know they were running a
broken MTA).  They lost their job, then blamed me because their MX was
busted and was stupidly waiting for me to reply.  Thank God he was
only a work acquaintance, it would have really sucked had there been
love lost.

>> For the sake of sanity, one email per user, and for system roles, one

> personal stuff.  There's lots of good reasons.
>
> At one time I considered using plus-addresses for mailing lists (and I'm
> kind of surprised more people don't), but then God created procmail and it
> is good.

Well, for different personal roles, plus addresses are your friend if
you're not a procmail god.  The reason plus addresses are better than
entirely different addresses, is that your correspondents don't have
to remember a bunch of different addresses, just user+role at site and if
they're not sure which role, then just user at site still works.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Fri May  7 11:20:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Fri May  7 11:20:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RJ45 to Coax adapter?
In-Reply-To: <87vfj8g7eh.fsf@ursine.ca>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0405061457480.10542-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
	 <409ACA35.30803@robinson-west.com>  <87vfj8g7eh.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <1083954336.6269.208.camel@localhost>

On Thu, 2004-05-06 at 21:58, Paul Johnson wrote:

> > Cat 5 has to do with the number of twists per foot.
> 
> Not exclusively.  Number of wires also factors in.  Category 3 cable
> is 4-strand wire, and commonly uses RJ-11 connectors (aka a phone
> cord).  As opposed to Catagory 5's 8-strand cord, commonly used with
> RJ-45 connectors (aka an Ethernet cable)

Actually, yes, exclusively.

Cat-3 may normally only be two pair that you've seen, but I have at
least two or three cat-3 patch cables floating around for use with old
10BaseT NICs.  I can assure you, they have an RJ-45 connector at each
end with four pairs of wires.

Cat-5 that *you* have seen may have all been 4-pair... but if you look
for it, you can find even 50 or 100 pair cat-5 cable out there.  Beyond
100 pair, it becomes difficult to maintain the quality, as I understand
it, so most cable over 100 pair is only rated at cat-3.

The category of cable is based upon the number of twists per foot.  The
number of twists is what allows it to function at the various levels...
16Mbps for cat 3, 100Mbps for cat 5.  

Saying cat-5 is always 4-pair and cat-3 is always 2-pair is like saying
all vehicles on the road have four wheels...

Rob

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri May  7 12:08:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri May  7 12:08:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Wifi Clinic - Saturday May 15 11am to 5pm
Message-ID: <20040507190639.GA8502@gate.kl-ic.com>

This is a reminder of the Linux Wifi Clinic on Saturday, May 15 
from 11AM to 5PM.  Riverdale High School off Terwilliger in SW
Portland.   http://hs.riverdale.k12.or.us/directions.html 
The school has tables and power plugs, and lots of bandwidth to the
Internet. 

Invite your friends (well, no, not YOUR friends... :-) )  Post this
to other user groups.  If you are a business owner and too busy to
do your own setup, stop by and meet some of the many consultants
available who you can pay to do it for you.

There was a great deal of interest at the PLUG meeting last night,
with quite a few Linux people interested in attending and helping. 
The big question there was, how many Wifi savvy folks would be there
from Personal Telco Project?  Some folks have made enthusiastic
commitments, but the more the merrier!

There are three levels of project we -could- do:
   (1)  basic Linux system setup on a laptop
>> (2)  setting up Wifi and road warrior security
   (3)  setting up a PTP node
   (4)  WAP hacking, like reprogramming WRT54Gs .

However, in the interests of time, we will be concentrating on (2),
setting up Wifi on laptops with Linux already running.  Setting up
portable security, IPTABLES, SSH keys, etc. will be a priority.  If
the clinic works out OK, we can be more ambitious the next time.  We
would like to concentrate on 802.11B.  Again, we can do G the next
time.  This is not to say we can't do some distro installs, or some
advanced hacking, after we get everyone up and running and secure and
cracker-tested;  I just think we will have a full day with the basics. 

So, prerequisites:

  (1)  Patience, and a willingness to help others if you can.

  (2)  A laptop with a reasonably recent Linux installed, and
       -backed up- (we will be testing security, you may get
       root-kitted).   Bring your AC adapter, CD drive, floppy
       drive, ethernet card, or whatever you need to move bits.
       We will be Linux distro agnostic:  Redhat 8, Debian ?, SUSE
       ?, Mandrake ?, or better.   Within the last two years so
       we can be sure there are drivers and security updates for
       that distro.  Avoid Lindows (too insecure). Unless someone
       is pretty familiar with wifi drivers for 2.6, we should
       avoid this recently introduced kernel.  

       If you want a nice distro for newbies, I suggest Xandros
       Desktop 2 Deluxe, which is based on Debian and has a lot of
       features designed for the new user.  If you are a cheapskate,
       download Debian or Fedora Core 1 (not 2!) and burn some CDs. 
       Check http://www.linux-laptop.net  for laptop gotchas.  No,
       you cannot run a decent road-warrior Linux on your 286 8Mbyte
       240x320 10 year old cheapo.  We are not here to help you 
       recover from horrendously bad buying decisions.

  (3)  A wifi card with linux drivers.  I suggest a PRISM based
       Senao card, 2511CD 200mW .  Cheaper, lower power PRISM
       cards are around, but beware, some manufacturers change to 
       unsupported chipsets while keeping the same model number.
       If you are unsure, ask the list.  We can support beta or
       oddball drivers if someone steps up to support and configure
       those drivers.  The Atheros G stuff looks interesting, but
       we need a volunteer to take care of those installs. 
       Built-in wifi can be "challenging".

  (4)  The ethernet-connected Wireless Access Point (WAP) that
       you plan to use at home (no USB unless you are sure you
       can configure it from Linux).  If you are using the WAP
       with external DHCP and routing, you may want to bring in
       your server (yikes!). 

       If you don't have a WAP, I suggest the $80-$100 Linksys
       WRT54G (not GS, and serial numbers starting with CD5...)
       because it is a customizer's playground, or the $40-$60
       Linksys BEFW11S4 because it is cheap and easy. Note that
       almost all current WAP units are web-page configured and
       pretty easy to figure out if you've read the docs.

  (5)  Documentation - bring your system notebook to make notes
       and write down procedures (you DO have a system notebook,
       yes?  If not, buy a steno pad and start taking notes!).
       Also, manuals for your WAP, wifi card, Linux distro, and
       pointers to websites you have found useful so far.  Read
       the docs you have, please!  

  (6)  Think up some secure, easy to remember passwords.  I like
       initial letters and numbers, like 4oYbabtU ( 4 of Your bases
       are belong to Us ).  Rude phrases are easier to remember and
       harder to babble to others.  We may quickly crack the passwords
       you have now:  "Rover123", "Shirley", and "studMuffin" are
       overused.  I cracked 4 passwords on my father-in-law's computer
       in 230 milliseconds ... he learned to use better passwords.

  (7)  Crucifixes, magic amulets, black candles.  Prayers and/or
       Spells.  We will have good people there, but cannot guarantee
       results, so whatever supernatural gestures work for you...

  (8)  Did I mention patience?

  
Rick Lindahl ( rick at invictusnetworks.com ) will be there with some
gear to sell (Senao cards, antennas, cables, other fun stuff). 
We may also have somebody to peddle Linksys WRT54G WAPs.  Since our
vendor friends may run out before you get there, make arrangements in
advance to be sure the device you want to buy will be reserved for you.

I will probably think up more stuff before next Saturday.  Help
of any kind will be appreciated.  The cool thing about the Linux
world is that there is always something you know that somebody
else will appreciate learning (and vice versa)!

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From ehem at m5p.com  Fri May  7 12:59:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri May  7 12:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Webmail server suggestions
In-Reply-To: <20040507073602.11784.41905.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

> From: Michael Robinson <plug_0 at robinson-west.com>
> 
> Well, it's not overboard.  Sendmail is hard to configure, so it's hard 
> to configure
> properly.  Sendmail is still insecure, and likely will always be so.  A 
> little googling
> and you can find out about exploits of even the most recent releases of 
> sendmail-8.
> I have the 3000 page book on sendmail, no thanks.  Postfix and even qmail
> are easier to work with than sendmail.  They were written with security in
> mind.  If you really think Sendmail can be set up securely, try to convince
> Wietse Venema.  He wrote Postfix to replace sendmail.

You've mentioned the major version, but not the minor version. Versions
8.6 and 8.7 followed the security patch a week trend, 8.9 and more
recently 8.12 are a very different matter. Both are major version 8, but
two are secure today, two very definitely aren't.

The last sendmail hole was found over 6 months ago, similar to the time
frame for the last postfix hole. Exim, another MTA, had a hole announced
yesterday. All Linux distributions contain helper scripts to handle
generic sendmail installations, so even if can't handle the config
yourself it isn't too difficult. None of the others include the level of
functionality that sendmail has.


> From: Michael Robinson <plug_0 at robinson-west.com>
> At least I got the 300 part right, somebody really needs to lighten up a
> bit.  I know,
> go touch a live ethernet wire and make sure it's 300 millivolts.

True, but the 3 orders of magnitude you were off by were far more
important. 300V is dangerous to handle, 300mV can be handled utterly
casually.

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri May  7 14:19:02 2004
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Fri May  7 14:19:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Virus Scanning Within A Java App'?
Message-ID: <20040507141920.3fcc27b7.jason@vancleve.com>

Anyone know of an antivirus library for Java?  We have an odd
requirement for a Web service in development:  we are to scan all
incoming messages for virii, within our Java application.

Well, I think this is probably the wrong architecture altogether,
personally.  Which renders my question twofold.  First, is there even a
usable Java library available for this; and second, what would be the
alternative?  If we can convince our client that we should not be virus
scanning in Java, within our application, we might get this requirement
changed.  But I'll need to make a strong case.

Couldn't we run a *nix daemon of some sort, configured to listen to our
Web ports, scan all requests and relay a modified stream to the Web
server on different ports, or so?  That daemon would only need to flag
messages as infected (an HTTP header will do), so that our application
can respond with an appropriate error.

--Jason Van Cleve

On Fri, 7 May 2004, Jason Van Cleve wrote:
> Couldn't we run a *nix daemon of some sort, configured to listen to our
> Web ports, scan all requests and relay a modified stream to the Web
> server on different ports, or so?

Amavis with clamav can do this.  It can be configured as a kind of SMTP
pass-through that will take a stream in one side and send it out the other
just marked for infection (or quarantined as you see fit).

> That daemon would only need to flag messages as infected (an HTTP header
> will do), so that our application can respond with an appropriate error.

Why would you want an HTTP header in an email message?

Anyway, you can certainly flag infected messages.

Jeme> So we've got a Voodoo 2 card.  I assume that's an intel PCI card

Jeme> Anybody ever used a Voodoo2 add-on card before?

My father had one of these.  The Voodoo2 (I liked to call it a
"DooDoo2") provides 3D graphics.  Normally, it just passes 2D graphics
through from the onboard video.  When it goes into 3D mode, I gathered
that the DooDoo essentially cuts off the 2D input and substitutes its
own.  I think you _could_ just disconnect the DooDoo and connect the
monitor directly to mister 2D.

On the other hand, you might still be able to use DooDoo2.  I recall
the word "glide" used.  See, e.g.:
 
   <http://www.xfree86.org/4.3.0/glide.4.html>

I've got one of these sitting in a cardboard box.

On Fri, 2004-05-07 at 16:16, AthlonRob wrote:

> I had honestly hoped that harping on him at every turn would lead him to
> leave the list again, but that doesn't seem to be working too well. 
> Michael won't learn, as his posting history demonstrates.  Michael's
> contributions to the list thus far have provided nothing positive I can
> recall.  He regularly starts ranting about various things (which
> actually lead to him leaving the list 'for good' a few months ago),
> often asks vague questions without answers, and provides the list with a
> plethora of just plain Wrong Information.

The only effective policy I've found for dealing with net kooks is to
simply ignore them.  They tend to thrive on attention, and ignoring them
tends to dry up their enthusiasm.  I also ignore them when they're not
being kooks (if ever), which further deprives them of whatever help they
might have otherwise gotten.  New subscribers may be at first misled
into responding or taking their advice seriously, but most people are
pretty quickly able to figure out who's worth listening to and who
isn't.

People using Cyrus IMAP and Sieve filtering can have message flags
automatically set in delivery, so you can just mark messages as read
without having to even open them.  Something like this:

if header :contains "From" [ "@robinson-west.com" ]
{
  addflag "\\Seen";
}

Otherwise, procmail can simply discard the messages. 

Wil

On Fri, 7 May 2004, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Here's fodder for Jeme and his cohort:

To which "cohort" are you refering?  I'm hardly the only one here who
recognizes the desctructive nature of the Firm.

> <http://www.economist.com/business/displayStory.cfm?story_id=2647328>

I've been saying that for years... and more along those same lines of
interpretting the behavior of systems as one would the behavior of a
living organism.

But the really KOOKY part about this article is this line:

'Unlike much of the soggy thinking peddled by too many anti-globalisers,
"The Corporation" is a surprisingly rational and coherent attack on
capitalism's most important institution.'

Now, I'm going to let the comment about "soggy thinking" slide.  It's full
of so many vague qualifiers ("much", "too many"... one would be too many
to some, so the statement stands) that it doesn't really mean anything.

The SHOCKING part is the last bit.  The corporation is "capitalism's most
important institution"?!?  Are these people totally ignorant?  Adam Smith
makes it VERY CLEAR in his Wealth of Nations (particularly in Chapter 10)
that the firm is an ENEMY of capitalism and can do nothing but hurt the
public interest.  (Granted now that Smith viewed capitalism as a force of
enlightenment rather than a scheme for domination.)

Now, I'm not going to defend capitalism[1] here, but to say that an attack
on corporations is an attack on capitalism is way off base and just shows
how frighteningly effective corporate propaganda has been.

J.

[1] Props where props are due, I suppose... capitalism did go some ways to
serving Smith's purpose of increasing worker productivity, but the profit
motive and a lack of social values has failed to translate that increase
in productivity into more leisure time for the working class opting,
instead, for higher profits and more wealth for the ruling class.

From steve at wirex.net  Fri May  7 18:40:04 2004
From: steve at wirex.net (Steve Beattie)
Date: Fri May  7 18:40:04 2004
Subject: Marking as read (was Re: [PLUG] Common Courtesy)
In-Reply-To: <1083973256.27238.15.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
References: <004401c433cb$60051520$6401a8c0@LAPTOP> <1083890698.6270.108.camel@localhost> <20040507210055.GF10800@nellump.net> <1083971790.6255.229.camel@localhost> <1083973256.27238.15.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>
Message-ID: <20040508013941.GA17325@wirex.net>

On Fri, May 07, 2004 at 04:40:57PM -0700, Wil Cooley wrote:
> People using Cyrus IMAP and Sieve filtering can have message flags
> automatically set in delivery, so you can just mark messages as read
> without having to even open them.  Something like this:
> 
> if header :contains "From" [ "@robinson-west.com" ]
> {
>   addflag "\\Seen";
> }
> 
> Otherwise, procmail can simply discard the messages. 

You can do the same thing as your sieve filter above with
procmail/formail, like so:

  :0f
  * ^From:.*@robinson-west.com
  | /usr/bin/formail -A "Status: RO"

I do something similar so that duplicate messages aren't treated as new:

  # Mark duplicates as already read.
  :0 Whc: msgid.lock
  | /usr/bin/formail -D 8192 msgid.cache

  :0 fWa
  | /usr/bin/formail -A "Status: RO"

See the formail(1), procmailrc(5), and procmailex(5) manpages for more
details.

--

<steve at wirex.net>                         Complete StackGuard distro at
http://NxNW.org/~steve/                            immunix.org
        http://www.sardonix.org -- Audit code, earn respect.

they know, and call you up, and refuse to take your advice, thinking
they know better.  Terminally stupid[2].

[2] I differentiate between stupid and ignorant.  Both are ignorant
and both imply the person is capable of learning in the first place.
To qualify as stupid, you have to fail to learn when provided with
ample clue.  Ignorance is readily fixed, stupidity could be terminal[1].

I was re-running the phone lines in the walls in my first apartment
(since it had five phone outlets and only one that actually worked,
got credit from my landlord for doing it, too) at two in the morning
(too hot to sleep) and I held a couple of the wire leads in my teeth
for a second.  Well, I wasn't concerned about the ~12VDC of the phone
line under normal conditions, but I did forget about the ~90VAC that a
phone line carries when it rings.  And at that moment, someone dialed
the wrong number.  Dropped that wire instantly.  Roommate and I had a
good laugh.

In-Reply-To: <409C8C57.7000609@robinson-west.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405071741170.31335@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
 <409C8C57.7000609@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405080239380.14998@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Sat, 8 May 2004, Michael Robinson wrote:
> It's been a bad week.  Even the press is embarassed to some degree
> reporting, a first really.

It's got to be embarrassing to admit that your pony can't show.

> I hope it raises the bar on our hopes for the individual person and
> causes a ripple affect here at home in a positive way, the way the super
> bowl scandal did.

I'd hardly call a tit a "scandal".  Sheesh.  It wasn't even displayed
sexually.  Just some body part out there in the open.  Grow up.

And I'd hardly call increased censorship "a ripple [e]ffect in a positive
way".

> If it didn't make us angry, the Iraqi people would be right in thinking
> that we aren't commited to their freedom.

Well, when we're shooting them and putting them in prisons and deciding
how their nation should be run and by whom, well, we're clearly not
committed to their freedom.

> I don't blame Rumsfeld or Bush, shame how investigations are just
> getting started and already a problem that Rumsfeld may not have been
> able to predict or prevent is being used by some to pressure him into
> resigning.  I think this country believes in innocent until proven
> guilty.

OK.  But what does it take to show that these guys are guilty of just
plain lying whenever they like to suit the current spin?

Here's a really nice example of Rumsfeld just lying the way he always has,
but forgetting that this is 2004 and we actually have instant access to
prior records to show inconsistencies:

<URL: http://www.moveon.org/censure/caughtonvideo/ >

Man, I love that one.

These guys (and I mean everyone with the opportunity, really) have been
manipulating the press, particularly television, for years and getting
away with it.  Finally, the resources exist to prevent the large scale
fraud that has been perpetrated for the last several decades.

Jerry Mander, in his book _Four Arguments For The Elimination Of
Television_, describes one flaw of the medium as being an inability to
revise, research, and correct.  This particularly applies to live
broadcasts where information that is incorrect can be given by honest
mistake and taken as fact by the audience who might not be tuning in at
some later hour when the correction is issued.  (And unlike print media,
there is no public archive of corrections for later perusal.)  This has
led to certain public figures purposely giving false information to
television broadcasters for immediate effect knowing full well that it can
later be corrected or denied with very little risk of being challenged on
the spot.  Until very recently, it was common for a person interviewed on
television to simply say, "That's not what I said" and offer some
variation that cannot be challenged in the immediate context and therefore
will be considered truth by the majority of the viewers.

I can just imagine that Meet The Press (the source of the clip noted
above) has a team of folks sitting off-screen with tons of digital
transcriptions of interviews and press statements and conferences through
which they can grep and instantly queue to the interviewer for display.

This clip is a great example of that because it's clear, at first, that
the interviewer is surprised that Rumsfeld would deny Iraq was considered
an imminent threat, but then has evidence to contradict within seconds.

The technology is very powerful.  It's good to see it used as a force of
enlightenment once in a while.

J.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Sat May  8 07:20:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat May  8 07:20:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Spamming on PLUG Message-Id header
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0405080700150.6609@pecos.madboa.com>

It looks like some bot (spam or virus, I can't tell) is running
through the PLUG archives -- or someone who's infected is subscribed
to PLUG -- and lifting Message-Id headers for mail shenanigans.

I was combing through my mail log this morning when I saw a couple odd
entries:

  May  8 01:27:19 irvine sm-mta[12110]: i488RGXj012110:
  ruleset=check_rcpt,
  arg1=<pine.lnx.4.58.0404080417080.16338 at pecos.madboa.com>,
  relay=c-24-30-20-167.mw.client2.attbi.com [24.30.20.167], reject=550
  5.7.1 <pine.lnx.4.58.0404080417080.16338 at pecos.madboa.com>...
  Relaying denied. Proper authentication required.

  [...]

  May  8 04:19:52 irvine sm-mta[14153]: i48BJhXj014153:
  ruleset=check_rcpt,
  arg1=<pine.lnx.4.58.0404080417080.16338 at pecos.madboa.com>,
  relay=[69.111.40.185], reject=550 5.7.1
  <pine.lnx.4.58.0404080417080.16338 at pecos.madboa.com>... Relaying
  denied. IP name lookup failed [69.111.40.185]

The "arg1=" entry indicated the intended addressee, but the wierd
thing is that it looks like a pine Message-Id header. The only
difference is that it's all lower-case characters; otherwise, it's a
dead ringer.

So I searched my sent-mail archives looking for that header. Bingo!:

  Date: Thu, 8 Apr 2004 04:22:28 -0700 (PDT)
  From: Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>
  To: plug at lists.pdxlinux.org
  Subject: Re: [PLUG] Next steps in Bayian SpamAssassin installation
  In-Reply-To: <4074D25D.4090308 at dimstar.net>
  Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0404080417080.16338 at pecos.madboa.com>

My locally generated Message-ID header ended up as bot fodder. Ewwww.

must specify a filesystem type.  I used the Red Hat Hardware Browser and 
verified that /dev/scd0 is the correct device for the cdrom drive.  So I 
tried mounting again, this time giving it the command line option "-t

I've never seen a company so unwilling to discuss their product.

 > Jeme> Anybody ever used a Voodoo2 add-on card before?

Yep. They were "the bomb" about 6 years ago.  If you had two they
would daisy-chain and do SLI (single-line interleave) which was
actually pretty nice (even with just one it was a very nice card,
IMHO).

<snip>

 > 
 > On the other hand, you might still be able to use DooDoo2.  I recall
 > the word "glide" used.  See, e.g.:
 >  
 >    <http://www.xfree86.org/4.3.0/glide.4.html>

Glide is the correct buzzword.  This is the howto I used years back to
get my voodoo2 working: (The linux 3dfx howto, available at many
places)

http://www.gamers.org/dEngine/xf3D/howto/3Dfx-HOWTO.html

Although, now there is a not that this howto is outdated, with some
links: "See glide.xxedgexx.com for more recent info, and use
news.3dfx.com for inquiries."

Russell is probably right in that you can ignore the voodoo card, and
go straight to the i740 (wire it that way--of course you won't get
acceleration off the voodoo, although the i740 does do "decent"
openGL for that time period).   You may also be able to leave the
voodoo patch cable in place and use the i740 directly.

If you do get it going, it should perform well enough to play some
semi-recent games (UT, for example, which has been ported).

On Sat, 2004-05-08 at 02:58, Michael Robinson wrote:

> I guess that's just a lie.  I don't feel enthusiastic anymore.  I tried 
> to help someone, look what happened when I made a mistake that was 
> really only off by an order of
> magnitude.  I'm not an EE.  I am a two year degreed political exile from 

only an order of magnitude? no the information was completely wrong. 
Having just looked up the signaling specs for ethernet it looks like a
3.15V peak-to-peak for 100BaseT if that is signaled differenterly the
potential between the two conductors of a pair could be as much at
6.3V.  This is about TWO orders of magnitude less than the 300V you
mentioned, and the 300 you seem to think saves your answer is no where
is sight since the person who mentioned 300mV (three orders of
magnitude) said "more like" i.e. on the order of.

(Please note that my discussion of ethernet voltages is based on a very
quick search an may be way off on some of the details.  Also when
working on strange cabling be careful, phone lines use much the same
wiring as ether net and the ring voltage of a standard phone line can be
as much as 100V relative to earth, this can give you a nasty shock and
be quite harmeful if yo are holding the wire in your mouth standing in
barefeet in a pool of water...don't do that.  On the other hand 100V is
not anything like 300V)

> PSU.  If people genuinely love this subject, I do not expect to offend 
> so many that I would be
> driven off purposely over a simple mistake.  

if it was juts one mistake it would be one think, but you post was
riddled with inacuracies so as to be not just worthless, but downright
harmful, other had not stepped forward to correct you I would have.

From llywrch at agora.rdrop.com  Sun May  9 12:34:01 2004
From: llywrch at agora.rdrop.com (Geoff Burling)
Date: Sun May  9 12:34:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RJ45 to Coax adapter?
In-Reply-To: <87r7tv8ir2.fsf@ursine.ca>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0405091214520.5421-100000@joan.burling.com>

On Sat, 8 May 2004, Paul Johnson wrote:

> AthlonRob <AthlonRob at axpr.net> writes:
>
> > Saying cat-5 is always 4-pair and cat-3 is always 2-pair is like saying
> > all vehicles on the road have four wheels...
>
> Actually, more like all cars have four wheels, all bicycles have two.

Even to say that in absolute terms is inaccurate. There have been 3-wheel
automobiles manufactured, at least until the 1950s. (One manufacturer
of these gas-burning, street-legal tricycles was Morgan, headquartered
in England & I believe is currently the largest English-owned automobile
manufacturer in England -- they produce something less than 1000 units
in a year. ISTR there were others, but for reasons below I'm sure someone
will mention who they were.)

And IIRC, there are some versions of recumbent bicycles that have 3 wheels;
yes, they are properly called _tricycles_, but you'd just annoy people &
wear yourself out correcting this usage.

My point with these OT corrections is that is always hazardous to speak
of absolutes & certainties concerning any topic. I used to say that
``unique" & pregnancy are two absolute conditions -- you either are or you
aren't -- but personal experience has proven to me that it's possible to
be ``kinda" pregnant (Google on the term ``blighted ovum" for the details).

One of the few absolutes I would now count on now -- based on my experience
on Wikipedia -- is that in any sufficiently large enough group, while
there will be people who puff up their egos by expounding incorrect
knowledge, there will also be sharp minds that will correct this
misinformation, thus deflating these egos. Unfortunately, some of these
inflated egos prove to have armoring, & prove immune to the constant
corrections.

Geoff

PS -- Rereading the above, it occurs to me that some people here may
think I'm talking about them: as I said, all of my examples concerning
inflated egos & their armoring come from Wikipedia; so if the shoe fits,
I wouldn't advertise it.

> I have been trying to figure out to download the current slackware
> distribution.

  I have the 4-cd-rom set for -9.1 and you're welcome to copies. My
preference is to support Patrick and his elves so I'm on the subscription
service. But, the distribution is certainly available to be copied.

  If you're installing on a workstation/server then you'll probably want the
ide kernel. If you're installing on a portable with pcmcia support (e.g.,
for an external cd-rom drive) then you'll want that one, too.

> The documentation also refers to a program called loadlin, but it is not
> very clear about whether loadlin is only for dos installs or if you can
> use it to install over an old (non-slackware) linux install or do a clean
> install.

 Loadlin is used to boot linux from a DOS system. You don't need it. You
also don't need rawwrite if you're working on a linux box.

  I have found Slackware to be very easy and clean to install over a prior
(RH 7.3) distribution and on brand-new machines. Oh, ... I also installed it
over a libranet installation.

  Will you be at next Saturday's WiFi Clinic? I can bring the cd-roms or I
can burn a set and bring them.

 >--Brian Quade
> I have been trying to figure out to download the current slackware 
> distribution.  I read much of the documentation and am still confused.  
> Every other time I download a cd installation, it comes in the form of 
> an iso file that I just burn onto a disc.  But slackware has different 
> kernels and options, 

There are slackware iso's available.  You can go to slackware.com and 
click on 'get slack' for a list of mirrors.

http://slackware.com/getslack/

or if you can not find what you need there, you can use a google search 
and pull up something like this.

http://ftp.man.olsztyn.pl/pub/linux/distributions/slackware/slackware-9.1-iso/

If you do this however, I still recommend using the md5 checksums from 
slackware.com to insure you have the correct image. Hope this helps.

Will



From drl at drloree.com  Sun May  9 22:55:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sun May  9 22:55:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] DNS Problem
In-Reply-To: <409f7604.15293559@mail.aracnet.com>
References: <409f7604.15293559@mail.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <1084168517.1126.29.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sun, 2004-05-09 at 11:26, Prutzer wrote:
> HI all,
> Okay, in Mike's class we were trying to setup DNS to resolve to a
> simple caching client/server so that we could dig locally and see it
> find the other machines on my private network as well as show a
> difference in time between getting and address from my ISP's domain
> server and the then stored locally version that should be stored
> locally in the cache. Nothing seems to work.
> I can connect to my isp and get the correct info using:
> 
> dig www.pcc.edu
> 
> but it's not being stored locally.
> I can do:
> 
> dig -x 127.0.0.1 and get proper reply

There is a reverse-lookup zone for this address in the default install
of bind.
> 
> I can ping by IP on my closed network.

Have you set up a zone file for your local network?
> 
> If I try dig -x 192.168.4.2 ( this is the IP address in my network of
> the machine i'm doing the resolve/caching on)
> I get error no server available.

To get a response to this query, you would need to set up a
reverse-lookup zone file in /etc/bind for your private network.
> 
> I've attached my script file that shows this.
> 
The program bind knows nothing about what is in the hosts file, it only
knows about the zone files you tell it about in /etc/bind/named.conf

> I'm unable to figure out why it's not working.
> 
To test for caching, it seems to me that you would need to track down
where the cache is being stored.  Although, I suppose you could do
something like "dig www.google.com @192.168.4.2" then (if you get an
appropriate response) you could unplug your gateway and try the same
command again.  If the resolver is caching, you will get the same
response, if it is not, you should get a "no server available" error.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree

On Sun, 2004-05-09 at 18:38, Vincent Yau wrote:
> Dear All:
> 
> I am in a small building that has a pre-built cat5e network.  All jacks
> and wires are cat5e which transmits both voice and data.

Cat5e is a cable spec, it defines the electrical and signal
specifications of the cable, not the signal assignments.  There are a
number of specs for the signal assignments, but mostly these juts defone
the pairs, you will need to know which wireing spec and which pair the
phone circut is on.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Mon May 10 14:30:03 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon May 10 14:30:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] slackware download process????
In-Reply-To: <409E7E2D.5060508@brianquade.net>
References: <409E7E2D.5060508@brianquade.net>
Message-ID: <1084225056.29790.71.camel@localhost>

On Sun, 2004-05-09 at 11:53, Brian Quade wrote:
> I have been trying to figure out to download the current slackware 
> distribution.  I read much of the documentation and am still confused.  
> Every other time I download a cd installation, it comes in the form of 
> an iso file that I just burn onto a disc.  

Let's hold up here for just a second... are you burning an ISO file onto
a disk as a file or as an image?  You need to burn it as an image... if
you mount the CD and do an ls, you should see many files, not just an
ISO file.  :-)

> But slackware has different 
> kernels and options, so the documentation explains how to create the iso 
> using mkisofs assuming I already have the whole directory structure (or 
> just the files I need) on my machine.  But I can't find any 
> documentation about how to download all of those files into the correct 
> directories other than to create the directories by hand and then 
> download each file by hand into the proper directory.  There must be a 
> simpler way to do this.

AFAIK, you should be able to boot most of the kernels from Pat's default
CD.  Do you think you'll need a funky kernel?  Those CD making
instructions are simply to help you make an ISO out of a set of files if
you need to do something funky.

And to get them all, download the whole directory tree.  Most ftp
utilities out there more advanced than the commandline 'ftp' are able to
handle this.  I'm not sure, but I think 
wget ftp://ftp.scarlet.be/pub/slackware/slackware-9.1/ will do the
trick.

> The documentation also refers to a program 
> called loadlin, but it is not very clear about whether loadlin is only 
> for dos installs or if you can use it to install over an old 
> (non-slackware) linux install or do a clean install.

Those instructions are up there for people trying to install Slackware
on ultra-low-memory boxes, essentially.  We're talking like 5MB of
RAM... where the initrd is too big.  :-)

As Rich stated, loadlin only works with DOS and really, you don't need
to worry about it.

As Rich said... just pop in the CD and use the default ide kernel, you
should be good to go.  :-)

Rob

Subject: [PLUG] Shared Address Books
Message-ID: <1084235176.29788.95.camel@localhost>

Hey list-

I've wanted to implement something for a while here on my home network,
I just haven't gotten around to looking at *how* to implement it until
recently.  I can't find anything that explains how to deal with shared
address books like what I'm looking for.  :-\

I'd like to start storing address books on my server in such a manner
that regardless of the email program I'm using, I can access my address
book much as I access my email (imaps).  At first, I thought LDAP was
the way to go for this... I went so far as to set up openldap (which
didn't want to compile on my old server box) before it really started to
look like it wouldn't do the trick.  Sure, it could provide a
server-side address book for me, but that book would be shared among all
the users of my server and would, by and large, be read-only.

So is there such a thing out there?  Or is it a pipe dream to be able to
share a single address book between Thunderbird or lookOut Express when
I'm using somebody else's computer, SquirrelMail when I'm on a public
computer, and Evolution or KMail here on my baby?

Surely the idea has been discussed before...  :-)

Rob

Mike,

You need to setup X for kde, gde, or mozilla.

If you are using a earlier RedHat distro, there is Xconfigurator.
Later ones have xf86config, maybe other distros have this because it
is from XFree86.org.

When X is setup.  Start the X windowing system by issuing:
startx.

Or you could have the system startup in X by editing /etc/inittab or by
answering yes in Xconfigurator when it asks for startup option.

Ken
CAD2CAM.COM

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon May 10 21:31:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon May 10 21:31:02 2004

 interface
In-Reply-To: <40A049B7.1080602@comcast.net>
References: <40A049B7.1080602@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405102129060.14998@shaft.bitmine.net>

On Mon, 10 May 2004, Mike Layne wrote:
> I only get the command prompt, which is elegant but doesn't tell me
> much.
>
> How do I start kde or gde or mozilla from there?

I read that you've got X configured somewhat... if you want X to start
automatically when the machine boots (as I do), then you will want to
install a "display manager" to manage graphical logins.

I like gdm, but there is also kdm and xdm.  Only install one.

(If you install gdm, be sure to go into "configure greeter" and change to
the graphical greeter and set it so that system functions can be done
without the root password.  That way, the system can be shutdown from the
gdm greeter without having to type a password.

From jeme at brelin.net  Mon May 10 23:52:02 2004
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Mon May 10 23:52:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Whole new problem - wildly self re-generating K applications
In-Reply-To: <40A0599D.908@comcast.net>
References: <40A0563A.7080502@comcast.net> <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405102131340.14998@shaft.bitmine.net>
 <40A0599D.908@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405102347040.14998@shaft.bitmine.net>

[Re: ditching KDE]

On Mon, 10 May 2004, Mike Layne wrote:
> I love the plan, but, having not practiced safe sex, find myself in need
> of a medical proceedure.  How do I get rid of it/

Well, the first thing to do is not run it.

How is it getting started?  How are you starting X?

This is one of those places where the configurability and customizability
of GNU/Linux systems gets to be a hinderance.  There are so many ways you
could be doing this, telling you how to undo it isn't exactly
straightforward.

If you're running a display manager (xdm, gdm, kdm), then usually the
display manager will let you choose which session manager or window
manager you'll be using (kde, gnome, enlightenment, windowmaker, etc.).
Start up with something other than KDE.

If you're starting X with startx from the command line, then you probably
have something in your ~/.xsession file that is starting KDE.  Modify that
to start something else.  You can change it to gnome-session, maybe.

After that, you have to run aptitude (or synaptic or dselect or whatever
makes you happy) and remove all the KDE stuff.  The easiest way I've found
is to remove everything that says kdelib, kdebin, kde-lib, kde-bin, etc.
That will remove the required libraries and apt will remove all the
applications depending on those libraries.  It's a start, anyway.

While metapackages are really nice for installing large collections of
packages, there's no commensurate way of removing large collections except
by finding the common dependency and removing that.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin

From heinlein at madboa.com  Tue May 11 08:00:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Tue May 11 08:00:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Shared Address Books
In-Reply-To: <1084235176.29788.95.camel@localhost>
References: <1084235176.29788.95.camel@localhost>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.58.0405110746020.466@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On Mon, 10 May 2004, AthlonRob wrote:

> I'd like to start storing address books on my server in such a
> manner that regardless of the email program I'm using, I can access
> my address book much as I access my email (imaps).  At first, I
> thought LDAP was the way to go for this... I went so far as to set
> up openldap (which didn't want to compile on my old server box)
> before it really started to look like it wouldn't do the trick.
> Sure, it could provide a server-side address book for me, but that
> book would be shared among all the users of my server and would, by
> and large, be read-only.

OpenLDAP needn't be read-only, though I'll admit that easy-to-use GUI
clients aren't exactly easy to come by.

If you can set up your local users with passwords in your LDAP
database, then there are a few GUI clients that'll allow folks to
connect and alter records. GQ (a gtk+ app) is my favorite:

  http://sourceforge.net/projects/gqclient/

I haven't installed phpLDAPadmin, but it looks pretty full-featured:

  http://phpldapadmin.sourceforge.net/

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From rlucas at tercent.com  Tue May 11 19:35:02 2004
From: rlucas at tercent.com (Randall Lucas)
Date: Tue May 11 19:35:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] VNC on Linux
Message-ID: <40A18CE8.5050304@tercent.com>

The graphical suggestions are good IF you can afford the time, hassle, 
and politics of putting the special client (er, server, depending on 
what flavor) on the remote machine.

On the other hand, for those of you who can live without the graphics, 
"screen" is the niftiest program ever, supporting all kinds of stuff 
like detaching and reattaching, scrollback buffers in each of multiple 
windows, split-screen, and intelligent key bindings that don't conflict 
much with other apps' magic keys.  And all you need is a VT100 (emulator).

Not enough people use or know about screen, but even if you never use 
the multiple virtual window capability, it's worth using screen within 
the window for all your terminal sessions in case you get booted -- you 
can always reattach to the screen and have your process happily waiting 
for you.

Randall

From ian at znark.com  Wed May 12 09:06:01 2004
From: ian at znark.com (Ian Burrell)
Date: Wed May 12 09:06:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Java plugin for Mozilla
In-Reply-To: <BAY9-F53GJ2TUSzbAUf0001ebd9@hotmail.com>
References: <BAY9-F53GJ2TUSzbAUf0001ebd9@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <20040512160539.GA21136@accesscom.com>

On Wed, May 12, 2004 at 05:43:26AM +0000, Vincent Yau wrote:
> 
> I am using Mozilla 1.6 and just download the latest J2SDK from Java.
> When trying to setup the java plugin, I simply
> create a symlink from mozilla/plugin to the ns610/libjava plugin
> that comes with the Java JRE/SDK package.
> When I invoke Mozilla, it would crash and give this message:
> 

The problem is creating the symlink to the wrong version of the
plugin.  The Mozilla 1.6 binary is compiled with gcc 3.2 and the Java
plugin needs to use the same compiler version.  The gcc 3.2 compiled
version should be in the ns610-gcc32 directory.

 - Ian

From stever at woo-hoo.com  Wed May 12 09:23:02 2004
From: stever at woo-hoo.com (Steven Raymond)
Date: Wed May 12 09:23:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Interesting article proposes a new aproach for fighting SPAM
In-Reply-To: <1084375888.5410.5.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
References: <1084375888.5410.5.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
Message-ID: <33097.209.210.31.8.1084378959.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>

> I thought this would be worth discussing:
>
> http://www.discover.com/issues/jun-04/departments/emerging-technology/

I find the idea very intriguing.  Perhaps I imagined it hearing about it,
but it seems that there should be a provision for whitelisting certain
servers inbound, therefore removing the computational requirement.  In
other words, only unfamiliar or infrequent SMTP servers would be required
to perform the computation tax.

While the proposed solution would probably work great for my tiny system
with a low volume of traffic- what about a small ISP that receives tens of
thousands of emails a day?  This computational tax is pushed onto the
sender of email, does it cause any corresponding work to be performed by
the receiver, ie, figuring out the expected solution?  How would that
work?







From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed May 12 09:27:01 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed May 12 09:27:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Interesting article proposes a new aproach for fighting
	SPAM
In-Reply-To: <1084375888.5410.5.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
References: <1084375888.5410.5.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1084379354.21616.13.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2004-05-12 at 08:31, Mel Andres wrote:
> I thought this would be worth discussing:
> 
> http://www.discover.com/issues/jun-04/departments/emerging-technology/

A few comments...

At a penny per email, most of us would likely be spending more than a
few bucks a year in addition to our ISP fees.  PLUG would need to start
advertising.  The LKML would need to start charging membership fees. 
Yahoo!'s groups program would implode and go bankrupt in about three
days.  Windows users would all be locked up for not paying their bills
when they got the latest worm.

The email computation scheme seems, to me, to be a bit nutso.  When a
mail server receives an email, be it from another mail server or from a
user, what does it do?  Quite often, it turns around and talks to
another mail server.  If you add 10 seconds worth of CPU time in there,
AOL is going to find they need to buy a skyscraper worth of blade
servers to keep up with the added CPU time.

Sure, they could specify only when non-servers connect to them do they
request the computation (and then, what, compute on a per-recipient
sliding scale?), but then they need to find a scheme to identify servers
instead of clients, since in SMTP talk they're all the same.

Naw, I don't think either of those schemes will fly nor will they work. 
Hunt down the root causes of spam... those who actually make the money
off of it... or keep filtering with more and more advanced spamassassin
rules, but don't charge me a penny or ten seconds of CPU time per email,
that's just nuts.

My two cents worth.  Oops, I guess that's three cents now.  Plus at
least a few dollars for the poor ol' PLUG server that turns this email
into a few hundred more emails....

Rob

Alex Daniloff <alex at daniloff.com> writes:
                                                                                
>What kind of insanity is this:
>> Day pass - $425
>> Convention Sessions - $895 early bird, $1095 standard
>> Exhibit hall plus keynote and BOF - $50 early bird, $75 standard
                                                                                
>Is this "Open Source" Convention for corporate folks or ordinary people?
>Probably I should think twice before buying any of O'Reilly books from now on.

This is the "convention space costs money" insanity, and the "employees
who set up conventions need to get paid" insanity.  This is not at all
out of line for professional conventions, and this convention in particular
is NOT run by volunteers.  A similar volunteer-operated conference I attend
yearly costs $700, for example.  I know they comp at least some of the
speakers.  O'Reilly does turn a small profit on this - though they lost
money as a whole last year.   

If you cannot afford more, I would suggest paying $37.50 (w plug
discount) for the exhibits.  Plenty of good things to see, and good
folks to talk to, and the keynotes are plentiful and fascinating.

This is a professional conference.  I am considering purchasing a full
conference ticket, even though I'm not a professional in this field.
While not exactly a bargain, attendees get good value for money, and
O'Reilly is not gouging.  If it is not worth it to you, don't go.  If
you think conferences should be cheaper, set up one of your own.

Keith

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed May 12 10:24:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed May 12 10:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Wifi Clinic:  Linksys routers on sale again
Message-ID: <20040512172245.GA28001@gate.kl-ic.com>

Attendees of the Linux Wifi clinic next Saturday, May 15:

Bestbuy is having a Linksys sale again;  WRT54G B+G router, $90,
BEFW11S4 B router, $50.  A Linksys mail-in rebate takes $10 off
that price.

We will be focusing on 802.11B at the clinic, but the WRT54G can
be configured for B only. The WRT54G runs Linux so people are
doing wonderful firmware hacks on it.  Be sure to get the Version
2.0 unit, which is labelled "Version 1.1" on the box, but has serial
numbers starting with CDF5.... in little lettering on the bottom of
the box. Serial Numbers CDF4... and lower are earlier versions and not
suitable, these are probably flushed out of the retail channel by now.

There is also a new WRT54GS Speedbooster version, which may prove even
better for hacking someday, but isn't getting much attention yet;  you
probably want to purchase the plain WRT54G.

The local folks ( http://www.portless.net/ewrt/ ) that are doing the
EWRT firmware hack also have a local source of the WRT54G units at $80.

See you all Saturday at 11am!  http://www.keithl.com/linwifi

New Releases

***Eclipse
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 0596006411
"Eclipse" is a fast-track approach to mastery of Eclipse. It's a tightly
focused book that examines all aspects of Eclipse: the menus, preferences,
views, perspectives, editors, team, and debugging methods, and how they're
used every day by thousands of developers. Eclipse covers hundreds of
techniques, from the most basic Java development to creating your own
plugin editors for the Eclipse environment. Development of practical
skills is emphasized with dozens of hands-on examples that get down to
business. 
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/eclipse/

Chapter 9, "Web Development," is available free online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/eclipse/chapter/index.html


***Learning Red Hat Enterprise Linux & Fedora, 4th Edition
Publisher: O'Reilly
ISBN: 059600589X
This book provides a clear, no-nonsense introduction to the Red Hat
distribution of Linux. It takes you through installation and shows you the
key parts of the system, always with an eye toward what can go wrong and
what you need to know to get over the humps. New in this edition are
installation instructions and package updating for Red Hat Enterprise
Linux and Fedora, and information on the GRUB bootloader and the CUPS
printer system. 
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/learnredhatentlnx/

Chapter 10, "Connecting to the Internet," is available free online:
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/learnredhatentlnx/chapter/index.html


***WarDriving: Drive, Detect, Defend
Publisher: Syngress
ISBN: 1931836035
This book educates users of wireless networks as well as those who run the
networks about the insecurities associated with wireless networking. This
effort is called WarDriving. In order to successfully WarDrive there are
hardware and software tools required. This book covers those tools, along
with cost estimates and recommendations. Since there are hundreds of
possible configurations that can be used for WarDriving, some of the most
popular are presented to help readers decide what to buy for their own
WarDriving setup. Many of the tools that a WarDriver uses are the same
tools that could be used by an attacker to gain unauthorized access to a
wireless network. Since this is not the goal of a WarDriver, the
methodology that users can use to ethically WarDrive is presented. In
addition, complete coverage of WarDriving applications, such as
NetStumbler, MiniStumbler, and Kismet, are covered.
http://www.oreilly.com/catalog/1931836035/

***Using Excel's Calendar Controls

calculations, charts, or pivot tables based on those dates. Dave and Raina

are entered correctly. They also show how to use an Advanced Calendar
Control to add or subtract days, weeks, or months from within a calendar.

From dmandel at pdxLinux.org  Wed May 12 14:08:02 2004

Subject: [PLUG] Home Networking Annoyances Needed for New Book (fwd)

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Fri, 07 May 2004 15:39:59 -0700
From: Marsee Henon <marsee at oreilly.com>
To: plug at sco302.DavidMandel.com
Subject: Home Networking Annoyances Needed for New Book

Dear User Group Leader:

Once again, I must say thanks for the great response to our previous 
calls for annoyances, gripes, and complaints about Excel, and the Internet,
and other topics. The email we received was useful and gave our
Annoyances books a great head start.

As you might guess, we have yet another book in the wings--this one
focusing on home networking annoyances. Everything from cabling hassles to
setting up a router to wireless access points to fussing with TCP/IP
settings to installing a shared printer. Whether you've set up a wired
(Ethernet, phoneline, or powerline) or wireless (802.11a, b, or g)
network, merely shared a DSL line, or networked a bunch of PCs and Macs,
feel free to share the annoyances you've encountered along the way.

If you or any members of your group have home networking annoyances 
you'd like to see solved, email marsee at oreilly.com with "Home Networking
Annoyances" in the subject line. Please note what hardware, software,
and/or service is giving you grief (e.g.: a LinkSys Cable/DSL Router with
4-Port Switch, SMC's EtherPower II network cards, SBC DSL, Windows XP,
etc.).

As thanks for sharing, we'll make sure to get copies of "Home Networking
Annoyances" sent to your group shortly after publication.


--Marsee



***

An example:

The Annoyance:
I added a new computer to my network, but it doesn't appear in My Network
Places or Network Neighborhood on any of the other computers. The Windows
help files tell you to reboot all the other computers on the network in
order to see the new computer, but there's got to be a better way!

The Fix:
There is. Assuming your hardware connections are working, and you've
created at least one shared resource on the new computer, you don't have
to reboot the rest of the network to see the new computer.

Wait twelve minutes. Honest. Could I make that up? Get a cup of coffee,
empty the dishwasher, or change all the burned out light bulbs in the
house. Then open the network folder again, or press F5 to refresh the
display if you didn't close the folder. You should now see the new
computer.

Why does this happen? The icons in the network folders (My Network Places
and Network Neighborhood) are controlled by a service called the Computer
Browser Service, which browses the network, peers down the pipes
(including the virtual pipes of wireless connections), and checks to see
who's on board. In a peer-to-peer network, the computers elect one of
their own as a browser master using a complicated scheme that involves a
private conversation among the computers (held secretly so you aren't
aware of it and can't control or interfere with it). The browser master
runs the browser service every twelve minutes, and populates the network
folders of all computers on the network with icons representing the
computers it finds.

***

On Wed, 12 May 2004, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:

> >>>>> "Matt" == Matt Alexander <lug at phxlinux.org> writes:
>
> Matt>   There's just something screwy that LWP
> Matt> is doing with the POST that breaks things for certain specific cases...
>
> There's HTTP::Proxy, that can sit in between your post and the
> server.  There's also always "ethereal", which I've used on more
> than one occasion to really see the bits.

Ethereal to the rescue.  Thanks, Randal.
The character '??' needs to be encoded as '%FC' when sent to the server.
If I send the '??' in my LWP POST then it's encoded as '%C3%BC'.
If I instead send the '%FC' in my LWP POST then it's encoded as '%25FC'.
It would be nice if I could somehow turn off any LWP encoding of the POST
altogether.  Maybe this is possible?

So then I added "use utf8" to my script and the POST is encoded correctly,
but it's broken several parts of my script and caused lots of strange
behavior.  Sigh...

Thanks,
~M

It's an idea that was proposed and discounted some time ago. The major problem
is that a large percentage of the spam is relayed through virus-infected
systems, so the spammers still won't pay the cost - the computational effort
will take place on infected home computers, penalizing innocent victims
who would have no clue why their systems are so slow. And it puts an 
unreasonable burden on legitimate servers that happen to process large
volumes of email.

> generally, is it legal to intercept and read an email message, that was

I'm not a lawyer, and definitely am not an ACLU fan, but I read an
article by an ACLU goon a few months ago (which I have since thrown away
when cleaning out old papers) that outlined this.  As I recall, it
stated you are allowed, by law, to view personal emails stored on a
system, but *not* personal emails traveling *through* a system.

Again, IANAL and I really don't remember the whole thing for sure.  But
Google might be able to locate the article for you.

Just a word of warning. There may be state laws that apply beyond what is
allowed or disallowed under Federal law.

There may also be distinctions between mail on your employer's mail 
server vs. on your personal ISP's mail server. Generally employers are less
restricted when it comes to monitoring employee communications compared
to other situations. This again may vary from state to state.

In other words it can get complicated. Ask a lawyer if the answer really
matters.

Terry

>generally, is it legal to intercept and read an email message, that was
>not intended for that person's eyes?

Probably no "reasonable expectation of privacy" if email placed in a 
known unsecure system.  Unlike placing a letter in a sealed envelope in 
the US mail where its a federal crime to intercept or open.  That said, 
if the answer is important enough to bet a few C notes, hire an 
intellectual property guy and get an answer with an insurance policy 
behind it.

The "summary" answers you get here come with no warranty or probability 
of accuracy and are worth about what you pay for them.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu May 13 23:50:03 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Thu May 13 23:50:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPF filtering for smtp severs...
Message-ID: <40A469D9.3090405@robinson-west.com>

Going through Postfix's site after implementing graylisting,
I've run into something referred to as SPF.  Apparently, the
idea is to query DNS TXT records where the valid sending
source for a domain's mail will be listed.  I'm probably
oversimplifying this, but so far this is how I understand it.

The idea then is to look up whether or not the indicated
hostname in a message coming in is in fact one that that
appropriate domain server lists a matching ip address for.

The part about SPF that has me confused is why it requires
the use of SASL or why SASL is being pushed.

How can SPF make it possible to know for sure that any
email message is coming from the source indicated in it's
header?

Is SPF a fully developed approach to shutting down mail
forging, or is it still experimental?

This idea of pressuring anti-spam technologies onto the
Internet, will hobbyist's get sued for noncompliance?  

If someone can patent an idea and sue everyone using
it, what's to stop SPF, or any other technique, from
getting patented and charged for?

As far as denial of service if too many DNS requests
for the TXT records SPF is based on, how much of
a problem could that be?  I get hundreds of junk mail
attempts a day where the domains chosen do seem to
be pulled out of thin air.  The sitenames used probably
have nothing to do with where this mail comes from.

The site of interest is http://spf.pobox.com




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Thu May 13 23:51:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Thu May 13 23:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] ...a new approach for fighting SPAM
Message-ID: <20040514065019.GA12809@gate.kl-ic.com>

Mel Andres writes;
> http://www.discover.com/issues/jun-04/departments/emerging-technology/

Alan writes:
> ...
> The only way to slow down spam is to break the kneecaps of spammers.

The only way to slow down spam is to reduce the economic profitability
of it.  More effective marketing of spam products in other venues
reduces the available customer base.  Incomplete/invalid/fraudulent
transactions against vendors who use spam (and who cannot seek recompense
by legal means) can drive up their cost of sales to unsustainability. 
Focus on the transactions, not on the email.  Cause them to lose their
credit-card merchant accounts.   Anyone want to write a "buy-bot"?  Do
landfills take deliveries?  Or do we just deliver the misrouted goods
to other spammers?

Of course, for the fraud-peddler spammers there is always Mugu baiting
( i.e. http://baita.mugu.co.uk ) and variants.  In some cases, mugus
have been led towards jail or even murdered by crime syndicates, so
this works too.

So, after the spammers, are penniless, ostracised, jailed, or worse,
THEN you can break their kneecaps.

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

This doesn't stop spam, but it could save someone the trouble of reading 
it.

spam.
Given a certain timeout, that message can be discarded.  Alternatively, 
you could
write spam in the body of a reply to a header email and the server could 
parse
that reply using perl, etc.

be on a
whitelist.

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri May 14 13:20:03 2004
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri May 14 13:20:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPF filtering for smtp severs...
In-Reply-To: <40A469D9.3090405@robinson-west.com>
References: <40A469D9.3090405@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <40A529CE.1070501@dimstar.net>

Michael,

Did you miss the L-O-N-G thread on here (what, last month, month 
before??) about SPF records? Most likely, it's archived by now. If 
nothing else, it's probably cataloged by google.

OK, do you NOT get Linux Journal, that had a very informative article 
about SPF records and how to implement them in a two part article in the 
April and May issues?

Either way, rather than asking questions that are answered with simple 
(and I mean simple) searches via google, you should go to google.

I'm NOT trying to talk down to you, or to put you down in any way, shape 
or form.

I'm simply pointing out that many of the questions you ask are already 
answered, and you'd save time and much bandwidth by looking for the 
answer instead of making someone else look for it for you.

Michael Robinson wrote:

> How can SPF make it possible to know for sure that any
> email message is coming from the source indicated in it's
> header?

Well, the truth is, is doesn't. Nothing does with 100 percent accuracy.

BUT, what is the likelihood that someone is going to spoof both the name 
AND ip address of a valid mail server, in spam?

The name is easy. The IP is harder.

> Is SPF a fully developed approach to shutting down mail
> forging, or is it still experimental?

Looked pretty developed to me in the LJ articles. Enough so that 
multiple MTAs support it.

> This idea of pressuring anti-spam technologies onto the
> Internet, will hobbyist's get sued for noncompliance? 
> If someone can patent an idea and sue everyone using
> it, what's to stop SPF, or any other technique, from
> getting patented and charged for?

Not a question anyone here can answer with authority. Ask a patent lawyer.

> As far as denial of service if too many DNS requests
> for the TXT records SPF is based on, how much of
> a problem could that be?

Why would it be any different than anything else? The DNS does one 
query, caches it, and then does another query when the TTL runs out. 
Usually a couple of days or more later.

>   I get hundreds of junk mail
> attempts a day where the domains chosen do seem to
> be pulled out of thin air.  The sitenames used probably
> have nothing to do with where this mail comes from.

Probably. And for those, the SPF record doesn't exist, so it's tagged as 
unknown. The system can't tell if it's forged or not. Only if the domain 
exists, and an SPF record exists can the system say if it believes the 
mail to be spoofed or legit. All other cases default to unknown.

Russ



From shahms at shahms.com  Fri May 14 13:46:02 2004
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Fri May 14 13:46:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] SPF filtering for smtp severs...
In-Reply-To: <40A529CE.1070501@dimstar.net>
References: <40A469D9.3090405@robinson-west.com>
	 <40A529CE.1070501@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1084567542.3400.312.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

> Michael Robinson wrote:
> 
> > How can SPF make it possible to know for sure that any
> > email message is coming from the source indicated in it's
> > header?
> 
> Well, the truth is, is doesn't. Nothing does with 100 percent accuracy.
> 
> BUT, what is the likelihood that someone is going to spoof both the name 
> AND ip address of a valid mail server, in spam?
> 
> The name is easy. The IP is harder.

Much harder, and since the SPF information is stored in the DNS along
with MX and the rest of the domain information, you can do a name <-> IP
check and be reasonably sure that the MTA giving you the mail is one
that is allowed by the SPF header.

> > Is SPF a fully developed approach to shutting down mail
> > forging, or is it still experimental?
> 
> Looked pretty developed to me in the LJ articles. Enough so that 
> multiple MTAs support it.

Depends on what you mean by "fully developed."  There a couple caveats
for using it for your own domains for roaming users and the like, but
it's significantly more reasonable and implementable than competing
proposals.  The only major problem with it is that in order for it to be
effective, it requires large-scale adoption.  But that's a problem for
all of the competing proposals.  Another minor issue is that one of the
biggest spam problems (Hotmail) is owned by a major backer of some of
the more broken (but profitable) proposals.

> > This idea of pressuring anti-spam technologies onto the
> > Internet, will hobbyist's get sued for noncompliance? 
> > If someone can patent an idea and sue everyone using
> > it, what's to stop SPF, or any other technique, from
> > getting patented and charged for?
> 
> Not a question anyone here can answer with authority. Ask a patent lawyer.

Unless there are patents currently pending on the "technology" in SPF,
the answer is "no".  IANAL, but were a patent to be granted it would
have to be applied for by the authors of the technology within 1 year of
publication.  Given that SPF doesn't do anything really new, I'd be
surprised if even the USPTO found it innovative and non-obvious enough
for a patent.  It's basically a "reverse MX record".  Rather than
answering the query "where should I send mail for <domain name>?" it's
answering "where should I accept mail from <domain name>?".

> 
> > As far as denial of service if too many DNS requests
> > for the TXT records SPF is based on, how much of
> > a problem could that be?
> 
> Why would it be any different than anything else? The DNS does one 
> query, caches it, and then does another query when the TTL runs out. 
> Usually a couple of days or more later.

Barring bugs in the DNS server, SPF records are pretty small (the AOL
SPF record is 185 bytes) and shouldn't present any DOS problems.

> 
> >   I get hundreds of junk mail
> > attempts a day where the domains chosen do seem to
> > be pulled out of thin air.  The sitenames used probably
> > have nothing to do with where this mail comes from.
> 
> Probably. And for those, the SPF record doesn't exist, so it's tagged as 
> unknown. The system can't tell if it's forged or not. Only if the domain 
> exists, and an SPF record exists can the system say if it believes the 
> mail to be spoofed or legit. All other cases default to unknown.
> 
> Russ
> 

Yes and it's up to the local configuration what to do with "unknown"
mail, it can be accepted, rejected or "other" where other might be
"increase spam score by 1.5".  Ideally major ISPs and mail hosts will
add SPF records quickly and that alone should curtail the spam problem
significantly, even if you are accepting unknown mail.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

From redhat at crisponions.com  Fri May 14 18:21:02 2004
From: redhat at crisponions.com (Dave Phillips)
Date: Fri May 14 18:21:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] RAID 5 problems...
In-Reply-To: <40A53BDE.1010502@robinson-west.com>
References: <40A53BDE.1010502@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <200405141820.55402.redhat@crisponions.com>

A few things here i can answer.  Yes you do need a spare drive for raid 5.  
For example if you have 5 20gig drives you would end up with an array that is 
80gigs (it uses the extra 20 gigs for parity).  Thats the beauty of raid 5, 
you can lose a drive in the array and be able to replace it and rebuild your 
data.  You also need a minimum of 3 drives to implement it.

I can not give you a knowledgable answer about your bandwidth question, but I 
can let you know I am have a raid 5 array I am running on a compaq card with 
7 drives on it and havent had any problems.

As far as any array goes each "disk" should be a separate drive.  Preferably 
all the same model, but you should try to have them be the same size at 
least.  The size of the raid array will be calculated by the smallest drive.  
If you have a 5 gig, and 2 10 gig disks in an array, it is only going to use 
5 gigs on each of the 10 gig drives (I dont know if you can partition these 
into 2 5gig partitions and use the extra space for something else)

Hope i answered a few of your questions

-Dave Phillips

***Performance Analysis of J2EE Applications Using AOP Techniques 
It's tricky to profile a J2EE application to find performance bottlenecks;
it's even trickier to do this with a production system, without
introducing instability or new slowdowns. Aspect-Oriented Programming
(AOP) offers a means of injecting new code, such as performance metrics,
into existing code, without re-compiling. Ramchandar Krishnamurthy shows
how this can be done.
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2004/05/12/aop.html

***The State of JAXB: Availability, Suitability, Analysis, 
and Architecture
JAXB, now part of Sun's Web Services Developer Pack, offers a means of
converting between Java objects and an XML representation. But is it the
ideal solution? Satya Komatineni investigates what JAXB has to offer. 
http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2004/05/05/jaxb.html

you how to write a simple FTP application in .NET.
