>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com> writes:

Paul> O'Reilly is a for-profit company. No one, from Tim on down, has ever
Paul> been anything less than forthcoming about that. The convention is
Paul> being held at a major hotel, and all the speakers are presumably being
Paul> paid and having their travel expenses covered. O'Reilly has at least

Actually, that's not the case.  With a few exceptions, speakers on the
main tracks are *not* paid, although their conference fee is waived.
Speakers giving tutorial talks (before the general conference) are
paid from the extra money collected by the tuition fees.

However, a conference of this size *is* an expensive operation.
Having been involved in some way with every OSCON (and Perl
conference) from the beginning, I can tell you a lot goes on behind
the scenes to make this all work.  I can also tell you that I've been
told by reliable sources that the conference actually *loses* money
each year, so even at these rates, nobody's laughing all the way to
the bank.  Tim sees the conference as an essential component of being
the world's largest publisher of books about open source software,
and thus as a loss center, not a profit center.

The speakers are not allowed to propose or deliver presentations that
are product oriented, although certainly you'll be more likely to buy
a person's book once you've heard them speak (in theory :-).

On Sat, 2004-05-15 at 18:37, Rich Shepard wrote:

> there any rhyme or reason to selecting a key that will be as secure as any
> other in a very low volume (1 portable, not on all the time) environment?

Do *not* consider WEP secure.  It isn't secure.  It will stop casual
assaults, but nothing sustained.

Most WAPs have some sort of key generating things... there's some
standard turning characters into a key.  In the past I've set my WEP key
to 'pepsi' and 'alina' (there was a Maxim magazine sitting there when I
picked that one, see
http://www.maximonline.com/girls_of_maxim/swimsuit_2004/alina.html).

>   I also have a question about WAP placement. On my computer desk in the
> office I have a bookshelf. If I put the WAP on the top shelf it's surrounded
> on two sides by the particle board side and back. Do I need a box or
> something to raise the antennae above the verticals? The portables will be
> used the den (about 30 feet as the radio waves fly through walls) and,
> possibly, the back yard if it's ever nice enough (but not too light to see
> the LCD screen). My searches on the Web have yielded all sorts of hits but
> nothing pertinent to these two questions.

Try it without raising it... if it doesn't work, try raising it...
AFAIK, the only way to be sure Wifi will work in a location is to test
it out and make sure it does work.

Rob

From drl at drloree.com  Sun May 16 00:15:02 2004
From: drl at drloree.com (Derek Loree)
Date: Sun May 16 00:15:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Dumb question about Linksys wireless card
In-Reply-To: <40A6F333.3020307@comcast.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405151828260.27985@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <1084679845.6262.99.camel@localhost>  <40A6F333.3020307@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1084691672.1124.31.camel@fastlinux.homenet>

On Sat, 2004-05-15 at 21:50, Mike Layne wrote:
> I set up Debian test mode without the pcmcia wireless ethernet adapter 
> in the slot.  How do I get it recognize so I can browse from the living 
> room?

You need to modify /etc/network/interfaces to include the wireless
extensions for the pcmcia card.  Things like:

auto wlan0
iface wlan0 inet static
    address 192.168.100.100
    network 192.168.100.0
    netmask 255.255.255.0
    broadcast 192.168.100.255
    gateway 192.168.100.1
    wireless_mode managed
    wireless_essid mywifinetwork
    wireless_key 2974385d349d38ad15f444cfec
    wireless_channel 7

Change to suit your needs, you should be able to just plug in the
wireless card, and find out what interface name was assigned to it by
looking in /var/log/syslog.

Good Luck,

Derek Loree




From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun May 16 08:51:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun May 16 08:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Random numbers for wireless WEP and others
Message-ID: <20040516155001.GA9739@gate.kl-ic.com>

Regards WEP security:   The purpose of WEP is not to make your system
perfectly secure.  WEP merely makes it more costly to penetrate your
network remotely.  WEP penetration is more expensive than slipping 
your sliding glass door off its rails and copying a hard drive, or
calling your secretary for a little social engineering.  WEP is not 
likely to be the weakest link in your security chain.  That said,
you should be using SSH protocols on your inside ethernet, and over
wireless.  Defense in depth.

WEP at least keeps the traffic down.  A seven tumbler lock is better
than a hook-and-loop, but neither should be confused with a bank vault.

Regards finding a key:  The builtin "generate a random hex string from a
phrase" feature of most WAPs is probably good enough.  As a contrarian,
though, I typically get my random numbers from http://www.random.org .

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

> The portables will be used the den (about 30 feet as the radio waves

> Web have yielded all sorts of hits but nothing pertinent to these two

> Rich

Any reason for not using WPA over WEP? I understand if you have legacy 
issues like OS and/or hardware that doesn't support WPA as we've faced 
that problem in the office with Win2K. New access points and/or 
wireless routers should support WPA in some fashion. WPA supports more 
advanced encryption where new encryption keys are generated after some 
set interval. 

For my own WIFI porting of my home network I use a Linksys WAP54G access 
point with WPA Preshared Key enabled and it supports either TKIP or AES 
encryption with WPA enabled. I used AES encryption and a group key 
renewal of 300 seconds. WPA works fine with WinXP and under Linux I'm 
using the "wpa_supplicant" daemon on my laptop that runs SuSE 9.0. I 
couldn't find the "wpa_supplicant" daemon on the SuSE CDs so I had to 
build it from the source. 

For managing WEP keys under Linux I use the "kwifimanager" program that 
is part of KDE. At some point it would be nice to have a unified 
process for managing both WPA and WEP but so far I have found that I 
need two different pieces of software to do this and I don't really 
have the time for any further experimentation.

WEP scares the heck of me since it is my understanding that good 
cracking programs exist to allow someone to crack a WEP key after the 
program sniffs a sufficient number of packets from a given wireless 
network. This may not be so easy on a small home network with a couple 
of machines that aren't generating millions of packets but say in an 
office that has 20-30 people all using WIFI it wouldn't take long to 
generate millions of packets on the network.

I'm still amazed at how many of my neighbors have WIFI in their home and 
in some cases they have the default SSID "linksys" broadcasting and WEP 
isn't even turned on. Sadly I the vendors are to blame as even the 
Linksys quick start guide recommends just using the defaults so 
everything just works. That's really dumb since it doesn't take into 
account that adjacent houses all may have the of the same AP or router 
broadcasting the same SSID and are all set on the same channel. :-O

I'm sorry as I probably didn't really answer all of your questions since 
I'm pretty limited in my WIFI experience.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405151828260.27985@salmo.appl-ecosys.com> <200405161016.26168.aschlemm@comcast.net> <1084733759.840.7.camel@kokopelli>
Message-ID: <200405161321.10036.aschlemm@comcast.net>

On Sunday 16 May 2004 11:56 am, Brian Beattie wrote:
> On Sun, 2004-05-16 at 13:16, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> > I'm still amazed at how many of my neighbors have WIFI in their
> > home and in some cases they have the default SSID "linksys"
> > broadcasting and WEP isn't even turned on.
>
> I handle this by putting my access point outside my firewall.

I did this to a certain extent but still used WEP when I was stuck with 
a Win2K laptop from work that only supported WEP through WIFI. I added 
a 3rd NIC to my dual-homed firewall. I put my AP on its own subnet and 
used OpenBSD's "authpf" for authenticating a user into the internal 
network from the WIFI subnet. Since all of the WIFI systems I have at 
home now support WPA I've moved the AP back inside as it's easier for 
the less technical users within my household to access my internal 
servers.

I wouldn't ever want a completely open AP on my home network since I 
don't want to have the FBI or other law enforcement officials showing 
up on my doorstep. Someone sitting in a car outside my house or one of 
my neighbors could potentially use my AP to use my internet connection 
to access systems illegally or something if it was completely open. I 
don't think most of my neighbors are that technical and none of them 
strike me as the types as they're all nice people but you never know 
these days. 

In an office that is secured using WEP or even WPA think about how easy 
it is to open up a network so an AP is wide open. All it takes is for 
someone to reset an AP using the button on the back and presto...The 
system goes back to default settings which include broadcasting a SSID, 
and all security settings are disabled. 

I'd like to see an AP that can be reset but still retains certain 
settings like SSID, WEP/WPA so the AP can never to set completely back 
to its factory settings which leave it wide open to anyone with a 
working 802.11 NIC within communication range. From what I've seen the 
consumer type APs that everyone is using do not have this feature and 
most offices I see use the same ones e.g. Linksys, D-Link, Netgear 
modules that people typically use at home.

Tony

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at comcast.net

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon May 17 06:23:02 2004

While helping set up Rich Shepard's Linksys acess point, I was
somewhat astonished to find that the wireless network was essentially
bridged with the inside interfaces (the hub side) of the device.
Essentially (pardon the ASCII art):

  OUTSIDE                   INSIDE

                       ((*))
           +---------+  / \   wireless
           |         |   |
 to        |         +---+
 cable/dsl |         |
     ------+         +---     4 ethernet ports
           |         +---
           |         +---
           |         +---
           |         |
           +---------+

All of the INSIDE, wired and wireless are all on the same subnet,
e.g., 192.168.xxx.0/24.

In my linux-based router at home, my PCI wireless card uses a separate
network for its interface from the other "inside" network.  Do all
WAP's behave like Rich's Linksys?  I kind of like being able to
separate the networks.

Which is why I have a separate firewall and a access point, and not a
wireless DSL/cable router.

My setup

        OUTSIDE                   INSIDE

                       ((*))
           +---------+  / \   wireless access point
           | U1      |   |
 to        | Sparc   +---+
 cable/dsl |         |
     ------+         +---    Inside Interface
           |         +---    DMZ Interface
           |         |
           |         |
           |         |
           +---------+

I have set up my inside interface and my wireless interface to act as
two separate and unreachable (from each other) networks.  That way my
home network is secure and secured from the wireless.  My wireless AP is
completely open and doesn't use WAP, but it is behind a firewall.

From john at meissen.org  Mon May 17 10:25:03 2004
From: john at meissen.org (John Meissen)
Date: Mon May 17 10:25:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WAP networking (learned at clinic)
In-Reply-To: (Your message of Mon, 17 May 2004 06:41:45 PDT.)
             <20040517134145.21243.10394.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> 
Message-ID: <20040517172409.1532673A34@john.meissen.org>

Russell Senior  said:
> While helping set up Rich Shepard's Linksys acess point, I was
> somewhat astonished to find that the wireless network was essentially
> bridged with the inside interfaces (the hub side) of the device. 
....
> Do all WAP's behave like Rich's Linksys? 

The short answer: yes.

The design goal of most access points is to add one or more systems to
the LAN without stringing wires. Most consumers want the systems to be
able to talk to each other for file/printer sharing. Putting them on
different networks makes that a lot more difficult.

However, where you put the access point in your LAN can make a difference.
In your example you showed an AP/router that manages a private network.
If your wired LAN is on a different hub/switch, then hanging the AP off
one of those connectors can essentially put the wireless connections
on a separate network:

  OUTSIDE                   INSIDE

                                         ((*))
           +---------+            +---+   / \   wireless
           |         |            | A |    |
 to        |    r    +------------+ P |----+   192.168.1.0/24
 cable/dsl |    o    |            |   |
     ------+    u    +---   LAN   +---+
           |    t    +---
           |    e    +--- 192.168.0.0/24
           |    r    +---
           |         |
           +---------+

Note that this only works for AP's which act as routers. My WAP-11, for
instance, is just a bridge.

A lot depends on what you're trying to accomplish. Conceptually there's
no difference between the wired/wireless connections to the AP, especially
if most of your connections are wireless.

john-





From keithl at kl-ic.com  Mon May 17 10:47:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Mon May 17 10:47:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WAP networking (learned at clinic)
Message-ID: <20040517174557.GA19366@gate.kl-ic.com>

Russell Senior writes:

> While helping set up Rich Shepard's Linksys acess point, I was
> somewhat astonished to find that the wireless network was essentially
> bridged with the inside interfaces (the hub side) of the device.
> Essentially (pardon the ASCII art):
>
>   OUTSIDE                   INSIDE
>
>                        ((*))
>            +---------+  / \   wireless
>            |         |   |
>  to        |         +---+
>  cable/dsl |         |
>      ------+         +---     4 ethernet ports
>            |         +---
>            |         +---
>            |         +---
>            |         |
>            +---------+
>
> All of the INSIDE, wired and wireless are all on the same subnet,
> e.g., 192.168.xxx.0/24.
>
> In my linux-based router at home, my PCI wireless card uses a separate
> network for its interface from the other "inside" network.  Do all
> WAP's behave like Rich's Linksys?  I kind of like being able to
> separate the networks.

When you think about it, putting things on the same subnet makes 
sense for most users.  They want to reach their printer and their
desktop from their wireless laptop, and probably couldn't handle
writing routing tables, especially if they had multiple switches
and subnets.

The Linksys WAPs and the Siemens Speedstream WAP do it that way.  I
prefer everything on one subnet myself, as I use my server's DHCP to
assign the same persistent ID to my laptop whether it is tethered or
wireless.  I feed my network with a crossover cable into one of the
4 ethernet ports on the back of the WAP, so the WAP ethernet ports,
and the wireless, are both extensions of the internal network.  I
have WEP to keep out the casual interloper, and SSH between machines
to slow down the folks that get through WEP, and Smith&Wesson to take
care of the folks that penetrate my physical security ( a much more
likely risk, IMHO ).

If you want a separate net, you can connect one of the WAP "internal"
ports to a separate E'net port on your server or firewall.  Otherwise,
you can use the cable/dsl port of the WAP to connect to the internal
network and get a different subnet, albeit one that inherits the
internal network's security.  And if you don't like the way THAT
works, buy a WRT54G and install one of the hacked firmware versions
that works the way you prefer, routing tables and all.  As the Perl
folks say, "there's more than one way to do it".

Keith

Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

"I cried because I had no drivers, until I met a man who had no source ..."

I spent part of yesterday helping a young friend try to find a Mac
compatable PCI wireless card.  We ended up mail ordering a WET54G
ethernet-connected bridge.  For PCMCIA cards, we found only Apple,
Asante and Farallon/Proxim cards.  There is another company that sells 
Mac drivers for PRISM cards, $30.  There may be more out there but
we didn't see it.

So as hard as it seems to find Linux drivers in a Windoze world, there
are drivers or development projects for most of the PCMCIA cards out 
there.  The poor Mac folks are having a much harder time of it.

drive? I see two commonly available configurations: 2 MB cache and 8 MB
cache. There really isn't much of a price difference to justify going
with the smaller cache drive, but I'm still curious. My best guess is
that for a system whose data retrieval patterns are relatively
scattered, then the cache might help, but that it would not do much for
a backup or MP3 server.

> How significant of an impact does the cache size have on an IDE hard

> cache. There really isn't much of a price difference to justify going

> that for a system whose data retrieval patterns are relatively
> scattered, then the cache might help, but that it would not do much for
> a backup or MP3 server.

The biggest reason you want the 8mb cache:

2mb cache = 1 year warranty
8mb cache = 3 year warranty

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue May 18 09:24:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue May 18 09:24:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Capabilities of EWRT  was: Re: WAP networking
In-Reply-To: <20040518134115.15268.82373.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040518134115.15268.82373.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040518162226.GA28872@gate.kl-ic.com>

Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com> wrote:
> ...  And if you don't like the way THAT works, buy a WRT54G
> and install one of the hacked firmware versions that works
> the way you prefer, routing tables and all.  As the Perl
> folks say, "there's more than one way to do it".

On Tue, May 18, 2004, Elliott Mitchell <ehem at m5p.com> wrote:
> With the adjusted firmware do you only get filtering between
> inside and outside? Or do you get the ability to do filtering
> and/or routing between all three legs?

See the diagram at  http://docs.sveasoft.com/SV-WRT54GHardware.html
It shows the three ports (eth0 [times 4], eth1 [WAN], eth2 [WIFI] )
that the firmware talks to.  The adjusted firmware can do anything
that Linux can be configured to do, so it is a matter of configuring
route  and  iptables  and so forth.  The EWRT folks 
(  http://www.portless.net/ewrt/ )  serve up a personaltelco captive
portal on the Wifi, redirect information from security cameras, all 
sorts of things.   This is NOT a gui/webpage setup kind of thing,
you have to write the tables, crosscompile, build and flash the code
yourself, but it is apparently not difficult for someone who has done
similar configuration on a regular Linux desktop machine.  And of
course, if you turn off the outside access to the flash, it is much
more secure than a web page configuration would be.

I hope we can have a demo of EWRT configuration at a future Advanced
Topics.

Keith

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue May 18 17:08:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Tue May 18 17:08:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] WAP networking (learned at clinic)
In-Reply-To: <20040517174557.GA19366@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040517174557.GA19366@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <40AAA30B.50804@robinson-west.com>

Keith Lofstrom wrote:

>Russell Senior writes:
>
>  
>
>>While helping set up Rich Shepard's Linksys acess point, I was
>>somewhat astonished to find that the wireless network was essentially
>>bridged with the inside interfaces (the hub side) of the device.
>>Essentially (pardon the ASCII art):
>>
>>  OUTSIDE                   INSIDE
>>
>>                       ((*))
>>           +---------+  / \   wireless
>>           |         |   |
>> to        |         +---+
>> cable/dsl |         |
>>     ------+         +---     4 ethernet ports
>>           |         +---
>>           |         +---
>>           |         +---
>>           |         |
>>           +---------+
>>
>>All of the INSIDE, wired and wireless are all on the same subnet,
>>e.g., 192.168.xxx.0/24.
>>
>>In my linux-based router at home, my PCI wireless card uses a separate
>>network for its interface from the other "inside" network.  Do all
>>WAP's behave like Rich's Linksys?  I kind of like being able to
>>separate the networks.
>>    
>>
>
>When you think about it, putting things on the same subnet makes 
>sense for most users.  They want to reach their printer and their
>desktop from their wireless laptop, and probably couldn't handle
>writing routing tables, especially if they had multiple switches
>and subnets.
>
>  
>
The ISC dhcp implementation has a rerouting package to punch into another
subnet, if your using dhcp with a pool of say 1 ip address you
shouldn't have any illegits hopping on.  If you have to logon to an 
encrypted
web link to transmit with the ip dhcp gives you, that should stop 
illicit traffic
too.  Someones more likely to hop on and attack your laptop as opposed to
your Wireless gateway.

Learning how to route between subnets isn't a bad idea, it offers some
security benefits.  It's easier to route legitimate traffic in than it 
is to block
illegitimate traffic, one should implement both of the firewalling
strategies though.  I can't think of a really good reason to avoid 
putting an
AP on it's own subnet.  If you use samba instead of NT, it shouldn't be too
hard to extend smb shares onto another subnet.  Security wise, do you
need to have an AP Wireless hub transmitting onto the Net?  Do you
want to send any sensitive information over it?  Wireless technology
offers a possibility of community communications on subjects that
aren't security sensitive.

WEP sounds like a waste of time.  SSL tunneling all protocols seems like
a better idea.  What would really be cool would be to replace WEP in the
wireless cards themselves with ssh technology.

    Michael Robinson

On Tue, 18 May 2004, Chris Penwell romanmir-at-comcast.net |PDX Linux|
wrote:

> 	So, how would a (primarily) desktop Linux person go about setting up a
> firewall to allow certain ports to be open during certain parts of the day,
> while allowing other ports to remain open all of the time.

> 	I want to allow the land lord's wife access to the 'net, while severely
> throttling my roommate's excessive kazaa usage. All while maintaining some
> resemblance of household order.

Rather than trying for time-of-day limitations, you could make use of one
or more of the linux Quality of Service packages.  If you're using a linux
box as your firewall this should be pretty easy.

http://www.linuxforum.com/linux-bandwidth-limit/cbq.html

This allows you to limit Kazaa to whatever data rate you'd like while
allowing other protocols to speed ahead.

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Tue May 18 22:48:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)

Subject: [PLUG] Researching Opus's email approach...

Anyone ever heard of IMail?  It apparently works with declude.  I hear 
with IP4R
lists and RHSBL's that there are ways to balance those checks using 
multiple
checks.  I think Postfix with Mailscanner uses declude, but my ISP says
otherwise.  I've been trying to find out more about what they're doing 
just to be
informed ;-)  I've never heard of Imail before.

I like to work on the forging problem myself.  Aside from anti forging 
techniques
and RHSBL's, what is being done to discourage people who write viruses and
spambot's directly?  What is the rate for catching these people and 
intervening
via diplomacy or law enforcement in person?  I'm not saying that any 
spammer
should be brutalized, especially innocent ones.  I wonder if law 
enforcement/high
tech specialists visiting some of the worst spammers to discourage the 
behavior
or clean up infected systems gratis is a necessary part of the spam 
solution.
 
There is enough monetary loss that some business may find economic wisdom
in offers of free assistance to willing parties that need it.  With SPF 
and technologies
like it, knowledge of where spam is coming from increases the 
possibility of someone
carrying out targeted on site visits.  Whether we are there yet or not 
is a curiosity
or mine.  How can we know if this happening and under which standard such
visits will be governed?  What about liability?
  
Everyone could start charging for someone to send them an email, but I know
that a lot of people wouldn't like that.  It also reduces the existence 
of this type
of forum.

A historical note of interest, people used to pay for their paper mail. 
 Jefferson got
upset about the amount of mail he'd get at times because he couldn't 
afford it.  I
wonder if email will change the same way that paper mail has?  Who 
knows, the
U.S. Postal Service may change and take over Internet email in this country
someday.  We are using less paper communication than we did even five years
ago, that suggests that what goes through email systems now must be getting
more critical.

     --  Michael Robinson

Sometimes there are minor errors in a package's install/remove
scripts, which you can repair in /var/lib/dpkg/info/foo.* and then
run:

  # dpkg --configure foo

Always good to feedback any problems to the packages maintainers
(probably already reports by the time you look).

answer questions: is my 250W, etc., power supply big enough,
have the power wires to a drive shorted, and how many watt
hours do these servers use per day.  Briefly: short detection,
load detection, and brownout detection concerning the power
supply's max capacity.

From wcooley at nakedape.cc  Wed May 19 19:32:02 2004
From: wcooley at nakedape.cc (Wil Cooley)
Date: Wed May 19 19:32:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Any cyrus imap/sasl experts among us?
In-Reply-To: <005b01c43e0e$bcebc9d0$6401a8c0@LAPTOP>
References: <005b01c43e0e$bcebc9d0$6401a8c0@LAPTOP>
Message-ID: <1085020301.28950.15.camel@denk.nakedape.priv>

On Wed, 2004-05-19 at 19:04, Sasha Romanosky wrote:
> Fwiw, 
> I had sasl setup for ldap and smtp but dropped it for lack of real
> purpose, or benefit over ssl.

You can't really compare the two; while some of their capabilities
overlap, the combination of the two is usually the easiest and most
effective.  For example, if you're only using SSL protect SMTP relaying,
then you're basically an open relay waiting to happen.  Currently, no
one is exploiting this kind of setup since it's fairly rare, but the
potential for abuse remains.  And if you want to authenticate with Cyrus
IMAP, you haven't any choice but to use SASL, although if you're using
PAM or passwd/shadow authentication, you really need to use SSL also to
protect your login and you protect your data in doing so.

Wil
-- 
Wil Cooley                          mailto:wcooley at nakedape.cc
Naked Ape Consulting                        http://nakedape.cc

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Thu May 20 00:28:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Thu May 20 00:28:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Getting rid of duplications...
Message-ID: <40AC5BBF.60107@robinson-west.com>

I'm trying to find all the mail exchangers for knllc.net so that I can 
upgrade 450 blocks to 550 blocks.  The
attached script is picking up duplicates from a copy of say yesterdays 
maillog created by postfix.

There can be more than one NOQUEUE with mx-unique#-knllc.net.  Whatever 
is sending this junk will forge
different hello names using the same mx-unique#.knllc.net at times.

In an arbitrary text file where the field seperator is a newline, is 
there a quick way to reduce duplicate entries
down to 1?  I could write a C program to take care of this, but that 
seems like overkill.  

Here's a sample of lines that I go after and apply cut to, etc. from the 
postfix log...

 .
 .
 .
May 17 03:17:46 xerxes postfix/smtpd[11010]: connect from 
sb-2-mx-237.knllc.net[66.10.93.237]
May 17 03:17:47 xerxes postfix/smtpd[11010]: NOQUEUE: reject: RCPT from 
sb-2-mx-237.knllc.net[66.10.93.237]:
450 <sb2-ms-issuevulnerable.com>: Helo command rejected: Host not found; 
from=<sonya.h at issuevulnerable.com>
to=<sonya.h at robinson-west.com> proto=ESMTP helo=<sb2-ms-issuevulnerable.com>
May 17 03:17:47 xerxes postfix/smtpd[11010]: disconnect from 
sb-2-mx-237.knllc.net[66.10.93.237]
   .
   .
   .


I grepped this piece.  In reality, I've got SPF and other lines in the 
log.  Let's say instead of
issuevulnerable.com, that the same sb-2-mx-237.* shows up later in the 
log with
sonya.h at looloo.com.  My current script will now have sb-2-mx-237.* at
least twice.  I guess that's what the problem with it is.  

My only other thought is to hard block any site that doesn't pass SPF 
verification.  What
if knllc.net SPF registers looloo.com, issuevulnerable.com, alf.com, 
etc...?  What's to
stop someone from running multiple domain names off a single set of ip's 
so that you
have so many names to block even if you get away from blocking ip's that 
it becomes
absurd to do so?  If they have to buy another name to spam me that does 
cost them
money, but names are so cheap.  I imagine if I learn how to virtual host 
that I can
do at least three or four domains on a single ip.

BTW: I don't have a sonya.h user, though I don't know that that can help 
me here.

Michael Robinson

From alan at clueserver.org  Thu May 20 12:20:04 2004
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)

Subject: [PLUG] knoppix logging

On Thu, 20 May 2004, Michael Rasmussen wrote:

> I'm using knoppix to diagnose a network problem. The object is to have knoppix 
> release and renew a dhcp address then look at the logs to see what server supplied the

From mikeraz at patch.com  Thu May 20 14:37:02 2004
From: mikeraz at patch.com (Michael Rasmussen)
Date: Thu May 20 14:37:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] knoppix logging - dhcp logging
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0405201125350.28615-100000@vir.1100.us>
References: <20040520190248.GB26381@patch.com> <Pine.LNX.4.44.0405201125350.28615-100000@vir.1100.us>
Message-ID: <20040520213649.GA31340@patch.com>

On Thu, May 20, 2004 at 11:27:06AM -0700, alan wrote:
> Look for a program called "dhcpping".  It will tell you where the leases 
> are coming from.

Thanks, that's good
 
> ethereal is also very useful.

Except when you do a release/renew the interface goes down and the capture stops.

I worked around this with 

for i in `seq 1 200`
do
  tcpdump | tee -a dhcp.watch
done
 
> dhcp does not record where it gets the lease from.
> 
> It should, but it does not.

But, it does:

Windows:  ifconfig /all <= will show dhcp server
pump:     pump -i <IFACE> --status | grep "Boot server"
dhcpcd:   logs extensively in /var/log/dhcpcd.log, including IP of DHCP server
		(may require -d option, but that's easy enough)

pump documentation states:
       Pump logs a good deal of information to syslog, much of it at the DEBUG
       level.  If  you're having trouble, it's a good idea to turn up syslog's
       logging level.

which was the basis of my original question.  

`man pump` would have revealed the --status option which would have told me
what I needed to know.

But then I'd still be in the dark about knoppix logging possibilities.

On Thu, 2004-05-20 at 21:56, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On Thu, 20 May 2004, Steve Beattie wrote:
> 
> > Wil, do you want to clarify what you mean here? By ssl, I'm assuming 
> > you're referring to starttls, no?
> 
> I believe Wil was saying that if you have an open relay on port 465, 
> albeit one that demands SSL crypto, that sooner or later the spammers 
> will figure out how to take advantage of it.

Exactly.  If you're requiring a client cert, you're better off than
password authentication, but it's good deal more trouble to manage the
certs than just passwords.

> > I do relaying with postfix based on starttls (check the headers on 
> > this message), but I disbelieve that mail.nxnw.org is ripe for relay 
> > abuse, as it only allows a particular public key to relay through 
> > it, that postfix on the client end uses to authenticate itself. Is 
> > there some flaw in this strategy that I'm overlooking?
> 
> No, that's a pretty good scheme. I use it on my local net, but 
> off-site hosts can only relay using smtp/auth.
> 
> > Granted, I have *no idea* how to get windows clients to present a 
> > tls certificate when doing smtp -- but that's not a problem I have 
> > to solve :-).
> 
> They can use stunnel...

At one point I tried to figure out how to use a cert with Netscape
(pre-Mozilla), but I have never been able to find docs that really
explain SSL/TLS certs very well, so I never figured it out.  When SMTP
AUTH came around I breathed a sigh of relief that I wouldn't have to. 
That said, I *would* like to find good docs that explain the intricacies
of SSL and the myriad of cert formats, ciphers, etc.

Wil

From sandy at herring.org  Fri May 21 09:57:01 2004
From: sandy at herring.org (Sandy Herring)
Date: Fri May 21 09:57:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Var out of space
In-Reply-To: <20040521165012.GA24539@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040521165012.GA24539@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <20040521165654.GA31212@kippered.herring.org>

On Fri, 21 May 2004, Michael Montagne wrote: 
> My /var partition is filled up.  It is keeping mail from getting thru.
> I've cleared some space but df still says 0 space available.  What do
> I need to do to get it back in shape?  It is reiserfs.

Is /var/log filling up as fast as you can clean it? Does `top' show
anything interesting? You can use the following "findbig" Perl script
written by Randal to identify the largest files...


#!/usr/bin/perl
require 'getopts.pl';
require 'find.pl';
&Getopts('n:');
$n = defined $opt_n ? $opt_n : 20;
@ARGV = ($ENV{'HOME'}) unless @ARGV;
&find(@ARGV);
sub wanted {
	$size{$name} = -s _ if not -l and -f _;
}
@sorted = sort { $size{$b} <=> $size{$a} } keys %size;
for (@sorted[0..($n-1)]) {
	printf
	    "%40s, %5dK, last accessed %3d days ago\n",
	    $_ , (-s)/1024, -A _;
}

e.g. `findbig /var'

Sandy

On Fri, 21 May 2004, Michael Montagne wrote:

> My /var partition is filled up.  It is keeping mail from getting thru.
> I've cleared some space but df still says 0 space available.  What do
> I need to do to get it back in shape?  It is reiserfs.

Usually if there's a program writing to a file and you delete the file,
the OS still keeps the file open (and the space used).  So you'll need to
restart whatever program was using the log file.

> Is /var/log filling up as fast as you can clean it? Does `top' show
> anything interesting? You can use the following "findbig" Perl script
> written by Randal to identify the largest files...
> 
> 
> #!/usr/bin/perl
> require 'getopts.pl';
> require 'find.pl';
> &Getopts('n:');
> $n = defined $opt_n ? $opt_n : 20;
> @ARGV = ($ENV{'HOME'}) unless @ARGV;
> &find(@ARGV);
> sub wanted {
> 	$size{$name} = -s _ if not -l and -f _;
> }
> @sorted = sort { $size{$b} <=> $size{$a} } keys %size;
> for (@sorted[0..($n-1)]) {
> 	printf
> 	    "%40s, %5dK, last accessed %3d days ago\n",
> 	    $_ , (-s)/1024, -A _;
> }
> 
> e.g. `findbig /var'
> 
> Sandy

No, it filled up with log files.  I need to watch that closer.  Always
on my day off too.  How does it know?  I just had to wait a bit for my
deletions to register.  I think it is working now.

http://www.themontagnes.com

problems).

So, be forewarned that you are using a *newer* Nvidia chipset on your video 
card,
you may want rethink about using Fedora RC2...

From heinlein at madboa.com  Fri May 21 15:34:02 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri May 21 15:34:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] unison source rpm
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0405211530230.29895@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

I submitted a source rpm for unison to the Fedora project today. 
Unison is sort of a two-way rsync; it negotiates changes between 
directories in two directions, not just one (ala rsync). If you're 
interested, the source rpm is online:

   http://www.madboa.com/geek/downloads/unison-2.9.1-0.fdr.1.src.rpm

To build it, you'll need a local ocaml installation, binary rpms for 
which are available from fedora.us.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From raanders at acm.org  Fri May 21 16:42:02 2004
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Fri May 21 16:42:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Network Analysis
In-Reply-To: <20040521231221.GA1652@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0405211635050.20185-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On Fri, 21 May 2004, Michael Montagne wrote:

> I'm trying to integrate a samba server in a windows 98 peer to peer
> network.  Some machines can't even ping the samba machine and vice
> versa while others can.  Is there a tool or command to scan the subnet
> and tell me which machines I can find so I can start looking for
> similarities?  Is there a better approach?

There is fping (can't remember where to find it) but I'd suggest you power
the whole network down.  Start up the hubs/switches/routers and then the
Samba server.  After they're all running start the windows systems one at 
a time.  I quite often had trouble with Win9x systems on a not-Windows 
only network.  The stupid Windows machines and the MS TCP/IP stack would 
get something in the mind and not let go of it.  ARP tables whatever. And 
just retarting didn't work very often.  It took a complete powerdown.
   If this doesn't help try removing and reinstalling the TCP/IP stack and 
if all else fails the NIC drivers.

Of course the network experts on the list probably have a better solution 
but I usually got so mad I resorted to the bigger hammer technique.


Rod
-- 
    "Open Source Software - You usually get more than you pay for..."
     "Build A Brighter Lamp :: Linux Apache {middleware} PostgreSQL"

On Fri, 2004-05-21 at 15:04, Paul Johnson wrote:
> "Vincent Yau" <v_yau3 at hotmail.com> writes:
> 
> > So, be forewarned that you are using a *newer* Nvidia chipset on
> > your video card, you may want rethink about using Fedora RC2...
> 
> Given that this happens on every distro when you change the kernel,
> this appears to be a problem with nVidia's drivers.  Use a card whose
> open source drivers aren't hindered by the vendor and you won't have
> this problem.

Find me a card reasonably priced that performs comparably to nVidia
cards with open source driver that aren't hindered by the vendor...

nVidia does have good reason for keeping parts of their drivers closed
source.  As such, they must be distributed in binary form, and that 4k
stack option *does* break binary compatibility, apparently... so of
course it's going to break the drivers.  :-)

I do believe it is perhaps a bit irresponsible of RedHat to distribute a
kernel with the 4k option enabled....

Rob

From aaron at ultravolt.net  Fri May 21 17:37:01 2004
From: aaron at ultravolt.net (aaron at ultravolt.net)
Date: Fri May 21 17:37:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Network Analysis
Message-ID: <42562.127.0.0.1.1085186215.squirrel@www.ultravolt.net>

Roderick A. Anderson said:
> On Fri, 21 May 2004, Michael Montagne wrote:
>
>> I'm trying to integrate a samba server in a windows 98 peer to peer
>> network.  Some machines can't even ping the samba machine and vice
>> versa while others can.  Is there a tool or command to scan the subnet
>> and tell me which machines I can find so I can start looking for
>> similarities?  Is there a better approach?
>
> There is fping (can't remember where to find it) but I'd suggest you power
> the whole network down.  Start up the hubs/switches/routers and then the
> Samba server.  After they're all running start the windows systems one at
> a time.  I quite often had trouble with Win9x systems on a not-Windows
> only network.  The stupid Windows machines and the MS TCP/IP stack would
> get something in the mind and not let go of it.  ARP tables whatever. And
> just retarting didn't work very often.  It took a complete powerdown.
>    If this doesn't help try removing and reinstalling the TCP/IP stack and
> if all else fails the NIC drivers.
>
> Of course the network experts on the list probably have a better solution
> but I usually got so mad I resorted to the bigger hammer technique.
>
>
> Rod

I believe the technical reason for this problem is the browse master
configuration in the "Client for Microsoft Networks" service component on
the windows boxes. One of the windows boxes has elected itself browse
master, and the samba netbios daemon is probably not configured to allow
being a slave. The reason powering down all the windows boxes works, is
because then the linux box can make itself master before any windows boxes
can challenge it.

I'm not familiar with Samba enough to know if you can configure browse
master settings. I'm sure you can, and if so, that might be a place to
start as far as resolving your issue.

Aaron

the windows boxes. One of the windows boxes has elected itself browse
master, and the samba netbios daemon is probably not configured to allow
being a slave. The reason powering down all the windows boxes works, is
because then the linux box can make itself master before any windows boxes
can challenge it.

I'm not familiar with Samba enough to know if you can configure browse
master settings. I'm sure you can, and if so, that might be a place to
start as far as resolving your issue.

Aaron

From ehem at m5p.com  Fri May 21 18:04:02 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Fri May 21 18:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora RC2 warning...
In-Reply-To: <20040521231302.26883.60646.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200405220103.i4M139QZ083614@m5p.com>

> From: "Vincent Yau" <v_yau3 at hotmail.com>
> I did 3 installations of it.  The first two works just fine.
> The 3rd one did not.  The Nvidia driver broke (I am using QuattroFX 
> card....)
> The other 2 boxes that worked are using older Nvidia chipsets and they are 
> fine.
> 
> I did a google search and apparently this is a known issue.  And someone 
> reported
> that the *latest* kernel, 2.6.6, works fine.  I am trying to fetch
> the patches but can't get to kernel.org (verio.net seems to be having 
> problems).
> 
> So, be forewarned that you are using a *newer* Nvidia chipset on your video 
> card,
> you may want rethink about using Fedora RC2...

Welcome to Fedora Core 2. As you've noticed, this is a known issue. This
is what happens when you use a highly experimental kernel, things break.
As the feature involved does seem to be the way of the future, it seems
likely that nVidia will take care of this issue very soon, but they
haven't had a driver release since this feature was created (and they're
having to deal with a major new product in the mean time too). This goes
back to Fedora being an _experimental_ distribution, by contrast nVidia's
driver is aimed at the workstation market whom are generally a lot more
conservative about new distributions (guess what, you've got a Quatro
card, they might listen to you!). Until the likely driver update the open
source "nv" driver works or you can build a kernel with the 4K stacks
disabled (apparently a process they've made difficult).

Since we're on the topic of Fedora breakage. You might want to avoid
installing it on dual-boot systems as well. The 2.6 kernel changed how
the kernel reported the partition table information, and Fedora failed to
take the time to get newer versions of the utilities.


--

From plug_0 at robinson-west.com  Sat May 22 07:16:02 2004
From: plug_0 at robinson-west.com (Michael Robinson)
Date: Sat May 22 07:16:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Network Analysis
In-Reply-To: <20040521231221.GA1652@themontagnes.com>
References: <20040521231221.GA1652@themontagnes.com>
Message-ID: <40AF5E5F.5050908@robinson-west.com>

Michael Montagne wrote:

>I'm trying to integrate a samba server in a windows 98 peer to peer
>network.  Some machines can't even ping the samba machine and vice
>versa while others can.  Is there a tool or command to scan the subnet
>and tell me which machines I can find so I can start looking for
>similarities?  Is there a better approach?
>

Go see http://www.openna.com or pick up Securing and Optimizing Redhat Linux
from www.tldp.org.  This book has a good section on samble.

Try tcpdchk.  Make sure nmbd and smbd are running.  Don't string too 
many hubs
together, you'll get unreliable samba performance.  DNS comes first, go to
www.isc.org and set up split dns.  Use netstat -lpt on the samba box to 
make sure
smbd and nmbd are running.  Swat is shunned by many, but as long as you 
have a
good iptables firewall that filters your external interfaces or you run 
samba behind
your firewall, you'll be fine using it.  Remember that everyone has to 
be in the same
domain.  Use security = user and program the 98 boxes to log on to your 
Windows
NT, samba, domain server.  It's properties on Microsoft Network client 
in network
neighborhood.  I strongly recommend going to grc.com and understanding 
Gibson's
recommendations about controlling Windows 98 network bindings so that 
you will
have the fewest possible.  Most common problems are not setting up samba 
to use
encrypted passwords and not being in the right domain.  I believe you 
can connect
multiple domains to the same samba server though by collating browse 
lists with it.
I strongly recommend using samba-2.8 or newer.  

If you can't ping the samba server, is that machine in the same subnet? 
 There are also
sysctl keys that disable ping support.

I'm attaching my working smb.conf.  This is my master smb server that 
Windows 98 logs
into just fine.

     Michael C. Robinson

From griffint at pobox.com  Sat May 22 12:14:02 2004
From: griffint at pobox.com (Terry Griffin)
Date: Sat May 22 12:14:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] tcp/ip networking with g77 fortran?
In-Reply-To: <868yfkxr5o.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <868yfkxr5o.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <200405221213.25465.griffint@pobox.com>

On Saturday 22 May 2004 11:17 am, Russell Senior wrote:
> My fortran writing experience is rather old now, but in the context of
> working with some legacy fortran code (that is actually quite fast
> compiled with g77 -O6), I have been wondering whether it is possible
> (and are there examples available) for making fortran code network
> aware?  That is, I want to know how tractable it is to retrofit an
> interface to load input data over a tcp socket instead of from a file.
> Any clues or pointers?  I am not succeeding in my google query
> attempts.

Not that I would admit to remembering any Fortran, but I think this
ought not to be too difficult. Under the hood g77 uses a library
called libg2c which is really just GNU's name for libf2c. You can
find the source for libf2c here:

   http://www.netlib.org/f2c/

(Scroll down, look for libf2c.zip.) This library is written in C but
callable from Fortran. Following the examples here it should be possible
to write your own Fortran-callable wrappers around any C functions
including BSD socket functions. The tricky bit will be figuring out how
to map a BSD socket descriptor to a Fortran Unit number. File open.c
in libf2c would probably be a good place to start for this.

Another option would to redirect externally. You could have the Fortran
program open a named pipe (which to it is just another file), while some
other program written in C feeds data to the named pipe from a network
socket.

Terry

> >fubar's up nvidia drivers." ...sure enough, I was right.
> >
> >Also, small correction; it isn't a 4K patch, it's a mainline kernel
> >option.  You don't need to remove any patches, just change one quick
> >thing in your .config.  :-)
> 
>    I did uncheck that option in .config but
>   apparently, in the new 2.6.6 kernel, that 4k stack option is permanent

Hmm, the mentions I saw elsewhere didn't overstate the issue. Not only
did they ship a 4K stack kernel, but they deliberatly removed the ability
to revert this from their kernel source RPMs.

They knew:
http://www.redhat.com/archives/fedora-test-list/2004-April/msg01454.html

Best easily findable answer:
http://www.nvnews.net/vbulletin/showthread.php?t=26745


So you can go for vanilla kernel source, otherwise you have to manually
edit the kernel source RPM, and remove the application of the
"linux-2.6.5-nostack.patch" patch. There have been a couple mentions that
CONFIG_REGPARMS *may* also cause problems.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat May 22 18:51:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat May 22 18:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] win4lin?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405221818480.30829@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405221448180.30323@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
	 <20040522233051.GA3895@sulu.pheon.com>
	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405221818480.30829@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1085277010.6478.3.camel@localhost>

On Sat, 2004-05-22 at 18:20, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   Next question: since the vendor supplies a kernel patch that must be
> applied and the system rebooted, can the same patch be applied to new
> kernels when as you apply them?
> 
>   I wonder how this works with the Slackware kernel upgrades since pkgtool
> handles this automatically.

That's a gotcha with Win4Lin... if you aren't using one of the distros
they provide a kernel for, you build your own kernel.  You'll have to
build your own kernel from now on if you use Win4Lin... I personally
enjoy building my own kernels (I can't *stand* letting somebody else
make such intricate choices about *my* system for me), but if you've
never done it before it can be a pain.  :-)

Don't use pkgtool for kernel upgrades any more if you start building
your own kernel.

Rob

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sat May 22 22:09:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sat May 22 22:09:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] win4lin?
Message-ID: <20040523044241.GA6392@gate.kl-ic.com>

I too am using Win4Lin version 4 with Win98 (I feel like I should
be talking about this at Winaholics Anonymous, not here) for a few
legacy applications.  I wouldn't mind using Wine, if I knew for sure
it would handle those legacy apps, but I have other things to do than
re-solve a solved problem.   I would rather wait for open source
replacements for the apps.

But I digress.  Win4Lin allows me to talk to dongled CAD apps, and 
seems to work with IE6 (for those Frontpage sites you would rather
not visit, but must), and most importantly for me, is designed to work
on top of Linux filesystems, with all the security and efficiencies of
that.  That means I can use Win4Lin in one desktop window, and edit
the text files that relate to an application in a Linux xterm window
on another virtual screen.  F##k notepad and dos-oid command windows.
Win4Lin reboots in seconds, which makes the usual windows crashes a
lot easier to live with. 

If I was really ambitious, I would hang all sorts of debuggers and
tracers on the programs running under windoze, and reverse engineer
them.  This would be a good platform for that, and help with porting
those apps to Linux, or designing replacements.

My biggest complaint is that Win4Lin is not compatable with 3 button
mice (which some CAD apps like).  When they finally get that fixed,
I will consider upgrading to a new version past 4.

My other complaint is that the install process kinda sucks, especially
if you need to combine the Win4Lin addons with a non-stock kernel.  You
can theoretically purchase a downloadable version over the web, but in
fact this is a Web-based installer, and you never actually get a CD
image or tar file that you can tinker with.  As a result, *after*
you pay your money, you are confronted with a failed partial download,
without even a clue as to how to back out and try again.   So even
though it costs $10 more, and means waiting for snailmail, you should
get the physical CD version.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

> On Sat, 2004-05-22 at 11:57, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:
> > Hi folks, long time no e-see,

> > For the last 3-4 days my machine is rebooting on its own.  It shuts 
> > down at 6:32-ish and is back up at 6:43-ish.  I've been 
> > troubleshooting this, but I could use some help.  Here's what I've

> 
> I had a system that was spontaneously freezing/rebooting. It turned out

I have a client who had a box in colo that would reboot at about the
same time every day. Turns out that the power cord had gone bad and when
the UPS truck went past the back of the building where his cabinet was,
it would shake the cord enough to disconnect. 

I doubt that your problem is a bad power cord, but I would NEVER have
checked the power cord on my client's colo box. One of the support guys
bumped the cord when plugging a keyboard in (and after plugging in the
monitor on the crash cart) and watched it reboot.

Strange but true.

I also had a SCSI disk that would fail every 44 hours, plus or minus 2
minutes. That might have been a failing capacitor, but it wasn't worth
investigating. I just got a new disk.

--Kurt

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Sun May 23 10:22:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Sun May 23 10:22:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: spontaneous reboots
In-Reply-To: <20040523134145.6237.98538.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <20040523134145.6237.98538.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <20040523165616.GA19639@gate.kl-ic.com>

On Sat, 2004-05-22 at 11:57, Kevin Cosgrove wrote:
> For the last 3-4 days my machine is rebooting on its own.  It shuts 
> down at 6:32-ish and is back up at 6:43-ish.  

I suggest booting from Knoppix about an hour before (up at 5:30? 
horrors!).  If the reboot is due to the hard disk or something on
it, Knoppix will still be running at 7:00.  If it is due to power
or other hardware, Knoppix will reboot, too, though it will not
leave a log of when.  

I'm betting it is something on the hard drive, possibly enemy action,
with a slight chance that it is a temporary disk failure caused by
frisky overuse by some other apps.  If the problem does track the hard
drive, it is time to build a new hard drive from scratch, because you
will never figure out which bits are bad - unless you've been running
tripwire and religiously saving the results.  Easier to do a rebuild,
reload from the distro, then reload apps and data.  The latter may be
copied across directly, since they may be corrupt but are unlikely to
crash the system.

Look at the BIOS and make sure all the suspend options are turned
off.  6:32 may be when the machine is quiet, some time after morning
log manipulations, and the BIOS thinks it can turn itself off.  A
hard drive powerdown may do the same thing.

The easiest way to test a UPS is to unplug it from the wall.  If the
attached computer crashes, the UPS is not doing its job (and there
is somebody on your circuit who is turning on some high power item
at 6:32 or so - Alarm clock->shower->waterheater?).   Note, only the
CPU box should be on the UPS, the monitor should be powered from the
wall;  this could be the monitor getting reactivated and overloading
the UPS.

Good luck.  Oh, for a power line monitor chart recorder ...

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Mon May 24 13:04:02 2004
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Mon May 24 13:04:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Hand-editing postscript files
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405241144001.17544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405241144001.17544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20040524200318.GA8968@bavariati.org>

On Mon, May 24, 2004 at 11:46:36AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Is there a simple way to edit postscript files? Google hasn't revealed any
> to me. There's PsTricks, but that's for graphics within LaTeX.

PS is stack-based (like RPN on an HP calculator), and while the commands
are a bit cryptic, you can generally figure out simple things like the
end-of-page command.  I've hand-edited lots of PS, using gv or GSView to
check my work.

Just ran across this:
http://atrey.karlin.mff.cuni.cz/~mj/papers/psref.txt
But note that most PS generators define their own macros and use those
instead of e.g. "showpage".

PDF is not normally hand-editable, since it's in binary format.  Convert
it to PS, fix it up, then convert back to PDF.

Much luck,
  Aaron

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Mon May 24 13:20:02 2004
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)

Subject: [PLUG] Hand-editing postscript files
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405241144001.17544@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   Is there a simple way to edit postscript files? Google hasn't
Rich> revealed any to me. There's PsTricks, but that's for graphics
Rich> within LaTeX.

Rich>   I downloaded some tabular data from Web pages. I want to strip
Rich> off the last line ("Report problems here") that falls on a
Rich> second page when I convert it to a pdf file. I would also strip
Rich> off the header, too, if I could identify it in the ps code.

Rich>   Any suggestions?

Download the tabular data in some other format than Postscript?

If you are stuck with Postscript, remember that a postscript file is
Just Text(TM).  Use your favorite text editor and go to town.  Of
course, it helps to have an inkling of how Postscript works.  It is a
postfix operator language, like your old HP calculators.  You stuff
things onto the stack and then call a function that eats the stuff on
the stack.  Stuff to be printed literally appears inside parens, e.g.:

  (this is text that is printed) show

where "show" is a function that "paints glyphs representing character
shapes".  You can tweek text inside the parens, but alignment is often
controlled externally, so it might mess up things.  If you are just
getting rid of text, that might not cause you so much difficulty.

The pagination problem might be more complex.  You can't just reflow
things in Postscript, that is the responsibility of something
upstream.  You may or may not be able to patch things up tractably in
the Postscript.

For full details, see Adobe's canonical _Postscript Language
Reference, 3ed_, Addison Wesley.  I think it is even online somewhere
these days.  Ah, yeah:

  <http://partners.adobe.com/asn/developer/pdfs/tn/PLRM.pdf>

Good luck.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I have nine fingers; you have ten.''
seniorr at aracnet.com

$0.02 Alert

I think Scribus (http://www.scribus.net/) will import PS files and allow
you to edit them within reason.

There have been a couple of replies indicating that is is just text.  
Well it is usually, if you're lucky.  I have seen and had to give up
dealing with several PS files because the micro-spacing commands made
finding the text impossible (pre/early linux times and all the nifty
utilites that have come out of the Open Source movement.)

A quick look at the Scribus documentation turned up a mention of 
the pstoedit utility.  That might make editing easier.

From ehem at m5p.com  Mon May 24 21:53:01 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Mon May 24 21:53:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: spontaneous reboots
In-Reply-To: <20040525035401.19709.90323.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

It doesn't require power problems to uncover a bad UPS battery. The
consistant reboot time could be caused by the UPS doing a battery
discharge test. If the battery is in really bad shape the UPS woule be
unable to switch back to AC power quickly enough and everything connected
dies briefly.

You said you didn't think it was a power problem, but you didn't say you
know the battery is good. How old is the battery (or batteries)?

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue May 25 10:21:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue May 25 10:21:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Accessing WAP
Message-ID: <20040525165629.GA5826@gate.kl-ic.com>

Rich writes:
>
>   At the clinic a couple of weeks ago, Kurt and Russell helped me configure
> the LinkSys/Cisco WAP. We gave it the static IP address of 192.168.55.200. I
> now have this unit patched to one of the ethernet switches and I've tried to
> access it so I can add the WEP code.
>
>   Mozilla tells me that it cannot connect to http://192.168.55.200. When I
> try the default IP address, 192.168.1.1, mozilla hangs until it times out. I
> also tried as root, but that didn't work either.
>
>   I must be doing something wrong that's so simple I cannot see it. Can
> someone let me know what step I've missed?

If all else fails, you can always reset the WAP and set it up again.
This may be required if you made WAP changes that you didn't write down.

I will assume you have either the recommended WRT54G or BEFW11S4.  These
units are nearly identical for routing configuration.  It is easiest to
do all this with a single straight-through ethernet cable from your
setup machine to one of the WAP's 4 LAN connections.  I will refer to
the setup machine as SETUP.

Unless you made changes to the contrary, you can only access the Linksys
WAP from the LAN side, not the WAN side.  That means the router will
only talk configuration to addresses it believes are on the subnet
it controls.  If you set up the Linksys with 192.168.55.200 as a
configuration address, then it must also be configured so that
192.168.55.xx is part of the internal address space.  Also, SETUP
should be configured to route 192.168.55.xx to the ethernet connection
that is wired to the WAP.   The output of /sbin/route from SETUP would
be handy for debugging this.

You can test the connection with a PING to 192.168.55.200 .  If you 
get "no route to host" from SETUP, then you are not routing on SETUP
correctly.  If you get no response to the ping, then the WAP is on
a different address than you thought.  If you get a response to ping,
but no configuration web page, I suggest you try browsing to
http://192.168.55.200:8080 , which is an alternative port for the
configuration web page, and may have gotten enabled when you were
setting something else on that page.

If you decide to reset the WAP, write down what you do.  I can write
up the details of setting up the WAP from scratch, but I do not have
time now.

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Tue May 25 10:57:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Tue May 25 10:57:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: spontaneous reboots
Message-ID: <20040525173209.GA6127@gate.kl-ic.com>

Keith Lofstrom writes:
 > The easiest way to test a UPS is to unplug it from the wall.  If the

Rogan Creswick responds:
> ....but not the safest (although, I am no expert in this area--the
> degree of safety increase may be minimal.. any insights from others
> who know more?).  Flipping the breaker for that circuit, plugging it
> into a wall outlet which is activated/deactivated by a wall switch, or
> putting a (high quality)powerstrip with an activation switch between
> the ups and the wall _should_ keep the ground connected during your
> experiment. (obviously there are powerstrips with out ground pins, and
> etc...).

Not true.  After all, you have to unplug the UPS to put the switch
in between, yes?  While I would not suggest hanging onto bare metal
on your computer while fiddling with the power cord, the computer is
grounded through the peripheral connections (which we are told are
not connected through the UPS).  The most unsafe part of the unplug
is what it might do software-wise, if the machine is poorly configured
and the UPS is in fact faulty.  And that can be remedied by doing
the unplug test while the machine is looking at the GRUB splash
screen, or some other unmounted condition.  

This crude test of the UPS tells us whether the problem is power side
or computer side.  Testing with Knoppix (if you can't boot from CD,
boot from a different distro on a swapped hard drive) tells us whether
the problem is hardware, or disk/software.   The point of all this is
isolating the fault to one segment of the problem space.  Without that,
we can speculate forever and come up with thousands of plausible fault
scenarios.  Speculation ends when empirical data collection begins.

Given the response to a reboot, and the response to alternate disk/software
we can make more intelligent suggestions for further testing.  Until
there is more data, the problem space is too large.  Debugging is 
intelligent data collection.  I have plenty more tests to suggest after
knowing the results of the UPS and the alternate software tests.


Keith 
(bonafides: MSEE, 1972, author of early Usenet FAQs on power
supply repair).

time.  Can I create an ethernet bridge with something like an old 386
 to detect any unusual traffic including alien protocols, etc, coming
off of my servers?  It may be that people who have been trying to send
me spam are retaliating against my recent anti spam upgrades.  I've
implemented SPF checking and greylisting.  I've also limited the
valid email addresses at my site that Internet clients can send to.  
Whoever sent this ebay thing sent it to an alias that I use for ebay
mail.

As far as reporting spam, how can you if the addresses in an email are
so easily forged?  If everyone uses SPF and SPF records can be
trusted, forged mail will be no more.  This list doesn't even use SPF
though.  It takes about five minutes to implement the necessary dns
TXT record.

The Ebay message claimed that I have been suspended, probably just
a ploy though.  Are hoaxes in general getting to be more convincing?

     --  Michael Robinson

Rod,

I too use putty to access my servers and the color comes up.  As much
as I like the color to quickly identify files.  Nice to see what is
executible.  The folder color and others by default have been a
challenge.  I have found that if I just change the hue of the blue in
Putty for that one connection then it is fine.  My problem has been
with ANSI Blue.  I just make it brighter.

Go into teh Window - Color section of Putty and change them.  You can
either set it while in that section by  clicking on the left upper
window bar and chossing 'change Settings' or you can do it permanently
by loading the save session and changing it in the options to the
left.

I fought with the color mappings on linux for many different
connections including telnet(windows and *inx), exceed, and putty.  I
just found changing the client to be easier and faster.

From ehem at m5p.com  Tue May 25 13:04:01 2004
From: ehem at m5p.com (Elliott Mitchell)
Date: Tue May 25 13:04:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: spontaneous reboots
In-Reply-To: <20040525190503.2675.15431.Mailman@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <200405252003.i4PK3NBa051395@m5p.com>

> From: Kevin Cosgrove <kevinc at doink.com>
> On 24 May 2004 at 21:51, Elliott Mitchell <ehem at m5p.com> wrote:
> > You said you didn't think it was a power problem, but you
> > didn't say you know the battery is good. How old is the battery
> > (or batteries)?
> 
> Maybe I was a bit too strong in my "don't think it's a problem".
> I did put UPS testing on my list of things to try.  This UPS is 8
> years old, as is its battery -- seems kinda old to me.  I have 2
> other UPSes if I need them.

Just a little old for a UPS battery. 8 years old for a UPS battery is
ancient. Figure UPS batteries should be replaced about every 5 years or
so. Nice thing is that smart UPSes will tell you the battery needs to be
replaced, rather than having a dumb one die during a short outage, of
course then you have to heed its warning.


> From: Keith Lofstrom <keithl at kl-ic.com>
> 
> Keith Lofstrom writes:
>  > The easiest way to test a UPS is to unplug it from the wall.  If the
> 
> Rogan Creswick responds:
> > ....but not the safest (although, I am no expert in this area--the
> > degree of safety increase may be minimal.. any insights from others
> > who know more?).  Flipping the breaker for that circuit, plugging it
> > into a wall outlet which is activated/deactivated by a wall switch, or
> > putting a (high quality)powerstrip with an activation switch between
> > the ups and the wall _should_ keep the ground connected during your
> > experiment. (obviously there are powerstrips with out ground pins, and
> > etc...).

I'd also like to point out that a battery can't produce nearly the
current a wall outlet can. As the source of that energy is inside the
UPS, the UPS is more than capable of grounding all the power coming out
of it. You'll lose the ground you'd want to use for ESD, but you
shouldn't be unsafe.

From srau at rauhaus.org  Tue May 25 13:24:01 2004
From: srau at rauhaus.org (Stafford A. Rau)
Date: Tue May 25 13:24:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Implementing only whitelisted allowed to stop spammers...
In-Reply-To: <40B199A6.1090303@robinson-west.com>
References: <200403100727.i2A7RgHq010046@m5p.com> <40B199A6.1090303@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <20040525202351.GA10306@rauhaus.org>

* Michael Robinson <plug_0 at robinson-west.com> [040525 11:39]:
> I've gotten what looks like a fraud email from E-Bay tonight.

Ok.

> This is the second really strange email that I've gotten in so
> many days.  The first one was I'm some woman in St. Petersburg
> Russia interested in doing web developement for your site.
> Now this one.  Both of these strange emails appear to be blatant
> attempts at social engineering, saying the right thing at the right
> time to get information from me.  I forwarded the Russian one to
> my ISP, they thought it was very clever.  What uses a .eml
> file anyways?

A couple seconds to Google "eml" and "suffix" suggests this might be
related to Outlook Express. Google is a pretty good tool. Have you tried
it?

>Is that really plain text?

Maybe. What are the contents?

> Airplanes have a black box.  This is the second red flag that something
> might be wrong which has come up in a very short time period of
> time.  Can I create an ethernet bridge with something like an old 386
> to detect any unusual traffic including alien protocols, etc, coming
> off of my servers?

Sure, but odds are you won't be able to distinguish unusual traffic from
legitimate traffic without a bit of work. What do you mean by "alien
protocols"? Do you mean non-IP traffic, like PIM or AH or OSPF or GRE or
anything else in /etc/protocols that isn't part of the TCP/IP suite?

Or do you just mean "bad stuff", whether it's ip or not? 

> It may be that people who have been trying to send me spam are
> retaliating against my recent anti spam upgrades.

Pretty unlikely. It's not all about you.

It's about your email address finding its way into a list that contains
a few million other addresses, and that list gets sold from spammer to
spammer, all with the forlorn hope that 0.01% of the recipients will
actually think it's a fine idea to buy their drugs or pr0n or hot stock
tips or mortgage refi's from someone who advertises via spam.

> As far as reporting spam, how can you if the addresses in an email are
> so easily forged? 

If you really don't have better things to do with your time, then you
could look at the received lines, see whose ip address is in the last
"Received from:" line before your own systems, do a whois on that ip,
and send your complaints there.

Chances are it's going to be a compromised Windows system on cable or
dsl, and the owners have no clue that their peecee is being used to
relay spam.

I'd rather spend that time working my dog in agility, flyball, and
herding. Or spending time in the garden. Or helping my daughter with her
homework. Or about a zillion other things.

> The Ebay message claimed that I have been suspended, probably just
> a ploy though.  Are hoaxes in general getting to be more convincing?

That is pretty much a function of your own skill at critical thinking
and skepticism.

--Stafford

"

I was getting what looked to be targeted spam.  I suppose someone may
have chosen a user name out of thin air that made it look targeted.  I
use ebay quite a bit, it must have been harvested off of there.  Do
people actually get paid money after they sell you something on E-Bay
to provide your email address to spammers?  E-Bay could fix this
problem by having an address they control show up to the seller
anonymously forwarding messages to the buyer.  This way, E-Bay
sellers would get an E-Bay address instead of mine.  

I for one think there's nothing wrong with trying to get a question
answered locally instead of going to google all the time.  There was a
time when the thought of regional linux help centers was seen as
an ideal.  Anymore, I fear that google has wiped out the idea of
getting questions answered through such regional centers.  As far
as using google all the time, I see great value in a question answered
locally.  It doesn't matter if google knows, what matters is what you
and I now.

"
It's about your email address finding its way into a list that contains
a few million other addresses, and that list gets sold from spammer to
spammer, all with the forlorn hope that 0.01% of the recipients will
actually think it's a fine idea to buy their drugs or pr0n or hot stock
tips or mortgage refi's from someone who advertises via spam.
"

So it doesn't matter where it comes from or who sent it.  The fingers
of the buyers of those lists along with the fingers of the sellers of those
lists need to be broken!  Course I'm not serious, but there should be a
way to proactively get out of other people's databases and enforced
laws regulating the collection of statistics about what disinterested
parties are doing.

Aside from this...

What bothers me more than spam is how electronic transfer works.  You
don't have to provide a code for paypal to write an  e-check against your
account.  My bank won't offer me a way to explicitly sign these transfer
requests either.  Paypal bounced my account three times when  I
accidentally set the payment method to check instead of credit.  At $22 a
bounce, that really hurt.  I've attempted to set the default to credit, but
paypal puts me on a page that essentially dicourages that and puts the
primary payment method back to check.  Add to that that some auctions
require direct transfer, taking the checking account off of paypal isn't so
easy.  I put it on when a seller required me to verify and it has been a
nightmere ever since.  I wonder if any banks are better about this than
Washington Mutual is?  It's harder for me to walk in to a branch and
withdraw funds than it is for someone to go after those funds 
electronically.  
That is just wrong.

I use Ebay because I'm after hard to find items including: 32 pin simms and
DIMMS from the pc100 and pc133 days.

From aaron at speakeasy.org  Tue May 25 15:15:02 2004
From: aaron at speakeasy.org (Aaron Burt)
Date: Tue May 25 15:15:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] !@#$% Color in PuTTY terminals
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0405251201001.12075-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0405251201001.12075-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <20040525221402.GA14466@bavariati.org>

On Tue, May 25, 2004 at 12:05:56PM -0700, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:
> I'm stuck at work with a WinXP system and use PuTTY to get to the servers
> I admin and develop on.
> 
> The problem is the damn colorization of everything.  ls, ll, vi, emacs,
> ... is driving me crazy.  Is there a simple way to shut off colorization
> for all applications?  I've looked at the files in /etc/profile.d but the
> colorization made them nearly impossible to read and discover if there was
> a single file/setting solution.

I was pleasantly surprised at how well PuTTY emulated an xterm when
accessing a Linux system, color and all.  But if you don't like it,
there should be a setting for terminal type or answerback.  Change it
from 'xterm' to a terminal that doesn't support color, such as 'vt220'
or 'vt102'.  You can even play with it from a terminal session with e.g.
"export TERM=vt220".

Good luck,
  Aaron

> Has anyone else had trouble with aggressive CFLAGS and gentoo?  What are 
> working CFLAGS settings for the initial install?

Way back when I first gave Gentoo a try, I think I did have a few
problems with overly aggressive C[XX]FLAGS causing unstable binaries.

After doing a little bit of research on how much the CFLAGS really did
for me, though, I toned things down considerably and have found the
system is generally in better shape with everything running nice and
stable like.  :-)

Most ebuilds that will have problems with common CFLAGS filter them out
these days (they didn't back when I was getting started).

cannot dictate passive behavior.  If I were to stand outside your house
with a banner depicting "certain acts" (whatever those may be) and you
were to look out the window, would you consider that a failure to adhere
to values?

Furthermore, how are you to learn about others' acts, behavior and
motivation, without observation?  It seems that ignorance would only
re-enforce social ailments for lack of open dialog to diagnose flaws or
objectively interpret scenarios.

> Too many liberals dominate the public ear and have gained power because
> noone wants to balance them with the alternative, life lived based on
> sound value systems.

See, that's more of that muddle-headedness that sometimes comes out in
your attempts to diagnose technical problems.  There are such a thing as
"liberal ideals" and "progressive values".  Many of those systems are quit
sound, mature, healthy, and rewarding.  But because the fundamental
defining characteristic of "liberals" is that they are simply NOT
conservative.  There's really only one way to be conservative -- to adhere
to the shared mythology of some ideal of ignorance and repression (for
what else could "conservative" mean if not going backward in learning and
what could an opposition to "liberalism" mean if not being for more
repression?), but there are an infinite number of ways to NOT be that one
way.  Perhaps it's difficult for the conservative mind to grasp the idea
of infinite choice -- that ideals can be chosen rationally (or randomly!)
from the infinite possibilities of reality and not merely be handed down,
whole and unquestionable, by the Authorities of the previous generation.
But that's how it is.  There is no one set of "liberal values", but
liberalism does not imply a lack of values.

J.
--

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net
   -----------------

 http://www.openlaw.org

From shahms at shahms.com  Tue May 25 16:13:15 2004
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: Tue May 25 16:13:15 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Anyone ever crack a Vaio laptop case?
