References: <40B38D5C.4090404@robinson-west.com>
	 <1085523780.7011.50.camel@localhost>  <40B3D0A5.6010307@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1085526734.23547.273.camel@shahms.mesd.k12.or.us>

On Tue, 2004-05-25 at 16:03, Ken Benderly wrote:
> The hard drive in my Sony Vaio pcg-505tr crashed hard.  I tried cracking 
> the case, but I can't separate the hinge assembly from the lower half. 
> This prevents me from accessing the guts and the hard drive.  Useful 
> tips would be greatly appreciated.
> 
> Ken

Yeah, I've done it a number of times on my (other) PCG-68P.  I ran into
a similar problem where, after I'd take out every single screw I could
find, I still couldn't get it open.  The culprit turned out to be a
rather cantankerous sticker on the inside of the case, undoubtedly there
to prevent you from pretending you didn't just void your warranty ;-P 
However, cracking the case wasn't necessary  on my laptop as there was a
somewhat hidden hard-drive access panel on the bottom.  Not sure if
you're in the same boat, but poke around for a while and make sure
you've removed every single screw, there are undoubtedly a number of
hidden ones.  Often times innocent looking rubber feet will actually
hide screws.  Occasionally there will be one under a sticker (but
usually not and you can typically tell without removing the sticker). 
Of course, YMMV.

Basically, Sony goes to a lot of trouble to keep you out, and for good
reason.  In my experience there is usually an easier way of accessing
both the hard drive and memory that actually opening up the entire case.
-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

The colorization is meant to help you distinguish different parts of the 
text
from each other logically.  Blue when looking at your filesystem for
example means directory.  I think that only vim is colorized in Redhat,
you should be able to use vi instead and get black and white.  The other
trick that may work is changing your ls alias and .vim.* file.  I can't
remember what vim's initialization file is called exactly.

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Tue May 25 20:10:03 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Tue May 25 20:10:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Problem with my new gentoo system...
In-Reply-To: <40B3FDAA.50200@robinson-west.com>
References: <40B38D5C.4090404@robinson-west.com>
	 <1085523780.7011.50.camel@localhost>  <40B3FDAA.50200@robinson-west.com>
Message-ID: <1085540982.7010.82.camel@localhost>

On Tue, 2004-05-25 at 19:15, Michael Robinson wrote:

> Stage one.  I'm trying doing nothing to the CFLAGS.  386 settings should 
> work.
> There has to be a way to tune it up later, or maybe it won't be that big 
> a deal.

I would at the very least set -O2 and -march, then -msse, sse2, whatever
is appropriate for your CPU.  -fomit-frame-pointer is usually safe.  If
your system has SSE support, setting -mfpmath=sse should result in
faster binaries.

All of those should be safe for most every package.  Anything it won't
be safe for will filter it out in the ebuild.

And as to tuning it up later... sure you can, you just recompile
everything.  Guess how long that takes......

Rob

From: bsr at spek.org (Brent Rieck)
Date: Tue May 25 20:54:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Anyone ever crack a Vaio laptop case?
In-Reply-To: <40B3D0A5.6010307@comcast.net>
References: <40B38D5C.4090404@robinson-west.com> <1085523780.7011.50.camel@localhost> <40B3D0A5.6010307@comcast.net>
Message-ID: <40B4149C.4030707@spek.org>

Ken Benderly wrote:
> The hard drive in my Sony Vaio pcg-505tr crashed hard.  I tried cracking 
> the case, but I can't separate the hinge assembly from the lower half. 
> This prevents me from accessing the guts and the hard drive.  Useful 
> tips would be greatly appreciated.

I've not taken apart a 505tr but I've taken apart my z505hs to replace 
the HD using this guys documentation of it:
   http://modular.fas.harvard.edu/z505he/apart/

It wasn't very difficult and if your case is similar to mine it 
shouldn't take you less than 30 minutes to open it, replace the HD and 
close it if you've never done it before.  A bonus is that nothing on my 
sony's case was "snapped" together in a way that you'd break off a 
crucial-yet-extremely-fragile tab while taking it apart or putting it 
back together.

This page links to several other laptop disassembly pages for other sony 
models that might be more similar to your laptop than a z505:
   http://www.tuxmobil.com/disassembly_laptop.html

--Brent

On Tue, 2004-05-25 at 16:12, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On Tue, 25 May 2004, AthlonRob wrote:
> > I was bragging of my 180 day uptimes (three in a row) to a friend who
> > works for a university in Germany.  He proceeded to show me his SGI box
> > with an 850 day uptime....
> 
> Uh... what kernel was that thing running?  uptime is tracked not by some
> subtraction of datestamps, but by adding the current date to the number of
> ticks since the system started.
> 
> I guess if the system was REALLY slow, there might be fewer than 32K ticks
> in 850+ days.  But at 100hz, 32K ticks is something like 500 days.
> 
> Someone correct me if I'm wrong.

You are wrong.

All time is kept that way internally.  System speed has nothing to do
with the uptime numbers.  (Expect in cases where the number rolls over
due to being in a too small numeric type.  And it has happened...)

If they have not rebooted in 850 days, then they have a whole bunch of
security issues to deal with.

From heinlein at madboa.com  Wed May 26 09:39:01 2004
From: heinlein at madboa.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed May 26 09:39:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Fedora Core 2 (?)
In-Reply-To: <34070.209.210.31.8.1085587389.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0405251104001.11554-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
        <1085524871.7017.53.camel@localhost>       
 <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405251607251.25987@shaft.bitmine.net>       
 <1085547416.14267.23.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>
 <34070.209.210.31.8.1085587389.squirrel@webmail.woo-hoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.60.0405260922470.31468@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 26 May 2004, Steven Raymond wrote:

> Someone was telling me that Solaris can have kernel updates without 
> rebooting.  Is that fact true, and does Linux have any similar 
> capability?

Sure, if the update is to a module. Just "modprobe -r" the module, put 
the update in place, and modprobe the new one.

Of course, if the updated module is for your root filesystem (e.g., 
ext3) or your main drive subsystem (scsi_mod or its descendants), then 
an update in place will be somewhat difficult. :-/

To me, uptime isn't all that meaningful a figure as long as the number 
and frequency of the downtimes remain reasonable. Unplanned and 
too-frequent downtimes are the real buggers.

-- Paul Heinlein <heinlein at madboa.com>

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Wed May 26 10:14:01 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Wed May 26 10:14:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] old tape formats
Message-ID: <20040526171324.GA2771@gate.kl-ic.com>

I have some 12 year old tape images made by Novaback, a backup program
for DOS and Windoze.  The bits are intact, but the original tapes,
drives, machines, and software that made these images are long gone.
(Some years ago, I dd'ed the ancient DC300 tapes onto newer media, and
have images for those that did not erupt in brown vapor).

Now I want to get at a file I made in 1992.  While I have the Novaback
image, as bits, I don't have a program to take it apart.  I imagine I
could decode the backup file format and eventually write a program to
extract the file, but perhaps somebody in the world has already done this.

Any suggestions where to look for programs, or just the tape format?

Keith

----
BTW, I have done this with other, even older tape formats.  It is a
fun puzzle to solve, but it is time consuming and I don't have the
time right now.  I can still read old DUMP and TAR images from the
same era, so this is another reason why open source and open standards
are superior to proprietary standards. 

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs



From kevinc at doink.com  Wed May 26 10:42:02 2004

In-Reply-To: <20040522185757.A811D406A@joseph.doink.com>

I let my problem child computer run overnight after booting from
a tomsrtbt floppy.  It rebooted just as before, which I believe
tends to indicate that my installed OS and disk drives are not
likely the culprit to the reboots.  Then while sitting at the
computer my house experienced a brief power hit, not even long
enough to reset the microwave clock.  But the UPS barfed and the
computer shut down.  Just a couple months ago this didn't happen.
The UPS I have is old enough, as is the monitoring software, that
I didn't get any software warning of a low battery condition.  I
thought to check the turn-on time of my programmable thermostat.
It's set for 2 minutes before reboot time.  I'm in a sea of
circumstantial evidence!

I'll be replacing my UPS.  It turns out that APC has a trade-up
program, and I can trade in all 3 (different brands) of my weak
UPSs for new APC units.  They pay for shipment of the old ones
back to them, and I pay for shipment of the new units to me.

Thanks for the help folks.....

On Tuesday, June 8, Richard M. Stallman, founder of the GNU Project and
Free Software Foundation, will give a speech in Lincoln Performance Hall
at Portland State University: "The Free Software Movement and the
GNU/Linux Operating System."  He will discuss the purpose, goals,
philosophy, methods, status, and future prospects of the GNU operating
system, which in combination with the kernel Linux is now used by an
estimated 17 to 20 million users world wide.  There will be a
question-and-answer session afterwards.  The event begins at 7:00 PM,
and will last approximately three hours.  Lincoln Hall is located on the
Portland State University Campus in Portland at the corner of Broadway
and Market Streets.

>>>>> "Chris" == Chris Jantzen <chris at maybe.net> writes:

Chris> I don't envy your quest to get that modem to work. However, you
Chris> might try "literal pasv" at the DOS FTP prompt to force passive
Chris> mode, which doesn't attempt alternate callback connections or
Chris> such.

Chris> Although that may be asking for trouble. Use a cygwin CLI FTP
Chris> client instead?

Thanks for the suggestions!

I remembered and tried "macof" from the dsniff toolkit, which is
supposed to blow the switches ARP table and push it into hub mode.  It
didn't seem to work.  I hammered the switch, but never saw the ftp
traffic from my linux box.

The other idea I had was to put ethereal on a w2k box and run the DOS
FTP client from there (but I am not onsite at the moment).  The
ActionTech actually does the right kind of connection tracking.  I can
run (linux netkit) ftp in normal (non-passive) from the linux box to
aracnet.com through the ActionTech and it works fine.  I switch to
passive mode and that works too.  When he tries connecting to his
host, it doesn't work with DOS FTP, but does work with WSFTP (but that
is undesirable for other reasons).

The DOS FTP program doesn't have a passive mode option.  The "literal
pasv" thing is something to try though.

Cygwin is probably too invasive a workaround in this case.

Thanks!

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Wed May 26 22:12:01 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Wed May 26 22:12:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] IM Servers
In-Reply-To: <20040527042753.GJ27571@maybe.net>
References: <1085631312.7075.13.camel@localhost>
	 <20040527042753.GJ27571@maybe.net>
Message-ID: <1085634684.7069.23.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2004-05-26 at 21:27, Chris Jantzen wrote:

> Could you elaborate for the list what exactly you mean? Selected
> preset groups of people you can broadcast a message to at a whim?
> I.e., a sort of "mailing list" for IM?
> 
> Certainly clients can already do this, but I imagine you don't want to
> set up the same groups in clients a dozen times, eh?

I'm sorry, it's been a LONG last couple of days.  :-)

The 'shared roster' or 'shared group' or 'predefined group' works like
this...

Everybody in group A subscribes to the Group A group.  Now they're on
that list and that list is in their contact list.  Now to set up their
contact list, they just subscribe to the proper group and it's done,
they don't have to subscribe to each individual person.

An example might be if Jabber.org had a PLUG group.  We could all
subscribe to the PLUG group instead of everybody emailing everybody
their JIDs... and we'd all be on each others' group rosters.

Jabber 1.4 has such support, called mod_groups, but it doesn't seem to
work anymore, you lose yoursubscription when you log off.  :-\

Rob

Subject: [PLUG] nForce2 Memory Woes

I recently thought I take the plunge and upgrade from my aging PIII system
to a fancy new AMD Athlon 3200.  Unfortunately, I can't seem to get the
motherboard (Gigabyte GA-7N400 Pro2 rev 2.0) and the memory (2x Kingston
KVR400X64C25/512) to play together nicely.

When running single channel (64 bit memory path) Memtest86+ v1.11 runs
flawlessly, however as soon as I reconfigure for dual channel (128 bit
memory path) I start seeing errors.  I've swapped both motherboard and
memory yet the problems persist.

I figure I have some options:
  1) Reduce the memory bus frequency so it works
  2) Try the expensive HyperX "matched" RAM
  3) Try Crucial's CAS 3 RAM (vs 2.5 on Kingston's, maybe slower timings
     help?)

Has anyone else had issues with their nForce2 boards running dual channel?
What did you do to solve the problem?

  -- Steve

PS: I plan to use this box for Xvid encoding so I'd like to squeeze every
ounce of performance out of it.  ;-)

On Thu, 2004-05-27 at 00:20, Chris Jantzen wrote:
> On Wed, May 26, 2004 at 10:11:24PM -0700, AthlonRob wrote:
> > Everybody in group A subscribes to the Group A group.  Now they're on
> > that list and that list is in their contact list.  Now to set up their
> > contact list, they just subscribe to the proper group and it's done,
> > they don't have to subscribe to each individual person.
> 
> Ahh. So kinda like how the AIM servers download all your contacts to
> you whenever you install fresh.

That functionality is already in Jabber.  This would make it easier to
add a whole slew of contacts to your list that automatically updates
itself as other new members join or existing members leave....

> > Jabber 1.4 has such support, called mod_groups, but it doesn't seem to
> > work anymore, you lose yoursubscription when you log off.  :-\
> 
> Maybe try a different client? Like GAIM?

I did... I've tried psi, GAIM, and tkabber.  It half-works with gaim
because gaim stores the contact list locally.  If everybody used gaim,
it *might* work, but I don't think it would continually update itself as
it should.

It's a bug in Jabber nobody seems to care about except for me.  After I
posted to the Jabber Admin list about the issues with the setup, I
received an off-list email from somebody stating *they* were shocked no
other IM services support said functionality, including Jabber, and that
it was one of the top requests they had for *their* servers, which
include IM functionality (and are adding this shared groups support in
the next release).

Rob




From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Thu May 27 09:59:02 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Thu May 27 09:59:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] nForce2 Memory Woes
In-Reply-To: <393-58004@sneakemail.com>
References: <393-58004@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <1085677114.7072.34.camel@localhost>

On Wed, 2004-05-26 at 22:55, Steve Bonds wrote:

> I figure I have some options:
>   1) Reduce the memory bus frequency so it works
>   2) Try the expensive HyperX "matched" RAM
>   3) Try Crucial's CAS 3 RAM (vs 2.5 on Kingston's, maybe slower timings
>      help?)
> 
> Has anyone else had issues with their nForce2 boards running dual channel?
> What did you do to solve the problem?

I've assembled four or five nforce2-based systems so far and haven't
encountered any problems with any of them... and I generally use the
third cheapest RAM available.  They're all running in dual-channel mode.

DOES reducing the memory bus frequency solve the problem?  DOES slowing
down the timings solve the problem?  You should be able to test either
of those through the BIOS, I think, with your current RAM.

I'm a huge nForce fan, myself... my old Duron 650 was able to outperform
most PIIIs of the 850-900MHz category in many benchmarks thanks to the
overabundance of memory bandwidth available to it.

Rob

In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405270701510.30932@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405270701510.30932@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

On Thu, May 27, 2004 at 07:12:11AM -0700, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   A new problem with my HP Professional Color 2500C printer: the 11"x17"
> paper feeds slightly skewed. I suspect that the feed rollers need a
> cleaning. Has anyone any experience with this type of problem on a
> large-format printer?

"Platen cleaner" for typewriters should help.  Swab the rubber rollers a
couple times and a bunch of crud should come off.

If your livelihood depends on the printer, I'd recommend taking it in
to The Printer Place for a cleaning rather than doing it yourself.

Mel,
What I have done that works quite well, is to install the mplayerplug-in
v.2.6, which handles most Windows Media and Quicktime movies. For Real,
use the RealPlayer 10 alpha which just recently was released. 
https://player.helixcommunity.org/2004/downloads/ 
Select the RealPlayer Alpha not the HelixPlayer as that does not handle
RealMedia properly. By having both of these installed, I can watch Real,
Windows, and Quicktime as well as AVI, and MPEG. 
Because of the crappy way Yahoo Movies is set up, you seem forced to
have Windows Media Player as your only selection even with RealPlayer 10
installed. When I tried the Spiderman 2 trailer mplayerplug-in started,
and then it took about 5 minutes for the clip to load, only to have just
the sound work and not the video. This may be a problem with the .wmv
format. Not certain on that. It's the first time I've seen an issue
though. I've just watched 3 short films on atomfilms.com with the
RealPlayer 10 plugin and it worked great!

Enjoy,

Garrett Mickelson
gmickels at yahoo.com

Micro$oft, your potential (to earn money), our passion (to extort it).

On Thu, May 27, 2004 at 09:10:53AM -0700, Colin Kuskie wrote:
<snip>

Several things here set off my BS detectors.

> Attention All School Staff: Teachers, Students and Faculty Members:

Claims to address a special group, but really could be anyone since no
school is specified.  Makes folks think they're getting in on a special
deal, even when it's not.
  
> You Must Respond By 5 P.M. Friday, May 28, 2004.

"Act NOW or you might miss out!" is a standard sales tactic.  Gets the
adrenaline pumping, prevents deliberation and checking with other folks.
For me, it is a MAJOR red flag.

> Through a special arrangement, Avtech Direct is offering a limited
>  allotment of BRAND NEW, top of-the-line, name-brand desktop computers
> at more than 50% off MSRP 

In there are six of the stock phrases that are burned in the brain of
every sleazeball salesman when he emerges from the primordial ooze and
begins his instictive migration to the nearest car lot or discount
furniture store.

> These professional grade Desktops are fully equipped with 2004
>  next generation technology, making these the best performing
> computers money can buy.

Four or five more stock phrases there.  Was this thing computer-
generated or something?

Oh, and the specs are for last year's bottom-of-the-line model.  You can
do better for $200 at Fry's or Wal-Mart.  Heck, you (or your friend) can
just about do better with a volunteer stint at FreeGeek.

Influenced by Cialdini,
  Aaron

On Thu, 27 May 2004, Aaron Burt wrote:

> Uses the PCL5c language, same as a Color LaserJet, which is well-
> supported under Linux.

Aaron,

  I noted that it does use PCL5; the linuxprinter.org site doesn't list that
model, however.

> Never used the color LED printers, but Oki's B&W LED models are IMO some
> of the best printers around.  Very crisp output, cheap consumables and
> quite durable.

  I'm trying to find the cost of the consumables. Not that easy. May require
a call to Okidata. (I had an Oki dot-matrix printer that I sold to a former
associate. It's still working perfectly after 20 years with one replacement
print head. Great products.)

  A serious reservation, however, is weight: 72 kg! That's 159 pounds --
without the duplexer (which I don't need for color in any case). That is a
_very_ heavy printer for a SOHO.

> Wonder if there's a continuous-ink system for it?

  I doubt it. Ink cartridges have expiration dates (about 2 years) and the
printer refuses to run if a cartridge is expired. PITA! I don't know about
the print heads, but when replacing the expired black cartridge didn't print
the entire length of an 11"x17" page in portrait mode I bought a replacement
black print head. That solved that problem.

  The color printer is used only for producing maps that accompany reports
and permit applications. I just don't use it that frequently. But, when I
need it, the tabloid-size paper is exceptionally valuable for clarity of
presentation. And, some agencies require maps to be that size, too.

Thanks,

Rich

That's what MSRP is. (Manufactures Suggested Retail Price for those that 
don't know.)

Basically, that's what the manufacture thinks is the fair market value 
for the item you are purchasing. Most of the time, you will purchase 
stuff at much less than MSRP.

I've seen a lot of (Tom Petersen) retailers that advertise (Fry's) 
discounts from MSRP to make you (Damark) think you are getting a 
fantastic deal. Without checking it out, you may be paying more than the 
regular price, elsewhere.

Kudos to the guy that decided to check this out before jumping. :)

Russ

From gmickels at yahoo.com  Thu May 27 15:06:02 2004
From: gmickels at yahoo.com (Garrett Mickelson)
Date: Thu May 27 15:06:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Movie trailers
In-Reply-To: <1085689751.19873.24.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
References: <1085622904.18120.26.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
	 <1085681249.4441.64.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1085689751.19873.24.camel@d8qbcf21.comcast.net>
Message-ID: <1085695537.10993.9.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Mel,
Distro shouldn't be an issue. What I do is find one location for all
plugins, i.e. /usr/lib/mozilla (Fedora Core 2) and then simlink the
plugins directory in all other mozilla directories to that one. Mozilla
usually scans a number of directories to find plugins including
~/.mozilla/plugins, /opt/mozilla/plugins, /usr/lib/mozilla-X.X/plugins,
etc. but I find it easiest to locate all plugins in one directory then
simlink to it. Most non-ditro based RPMs tend to
use /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins/ as the install location for their plugins.
Your solution maybe something like that.
As for realplayer, first uninstall the old RP:
rpm -e RealPlayer-8.0.3.465-10
then install the new:
rpm -Uvh RealPlayer-0.3.0.120-20040517.i586.rpm

This will install the plugin automagically
into /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins, btw.

The interface is much nicer and is GTK2. It handles media better than
RP8 as well. 

Good luck!

-Garrett

Garrett Mickelson
gmickels at yahoo.com

Micro$oft, your potential (to earn money), our passion (to extort it).

From danh at fork.com  Thu May 27 17:46:01 2004
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)

Subject: [PLUG] Richard M. Stallman On Tuesday, June 8 will give a speech
 at Portland State University
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.52.0405261656330.26766@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0405271724110.23315-100000@cohiba.fork.com>


On Wed, 26 May 2004, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> 
> On Wed, 26 May 2004, Dan Haskell wrote:
> > "GNU/Linux"? oy.
> 
> That's what Debian's distributing, I don't know about others.

I don't want to start another flamewar about this, so I'll state my
opinion once and withdraw from the field:

Debian is free to call their Linux whatever they want. So is RedHat,
Yellow Dog, etc. However, Richard Stallman has *no* right to tell others
what to call their distro. There's nothing in the GNU license that says
"you're free to redistribute this software as long as you prepend 'GNU/'
to the name". If Stallman wants to insist on a name then maybe the FSF
ought to come up with it's own distro.

Truth be told, for years the GNU's Bulletin referred to the OS as simply
"Linux". This whole "you must call it GNU/Linux" thing is relatively new.

> Certainly makes it easier for people to know what they're getting once
> you're also distributing GNU/Hurd and whatever else.

I won't hold my breath for that one. :)

Dan

I have been trying to stay out of this mess, but this time I have to
speak up.

On Wed, 2004-05-26 at 22:58, Michael Robinson wrote:
> Some war hero, why doesn't he support body armor for
> the troops among other essential supplies? 

If you were watching PBS TV last Friday night (NOW with Bill Moyers),
you would know the truth about that misleading TV ad. Right after the
Vietnam war, when most of the country (Democrat and Republican) was
trying to reduce the size of the military, Kerry joined a great number
of Congressmen in voting against a large spending bill. One of the many
(MANY) items on the spending bill was body armor.

In short, characterizing a vote against an appropriations bill as a lack
of support for body armor is ridiculous and misleading.

I know it is too much to ask, but it pays to check your facts before
making allegations. Most everything you see in political ads (from
either side of the aisle) is misleading.

Evan

P.S. I'm not going to respond to anything you say in response to this,
so just don't bother. If you must say something, please send it directly
to me.

Dan> [...] However, Richard Stallman has *no* right to tell others
Dan> what to call their distro. [...]

I think if you read closely, he is *asking* people to call it
GNU/Linux.  He might also be choosing to cooperate more with people
who do.  I don't see anything wrong with that.  Just plain "Linux"
really only accurately refers to the kernel.  The choice "GNU/Linux"
for the kernel plus the rest of the operating system is somewhat
arbitrary, just as any other choice is.  I personally try not to judge
other people for the name they give it.  The important thing is that
it exists and that it is Free Software.

Anyway, now we've got at least 4 cents.

Jeme> Certainly makes it easier for people to know what they're

Jeme> else.

From guy1656 at ados.com  Fri May 28 08:05:03 2004
From: guy1656 at ados.com (GLL)
Date: Fri May 28 08:05:03 2004
Subject: [PLUG] OT - Geek Food Now Officially Defined
In-Reply-To: <20040528033431.GA988@nellump.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405271150330.32344@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
  <87pt8pmiff.fsf@ursine.ca> <20040528033431.GA988@nellump.net>
Message-ID: <200405280811.44802.guy1656@ados.com>

: > GLL <guy1656 at ados.com> writes:
: > > That's all we need. Next comes ISO-9000 for pizza control.
: >
: > Well, it wouldn't be ISO-9000, that's already taken.  Another ISO
: > number could be subbed in, though.
:
: ISO-9000 is a set of quality management standards. It is process-based,
: not product-based. So, yes, ISO-9000 could be used for pizza production.

The funny thing about -9000, compared to -9001, -9002 or QS-9000 (automotive) 
is that ALL it really does is say 'write your quality plan down, and show 
inspectors that you are following your written plan.' There is NO requirement 
for process improvement (unless you write that in.)

I was at a 9000-certified stamping plant where the process boiled down to 
'stuff whatever crap that comes out of the final machine into boxes, and ship 
the closed boxes to customers.' No verifications on how accurately the 
machines were producing, (such as CPK.)

So, 'throw stuff on the dough, bake it and call it a pizza.'

- GLL

From keithl at kl-ic.com  Fri May 28 09:51:02 2004
From: keithl at kl-ic.com (Keith Lofstrom)
Date: Fri May 28 09:51:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Tracking down missing OS code author
Message-ID: <20040528165004.GA11542@gate.kl-ic.com>

This may be OT, but it relates to open source.  What happens to an
OS program when the author/website can no longer be found?

Many of you have seen my presentation on Dirvish for disk-to-disk
backups.  I had quite a correspondence going with Dirvish author
J.W. Schultz, with the last email from him dated March 1.  I received
no emails after March 1, which I chalked up to either busyness,
offendedness, lack of social skills, or "other" (after 50 years,
people still surprise me a lot, programmers especially).  In all
that email, I never learned his first name or what city he lives in.

Well, last night I learned that the Dirvish website
(http//www.pegasys.ws/dirvish) is no longer responding (it was up
a couple of months ago).   This led me to check with some of his
other correspondents, look for postings to the RSYNC mailing list,
Kernel mailing list, etc.  Apparently he dropped of the radar just
after March 1.

I know JW is older than I am, having discussed big-iron/punch-card
machines in his email (yes, I've used punch cards and paper tape).  
Further sleuthing revealed that his pegasys.ws website is registered
as a "dot website", and the .ws domain registrar (western samoa ?!)
does not reveal names, email addresses, etc.  The IP address is within
the xo.com subnet around the Bay area (thank you traceroute);  no news
articles or obituaroes for "Schultz", though.  Not that you are
required to reveal your real name on the internet.  There are, or
course, a zillion companies with Pegasys and Technologies in their
names.  There are also about 150 J. Schultzes listed in the Bay
area; and given his privacy habits, he may well be unlisted.

Can anyone suggest other means for finding a software guy?  Social
engineering techniques to apply to xo.com, the .ws registrar, SUSE
(his distro of choice), etc?  

If he is not findable, at what point do I set up a Dirvish website
of my own and start supporting it?  What is the etiquette here?

And for the rest of you O.S. authors, what are you doing about
continuity after you are unexpectedly called to a meeting with 
the Great Penguin In The Sky?

Keith

-- 
Keith Lofstrom           keithl at ieee.org         Voice (503)-520-1993
KLIC --- Keith Lofstrom Integrated Circuits --- "Your Ideas in Silicon"
Design Contracting in Bipolar and CMOS - Analog, Digital, and Scan ICs

In-Reply-To: <20040528165004.GA11542@gate.kl-ic.com>
References: <20040528165004.GA11542@gate.kl-ic.com>
Message-ID: <200405281002.38764.kyle@silverbeach.net>

On Friday 28 May 2004 09:50, Keith Lofstrom wrote:
> Can anyone suggest other means for finding a software guy?  Social
> engineering techniques to apply to xo.com, the .ws registrar, SUSE
> (his distro of choice), etc?

Arrest records?

Since his site went away some time after he disappeared, it might be 
intentional.  Or maybe he had a heart attack or something and his 
registration expired while he was in the hospital.  Maybe he found a 
bus with his name on it :-(

> If he is not findable, at what point do I set up a Dirvish website
> of my own and start supporting it?  What is the etiquette here?

I'd pop up a site relatively soon so that the search engines get it, 
but make sure that there are disclaimers that this is just a public 
service "for great software from the MIA author" and that you'll be 
redirecting to the original site once it is back.  That should make 
it clear to the author (if he is still around) that you are just 
trying to help rather than take over the project.  I'd collect 
patches and code.  I'd also put a plea for more information about the 
author on the site.  

If the author stays under the radar for more than a few months without 
showing up somewhere on a search engine, then I'd assume that he's 
either no longer capable of being on line or for some other reason 
has voluntarily dropped out.  Whatever the reason, you're it at that 
point.

Software that is orphaned without explanation rarely seems to come 
back without a supporter.  I cannot think of any examples.  I have 
seen sites that are mirrors of sites that dropped off the Internet 
for some reason.  Those sometimes grow into the main site for the 
software.

> And for the rest of you O.S. authors, what are you doing about
> continuity after you are unexpectedly called to a meeting with
> the Great Penguin In The Sky?

"Apres moi, le deluge" seems most common.

Best,
Kyle

Well they drilled it in to our heads in Marine Corps bootcamp in 1987,

equipment load out. Nor during the (First) Gulf War were we ever allowed
to provide our own weapons, nor keep any we found on the battlefield. It
was an instant court martial in either case.

It looks like the error was "can't open /dev/dsp", but I agree with
Rob.  Michael, it would help a lot if you formed your questions more
clearly, possibly by like this:

<preamble about the problem> I'm getting these errors:

$ <command>
<error output>
...

I believe I've pointed you to ESR's essay on asking good questions,
please take that seriously.  There's a bit for everyone in that doc,
and it is reasonably well written.

Regarding your permission problems.  Have you logged the user out and
back in so the group change takes affect? Have you checked the
permissions on /dev/dsp to ensure you are part of the correct group,
and that the permissions on the device haven't been fubar'd?

-Rogan

> including ~/.mozilla/plugins, /opt/mozilla/plugins,
> /usr/lib/mozilla-X.X/plugins, etc. but I find it easiest to locate all
> plugins in one directory then simlink to it. Most non-ditro based RPMs
> tend to use /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins/ as the install location for
> their plugins. Your solution maybe something like that.
I have found plugin directories under /usr/lib/mozilla, /opt/mozilla,
and my user directory ~/.mozilla/. I created symlinks from wherever the
actual file exists to the others. I believe that Suse wanted them in
~/.mozilla/plugins, as the mplayer plugin is working after I created the
symlink there.

> As for realplayer, first uninstall the old RP:
> rpm -e RealPlayer-8.0.3.465-10
Did that, mo problem.
> then install the new:
> rpm -Uvh RealPlayer-0.3.0.120-20040517.i586.rpm
Did that.
> 
> This will install the plugin automagically into
> /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins, btw.
I found it in /usr/local/RealPlayer.
> 
> The interface is much nicer and is GTK2. It handles media better than
> RP8 as well. 
Yes, I agree, at least as far as I have been able to use it. I have been
able to bring up airamericaradio.com. But, I am back to having the
RealPlayer selection grayed out when trying to view a movie trailer. It
does provide a link to Real for a download of the Windoze version (Plus
trial). There are lots of plugins in the appropriate directory, I
created several symlinks to ~.mozilla/plugins. But evidently have got
the right one(s) yet. 
> 
> Good luck!
> 
> -Garrett
Thanks,

  Mel

From AthlonRob at axpr.net  Sat May 29 12:48:01 2004
From: AthlonRob at axpr.net (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat May 29 12:48:01 2004
Subject: [PLUG] Configuring wireless.opts

	 <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405291119420.9015@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1085860053.3891.18.camel@localhost>

On Sat, 2004-05-29 at 11:26, Rich Shepard wrote:

>   What should I check to test the routing? On the cat5 the connection works
> just fine so I have to assume that /etc/host* is not where I have the
> problem.

I've honestly just skimmed this thread, so let me apologize if I'm
coming from Mars....

If you've set your default route and stuff over eth0, then you unplug
eth0 and enable your wifi connection, your default route is likely still
going to be over eth0, even if eth0 is down and your wifi connection has
eth0's IP address.

I'm not sure if you're trying to switch back and forth between wired and
wireless... if you are, just re-issue the route add default gw line
every time you switch to be sure it's set for the proper interface.

Rob

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun May 30 12:28:02 2004
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun May 30 12:28:02 2004
Subject: [PLUG] From programmer to ...
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.56.0405301225420.25503@salmo.appl-ecosys.com>

A computer programmer, bored with his job, decided to start his own
business. Wanting to do something totally different from his current
occupation, he bought a mating pair of rheas and a large tract of land.

His rhea farm was soon doing a booming business as there appeared to be a
great demand for the birds. Not being satisfied with just selling the birds,
the rhea farmer started researching how the birds were being used. He found
that all parts of the birds were being used, except the feathers. Nobody
wanted the plainly colored rhea feathers.

The ex-programmer, now rhea farmer, purchased some equipment, technical
people, and chemicals, and was soon selling fancy, colored rhea feathers.
The resulting sales were amazing and made the new feather merchant very
happy. There was one small problem. The workers making the colored feathers
were becoming quite ill. The concerned young man called in a number of
doctors to determine the nature of the illness.

It was discovered that without exception, the workers had developed a severe
case of ... "dye a rhea".

Subject: [PLUG] Just a note for the unaware.
Message-ID: <1086026851.9604.31.camel@atlas.cadtocam.com>

I was all excited about getting my 2.6.3 kernel running.  Then I tried
to start X windows.  No mouse.  I had a mouse in 2.4.x.  No mouse.  No
serial ports.  Recompiled the kernel to get serial ports.  Still no
serial ports.

Hmmmm.  Maybe there are module for the serial ports now.  There is for
the parallel ports. 

Sure, enough.  /lib/modules/2.6.3/kernel/drivers/serial/serial_core.ko
and 8250.ko.  These are new to 2.6.3.  I loaded them like any other
module:  modprobe 8250 loaded them just fine.  

I even got a message that /dev/ttyS0 and /dev/ttyS1 had interrupts
assigned.

Reran XFree86 -configure and got actually mouse action.

Neat. 

Ken Stephens
CAD2CAM.COM

than his wish to not see it.

Ignorance is not bliss and willfull ignorance is sociopathic.

> Why wouldn't you want to respect his obvious desire to not communicate
> with you?

A person cannot know whether or not they want information until they are
presented with that information and can make a decision.  It's a flat
contradiction to say that you can know what you don't want to know.

> That's a spammer's attitude, that your message is more important than
> his wish to not see it.

Um, not quite.  Spam is unsolicited.  This guy was soliciting responses.

And I was right.  He was interested to read my response and removed the
block.
